PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Multicultural Television Services for Wollongong
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the electors and residents within the City of Wollongong (State of New South Wales) respectfully showeth that:
(1) despite promises from the Government Radio 2EA did not begin transmission in Wollongong until 1979;
(2) Wollongong has one of the largest migrant populations in Australia in that over half the population are born overseas or have one or more parent born overseas;
(4) the cost of privately installing UHF aerials is prohibitive for many migrants in the city.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate use its powers to ensure that a repeater transmitter be opened in Wollongong on both UHF and VHF bands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Carrick, partly as Minister for National Development and Energy and partly as Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the Treasury submission to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources identified Australia's steaming coal deposits as a resource whose development could well attract some type of resources tax? Is it a fact that the Queensland Government has accepted an offer by the Winchester consortium led by the British Petroleum company to pay a resources tax in the form of extra levies on steaming coal shipments? Is it also a fact that British Petroleum Australia Ltd is wholly owned by the multinational BP organisation, which is in turn 46 per cent owned by the British Government? Is it therefore a fact that, as a result of the Federal Government's failure to levy a resources tax on behalf of all the Australian people, the high profitability of this venture will be carved up between the Queensland Government and shareholders, including the United Kingdom Government? Why does this Government put the interests of the Queensland and British treasuries before its own?
—I have not had the opportunity to read the Treasury's submission. I have it and I have put it aside because I think it is important to read it in depth.
—It is even more important that you understand it.

—Mr President, sometimes I have some difficulty in understanding some of the honourable senators opposite. Senator Tate will appreciate that submissions have been received from about five departments in recent days. All of them are voluminous and all of them need very careful study. I have to say to him that, whilst I would like to respond-and I will in due course-to that part of his question which relates to my own knowledge of the matter, I have made only a superficial scansion of it as yet. I am aware of the Queensland Government's granting of the Winchester franchise. I am aware that BP has a significant holding in it. I am aware that the British Government has a holding in BP. In fact, in London not so long ago, I discussed that matter with BP. I am aware that the Queensland Government has put on a series of charges, particularly rail freight charges, that I imagine are resource taxes. Fundamentally, the people of Queensland, and therefore the people of Australia, will benefit through the taxation that accrues upon the resources produced being redirected to them. The Senate is aware of the Commonwealth Government's stated attitude to a resource tax. With regard to the position of the Commonwealth Government at this moment, I have nothing more to add to what the Treasurer has said. I regret that I have not read that document. I will do so.

—I bring to the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport a campaign being waged by the South Australian region of the Australian Road Federation to urge increased Commonwealth grants for roads. In particular, I note two ARF claims. One is that the Commonwealth Government is reducing, in real terms, the money available to States for road construction and maintenance. The other is that South Australia's share of Commonwealth road grants has declined steadily since 1960 from 11.3 per cent to 8.5 per cent. I ask the Minister: Are these claims true? Will the Minister give further consideration to so applying a liberal federalism approach to road funding that funding for State roads will be and will be seen to be a matter for State government decision and State government accountability to the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can advise Senator Teague that apparently the figures which were cited by him in his question and which originated from the Australian Road Federation are substantially correct. However, the figures cited in relation to the claim of a reduction in real terms are another matter because it does not seem that they have been prepared on a valid basis. The Minister for Transport, I think last year, announced that the Commonwealth would provide grants totalling $3,650m to the various States and the Northern Territory for road works over the five years from 1980-81 to 1984-85. The annual apportionment of these grants involves annual percentage increases of over 11 per cent in 1980-81, 9 per cent in 1981-82, 7 per cent in 1982-83 and 6 per cent in 1983-84 and in 1984-85. These increases take into account both inflation expectations and the responsible economic policies that the Government is pursuing.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, let me give honourable senators a little bit of history on this matter. Prior to 1969, Commonwealth road grants to the States were distributed on the basis of a formula which attached equal weighting to area, population and the number of registered motor vehicles. But since then, the allocation of grants amongst the States has been gradually brought into line with the assessments of the relative road needs undertaken by the former Commonwealth Bureau of Roads. In this context, the proportion of the Commonwealth grants going to South Australia has been in line with the share recommended by that Bureau. As to the advocation of the federalism approach to road funding, Commonwealth roads assistance arrangements to apply after 30 June 1981 are still being considered by the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, follows the question asked by my colleague Senator Tate. I ask the Minister: Is it fair to assume that it is the Government's belief that a tax on resources at the Commonwealth level would endanger investment decisions by mining companies? Has the Government made any comparative study of resource taxes imposed by other countries and the effects on mining investment by foreign companies in those countries from which it would draw that conclusion? Is it the view of the Government that a State-imposed resource tax would not inhibit development whereas a federally-imposed resource tax would inhibit development? In asking this question, I refer to a matter raised by Senator Tate, namely, the rail levy in Queensland. I also refer to the very high wage levels paid by the Utah company in its coal developments in Queensland and ask: Is not that, in a sense, an imposition by some body other than the Commonwealth Government of a kind of resource rental tax on that company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a very healthy thing that there are discussions throughout Australia at the moment on the whole concept of how the individual Australian family can benefit from resources. In the concept of us all seeking to find an answer to that, I think that the dialogue is good, both at the Senate committee level and in probing in Parliament. I believe that studies have been made by the Treasury and the Government of the various resource-type taxes levied by other countries. The Government has, in its own judgment and with the knowledge of the impact of its own taxation at this moment, made the decision that it does not propose to levy such a tax. It has the view that its range of taxes, at the moment, are equitable and are the mix that is likely to create the best yield for Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true-Senator Button has made a useful point-that the States' imposing of a resources tax is having an economic impact. It would be silly to deny it; it is true. The States are sovereign and they are entitled to levy those taxes. They levy a variety of indirect taxes with or without any judgment by the Commonwealth as to whether those taxes are good or not. I also acknowledge that the high wage levels of the Utah company are a method of distribution of resources. It may well be that the Commonwealth and the States will have discussions at Premiers Conference level on various taxes, and on their nature and impact. This will have to be done over the years if we are to proceed as a Commonwealth. We are a federation. Inside that there are likely to be differences and aberrations. I acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Firstly, if, as the Minister says, the States are sovereign in these matters-of course they are-and are able to impose what is effectively a resource rental tax, have there been any discussions at the Commonwealth-State level in relation to the Federal-State financial arrangements which would take into account the position of those States not capable of imposing any form of resource rental tax because they have no mining development? Secondly, if there is a study of overseas experience in relation to resource rental tax of which the Government has taken account, will the Minister undertake to table at least a summary of what that study reveals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I acknowledge that these are useful probes. The whole question of the financing of the Commonwealth and the States is coming up for review at the next Premiers Conference which, I think, is scheduled to be held in a month or more, before the present financial agreement guarantees expire. There will be a total look at financing. Senator Button will know that the Premiers have met and made some recommendations. Inevitably, I think, the Commonwealth and the States will look at the whole field of taxation. I cannot predict whether there will be discussions as to the impact of resources tax. I imagine that there would be in the free flow of debate at the Premiers Conference.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the honourable senator's first question, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has as its primary objective the question of equalisation. Undoubtedly one of its fundamental headaches and problems will be to look at these new and emerging taxes, and the yields that States can have, and to see what may be done for others. Honourable senators must bear in mind that the Commission is at present undertaking a major Australia-wide look at equalisation. Senator Button will know this. He will also know that the basis of it is to bring other States to the standard of Victoria and New South Wales. It may well be that that will have to be looked at in the future and that there will be a substitution of Queensland and Western Australia for the purposes of those kinds of values; but the equalisation would be fundamental.

I cannot say whether there is any one document dealing with this matter. I draw the attention of Senator Button to a previous inquiry by, I think, Senator Thomas's Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which asked my Department for some objective statements on resource taxes. I think it tabled a document which canvassed the pros and cons of the matter. If the honourable senator seeks further information, I will be happy to provide it to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer to a question asked on 26 February by Senator Puplick regarding the importation of gold chain in continuous lengths in order to avoid the 30 per cent extra duty. The Minister stated in his answer that representatives of the jewellery industry had provided the Department of Industry and Commerce with detailed information on the situation, which was being examined as a matter of urgency to determine whether the level of assistance for local industry should be referred to the Industries Assistance Commission. Does the 1978 IAC report on jewellery and other precious metal ware cover the situation, therefore precluding the need for an additional inquiry? Will the Minister consider the findings of that report sufficient for a speedy decision to be made?

—I understand that, although the goods which Senator Thomas referred to-that is, continuous gold chain-were included in the general reference covering a wide variety of jewellery, precious metal and other items given to the Industries Assistance Commission at the time, in fact no evidence was presented to the IAC in respect of continuous gold chain. The IAC approach was to recommend minimum duty rates in cases where there was no known local production. Of course, the IAC report was considered by the Government in the normal manner as a result of recommendations which the Commission laid down. However, for those reasons the IAC report is not considered sufficient to enable the Government to deal with the present situation, no evidence having been given by local manufacturers. Therefore, as indicated previously in answer to Senator Puplick's question, the importation of chain in continuous lengths at minimum duty rates is being examined by the Department as a matter of urgency to see whether the matter should be referred to the IAC for further inquiry and report.

—I direct my two-part question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It deals with the complex question of the acquisition of Australian citizenship. By way of preface, I refer to the fact that an Australian national soccer team played in North and South Korea some years ago. The players wore the green and gold jersey but travelled on British and Irish passports. My colleague, Senator Douglas McClelland, would be aware of this. The government of the day cut corners in order to give the players Australian citizenship; otherwise they would have been disqualified from playing. But that is water under the bridge. Has Sir Arthur George been told repeatedly what the Australian citizenship requirements are? It is not a question of football mercenaries wanting to cut corners. As in the Boden case, just what is being done to convince the Australian Soccer Federation that every time there is an overseas tour it must plan ahead and tell players what Australian citizenship is all about? Secondly, I refer to another case-a sadder one-the Robyn Shaw case. It involves a 13-year-old girl and the problem of the wife marrying a second time and Australia apparently not recognising the parental control of the second husband, which means that the girl is denied Australian citizenship. Will the Minister take this matter on board too because, obviously, some minor adjustment could meet this everyday occurrence?

—I am afraid that I will have to take both Senator Mulvihill's questions on board, as he puts it, and refer them to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I have some general knowledge only in relation to the soccer players who, perhaps at the last minute before leaving Australia, have had difficulty in obtaining Australian citizenship. It seems to be a reasonable proposition that they should plan and prepare for these tours and obtain citizenship in good time.
—Or give Australians a go, as we do in rugby league.

—I would not dream of getting into the policies of the Australian Soccer Federation or of the Australian Rugby Football League. I will refer those questions to the Minister and get a detailed answer for Senator Mulvihill.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question because I think the Minister has ignored the thrust of the preface to my question. I would like a clear cut verification of the fact that we did bend over backwards on the Korean venture in order to cut corners on citizenship qualifications. Senior immigration officers admitted that to me on Senate Estimates Committee C. I think that ought to be made abundantly clear to Sir Arthur George. I am sure that Senator Baume would nod his head because he would know of the summit conference when that fact was told to the Australian Soccer Federation.
—I will ensure that that aspect of the question is given proper consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Minister seen the report in today's Australian of evidence given to the Norris inquiry into ownership and control of newspapers in Victoria? I refer to that part of the evidence given by Mr Roger Wilson, the secretary of the Victorian branch of the Seamen's Union and a member of the National Committee of the Communist Party of Australia, in which he said that, during the early 1970s, apart from his present positions he was also a member of the Melbourne Moratorium Campaign Committee; that that Committee did not believe that the Age newspaper was reporting the moratorium campaign in a sympathetic way-I quote Mr Wilson: 'In general we were not very happy in terms of the reporting . . . throughout the nation about our involvement in Vietnam'-and that the Seamen's Union felt it necessary to apply a little pressure to the Age. Mr Wilson claimed that a deputation from the Seamen's Union put it to the management of the Age that, unless its reporting became more sympathetic, its supply of newsprint might well be withdrawn. The newsprint came mainly from Tasmania. According to Mr Wilson's evidence, this caused the reporting of the moratorium suddenly to improve. I ask: Does this evidence before the Norris inquiry put at risk the credibility of the freedom of the Press in this country? If so, what action can be taken to establish the truth or otherwise of the evidence given?

—My attention has been drawn to the newspaper article in today's Australian headed 'Union ''threatened'' The Age on Vietnam coverage'. I can confirm that the article contains the information identified by the honourable senator. It seems to me that deputations from any group in society to anyone else are in order as a general proposition but that threats of the kind set out in the article are not. I suggest that threats of the type reported in the article are not in the best interests of the processes of a democratic country. In regard to the point raised by the honourable senator as to the verity or otherwise of the information, I cannot answer that. I will seek further advice from my colleague, the Minister whom I represent.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, follows the question asked by Senator Walters. Did Sir Robert Southey as National President of the Liberal Party in 1972 write to Sir William McMahon, the then Prime Minister, making suggestions 'as to how the Age newspaper can be brought into line'? Did he in that letter offer threats and suggestions as to how the Age could be brought into line by that type of action?

—I have no knowledge of any letters written by Sir Robert Southey to anyone. Nothing in the question asked by Senator Button would make me alter any of the sentiments I expressed in my previous answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the sales tax that is being imposed on the manufacture of stage sets and properties for the Nimrod Theatre in Sydney? The Nimrod Theatre, of course, is a non-profit professional theatre company. Is the Minister aware that a 15 per cent sales tax is being imposed and that the base of the tax is the full cost of materials on which sales tax has already been paid on purchase, plus twice the cost of the labour involved? Does the Minister agree that on the face of it this is an iniquitous tax which will do serious harm to the performing arts in Australia? In the light of representations from the Confederation of Australian Professional Performing Arts and others, including Senator Martin and Senator Teague, will the Minister urgently investigate this penal sales tax, which is about to be imposed in the trial case of Nimrod, before it is passed on to all other non-profit professional theatre companies in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that matter to the Treasurer to seek information with regard to it and to see what response he has to make to the suggestion from Senator Hamer.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the agreement on B52 bombers which the Government prevented us from debating in the Parliament last night. Has the Government a firm and unequivocal undertaking from the United States that under no circumstances will B52 bombers carry nuclear weapons over Australia? What monitoring arrangements, other than taking the word of the United States military, has the Government made to ensure that the United States sticks to its agreement? Is it fair to assume from the inclusion of sub-paragraph (VII) of the agreement, which allows for changes in the agreement after consultation, and sub-paragraph (VIII), which refers to our commitment under the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, that the United States at least has in contemplation the possibility of the aircraft carrying nuclear weapons and has discussed that matter with Mr Street and with the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister made it clear that the agreement between the Australian Government and the United States Administration would be that the aircraft staging through Darwin under the arrangements set out for surveillance flights and navigation training would be unarmed and carry no bombs; and there will be no qualifications to that. The Government has looked at the possibility that another nation may wish to raise some other problems as time goes on. It has said that no changes can occur in this situation without consultation and, therefore, without this Government's having the sovereign right to make a decision. This Government has made a clear decision not to permit bombs, nuclear devices or any armament on these aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the great values of an alliance such as the ANZUS treaty and one of the great values we learned from events in 1942 and 1943 is that there must be a strong working partnership and mutual trust. I would feel very sad if there were a suggestion of bad faith between the governments of the United States and Australia. To my recollection there has never been any evidence of bad faith in anything to which the United States of America has committed itself with regard to this country. I think it is a very good start in defence co-partnerships to presume the goodwill and honesty of one's partner. Indeed, the people of Australia will acknowledge with immense gratitude the co-partnership of the United States from 1942 to 1945. Indeed, the very survival of Australia derived from that. The people of Australia understand that and will applaud this agreement. I am not aware of specific monitoring arrangements. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister and seek any further information. But my view is that the agreement is clear, that it is enforceable and that nothing can change without the Commonwealth Government's agreeing to that change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I raise it with some hesitancy and I raise it with you. I remind you that you are here to protect the rights of all members, particularly those in Opposition and on this side of the House. This subject matter relates to defence and it is one of the most significant decisions made in recent years. Last night the Parliament was virtually debarred from debating it. I was gagged from making a statement. This morning I have asked three questions and, with great respect to the Minister, I have received an answer to none of them.
—Senator, what is your point of order?

—The point of order is: I asked the Minister a question in three parts: 'Has the United States given a firm undertaking?' 'What monitoring of the United States is going to take place?' 'Was the matter of nuclear weapons discussed between the United States and Australia?' They were the three parts of the question that I asked and, with great respect to the Minister, I got an answer to none of them. Surely the answers to questions should be relevant and, Mr President, I believe that it is your responsibility to ensure that they are.

—The Minister has the right to reply to the question in the way in which he did. He replied to the points that were raised. There is no point of order. Points of order are raised for breaches of Standing Orders. I can see no breach of the Standing Orders on the basis on which you have raised a point of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to the Commonwealth Public Service Board circular entitled 'Smoking in Commonwealth Government Offices' which draws attention to Government policy on smoking in Government offices and suggests action to implement that policy. While I recognise that, in applying Government policy, the Director-General of Health must take account of several factors including a balancing of the rights of smokers and non-smokers, I ask the Minister: How can the Department of Health, Australia's primary health authority, say on the one hand that involuntary smoking, according to medical evidence and by Government recognition, is harmful and can damage health and then propose that the source of the harmful pollution be able to continue? Does the Minister agree that non-smokers and, in particular, those people who are forced to become involuntary smokers have certain rights which need to be recognised and protected? Does he also agree that a compromise needs to be reached so as to allow smokers and non-smokers to co-exist with a minimum of discomfort to each group? What action has been taken by the Government to protect the rights of non-smokers in the Commonwealth Public Service? Has consideration been given to providing smoking lounges with special exhaust ventilation facilities to meet the requirements of the smoking minority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen is quite correct in saying that this is a problem of balancing the rights of different groups. It is a problem that requires common sense and compromise. The circular to which he referred was issued under the aegis of the Public Service Board last November by the Director-General of Health in his role as the occupational health authority in respect of Commonwealth employment. The intention in issuing this circular was twofold: Firstly, to draw attention to the Government's decision on the matter, as announced in its response to recommendation 42 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled 'Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?'; and, secondly, to achieve a balanced, practical approach to a complex problem that takes into account quite a few factors, including the very wide range and nature of work places that exist in the area of Commonwealth employment and the practical difficulties and high costs that would be involved in structural alterations to buildings or air conditioning plants in office buildings, particularly those leased by the Commonwealth. This circular progresses the intentions of the recommendation from the Senate Standing Committee and the proposal of the National Health and Medical Research Council on the rights of non-smokers, which the Senate Committee endorsed.

ANSWER.PARA: As stated in the circular, the policy aims to create a non-smoking working environment for Commonwealth employees with provision for those who wish to smoke, rather than vice versa. In this regard the circular, and the policy it disseminates, represent a significant and practical initiative in improving the overall working conditions of employees. As the Government announced in responding last year to the particular Senate Standing Committee recommendation, it has asked the Standing Consultative Committee on Occupational Health Services-a body chaired by the Public Service Board and comprising relevant departments, including Health, and the peak union councils-to monitor the implementation of the objectives set out in the circular. Whilst the reason for the suggestion that smoking lounges with special exhaust ventilation facilities be provided is appreciated, implementation of the suggestion is not practicable at present because of architectural and engineering-apart from cost-constraints.

As clearly enunciated in the circular, development of specific arrangements within individual work places is a matter primarily to be resolved at each work place, having regard to the general policy and to practicability. That approach is entirely consistent with the intentions of the Senate Standing Committee in making its recommendation. It should be noted, also, that the Committee recognised that there are civil rights to be considered for both smokers and non-smokers. Finally, as the circular was issued only last November, reasonable time must be allowed before the outcome of the actions proposed in the circular can be assessed. The Government has acknowledged the difficulties of applying the policy to office buildings generally. However, as community attitudes to smoking harden, it might be appropriate for further measures to be introduced as the honourable senator suggests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, concerns an Australian Capital Territory prisoner of some former notoriety in this Territory, Mr Kevin Riordan, who is now languishing in a New South Wales gaol. Has the Attorney yet written to Mr Riordan advising him of the Commonwealth's intention or absence of intention, as the case may be, to prosecute him in respect of an escape from custody in 1975? If the Commonwealth does intend to charge Mr Riordan with this offence, why was no action taken long before this, given that he has been in custody, both in New South Wales and in Victoria, for the last five years? Finally, will the Attorney take into account in determining his attitude on this question, first, the obvious stress which has been caused to the prisoner in question by the Commonwealth's apparent inability to make up its mind on this matter; secondly, the fact that it does appear that courts and prison authorities have recently commented favourably on Mr Riordan's general attitudes and change of attitudes; and, thirdly, the fact that Mr Riordan is now eligible for parole on all other charges for which he has previously been convicted and has some reasonable expectation of being released if the Commonwealth does not put further obstacles in his way?

—The case concerning Mr Riordan is a quite complicated one. It has a long history and a number of different features which I do not think it is necessary to go into at this point. The specific question related to whether I have written to Mr Riordan. I have done so, but only just recently. His entitlement to parole is under consideration by the Parole Board. He has taken proceedings against the Parole Board. I do not want to go into that matter; but that is, obviously, a delaying factor. In relation to the question of whether a further prosecution will be launched, I have informed Mr Riordan of the decision that has been made in relation to that matter. I do not think I should make that public until he has been made aware of the decision. I am quite happy to let Senator Evans know the position.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Attorney-General comment on the essence of my question, that is, the suggestion of maladministration by him or his Department in taking so long to reach a decision on what ought to have been a relatively straightforward matter, and causing a great deal of stress to an individual in custody in the process?
—I cannot comment on the reason why there has been some delay.
—Five years delay.

—Goodness me, no. The decision in relation to prosecution of Mr Riordan was taken by the New South Wales authority under a New South Wales law. It went to a court of appeal which decided that that was not the appropriate vehicle for prosecution for the charge of escaping from custody. I do not want to go into all the details about Mr Riordan here. The fact is that that decision was given towards the end of last year; I cannot remember when. The only possible question of delay has been in relation to whether we would prosecute him for a breach of a Commonwealth statute. As I said, that decision has now been made. The other question is that of his release on parole. There may be some question of delay in that area, but the delay is nothing like the period Senator Evans suggested by way of interjection.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Is the Commonwealth Government making any moves to encourage standardisation of high school curricula throughout Australia in view of the high mobility of the Australian population, particularly to Queensland from other States, and the disabilities experienced by children of those who move interstate in pursuit of better employment opportunities and a better way of life?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was Minister for Education, the problems of the differences among the States in standards of education and the problems suffered by parents and students in transferring from one State to another were fairly frequent matters for discussion at the Australian Education Council attended by Education Ministers. So the problem as outlined by Senator Martin is well known to me. The matter is doubly important in Queensland, I imagine, because of the large mobility of people from other States to Queensland. The simple answer, of course, is that there is not an attempt to standardise high school curricula. The reason is that under the Constitution the primary responsibility for education rests with the States and it is inevitable that there would be diversity. Nevertheless, there has been a considerable degree of acceptance by the States that they should move towards some minimal principles of standards.

ANSWER.PARA: Co-operation in curriculum matters occurs at the national level through the Curriculum Development Centre which has been set up to undertake curriculum development tasks and to develop teaching and learning materials for use in schools. The Centre's program involves close co-operation with a wide range of educational authorities and bodies including State catholic and other non-government authorities. I am advised that it is the usual practice in Australia for accrediting authorities to negotiate with tertiary institutions over requirements for entry to their courses. The tertiary institutions have ar- rangements amongst themselves over recognition of academic results. Inevitably, therefore, the Australian Capital Territory accreditation agency has an agreement with the Australian National University which is recognised by all other tertiary institutions in Australia. In summary, an attempt is taking place to get some minimal co-operation among the States to minimise the difficulties of students transferring between the States. But, as it is a recurring problem, I will refer it to the Minister in another place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs read recent reports in the Press stressing the need for an Australian consulate in Bali? I remind the Minister of my repeated calls for at least a consulate office in Bali and I ask: What action has been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether the Minister--
—I am not looking for a job.

— I wondered. I am not aware of recent statements that have been made. I would need to refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to gain information from him as to what priority this sort of movement may have in his own arrangements. I will seek early information on the matter.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory inform the House of the incidence of the parasite, the anchor worm, in trout in Canberra's lakes? Does this infestation produce a trout which is toxic to humans? If the answer to this question is yes, what action will the Government take to restrain the cultivation and dissemination of this parasite by the taxpayers of Australia?

—Unlike former Senator Webster and Senator Chaney, my scientific knowledge in this area is fairly limited. The question of anchor worms has not really come within my ken. However, I will undertake to refer the matter to the Minister for the Capital Territory and perhaps the Minister for Science and Technology to see whether I can obtain an early reply for Senator MacGibbon.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether the Minister has established a committee to inquire into the suitability of the Williamstown naval dockyard to construct follow-on destroyers with proper efficiency, whatever that may mean. Is the chairman of the committee Mr Ross G. Hawke from the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd and the Whyalla shipyards? Does the reference to the committee include a requirement to report on whether the ownership and operation of the dockyard should be transferred to a private company? Has the Government any intention to hand this Commonwealth operation to a private enterprise?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide an early reply.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of statements within the oil and gas industry that off-shore exploration can be seriously prejudiced, particularly in the short term, if the policy is continued of giving contractual preference to Australian constructed floating oil rigs over other rigs, even if those other rigs have been previously contracted to carry out drilling programs? If this is true, does the Government consider that such restrictions could effectively dissuade other foreign rigs from working in Australian waters even though there appears to be an increasing shortage of drilling rigs to carry out such work?

—I am advised that the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association had discussions with Ministers of the Government earlier this year with regard to the particular matters raised by Senator Kilgariff and that, following those discussions, the Association does not see any short term problem. As Australian rigs have firm expectations of employment until June 1983, approval of applications for the temporary importation of rigs over this period would be in accordance with normal government policies. The controls on the temporary importation of foreign vessels have been effective in providing the maximum possible employment for local vessels, at the same time ensuring that sufficient tonnage may be sourced from overseas to meet present commercial requirements. However, that policy is currently under examination to ensure that it does not cause undue difficulty in the petroleum exploration industry.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Are holders of allocations of Bass Strait crude oil entitled to sell their allocations? If so, what rules apply? Why were they not announced in his statement of 17 September last year on the outcome of the Government's review of the crude oil allocation scheme? Is he aware of reports that the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd has indicated that its allocation is for sale? Has he given approval for such a sale?
—I am not aware of the report. I will look it up if Senator Walsh will indicate to me the source of the report.
—The Australian Financial Review of 17 December.
—I will look it up and, in doing so, will provide the honourable senator with a full answer to the remainder of his question.

—Has the Minister for National Development and Energy or the Prime Minister had a request from the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, Dr Amos, for a federally funded ports development study for Tasmania? If so, what type of study is envisaged and will such help be considered within the terms of the Callaghan plan?

—My understanding is that at the meeting in Hobart late in February of the Commonwealth-State officials committee on assistance to Tasmania the State Government presented for Commonwealth consideration a proposal for a fishing port development study. The proposal envisaged, as I understand it, a grant of about $23,000 to study the fishing port facilities of Tasmania in order to provide advice to the Tasmanian Government on possible future fishing port development. Commonwealth assistance for the proposed study is currently being considered by the Commonwealth officials in the working party on assistance to Tasmania. If I get any further information on this matter I will let the honourable senator have it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate has been drawn to the proliferation of car stickers which read:

QUESTION.PARA: Fight inflation. Run over a public servant.

In view of Government members' attacks generally upon public servants-I refer to the derogatory statement made by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Phillip Lynch, boasting that there were now 11,000 fewer bureaucrats with their snouts in the taxation trough-can the Minister say whether there is any similarity in these attitudes? Will the Government dissociate itself from the defamatory statements and call on motorists to have regard to road safety, particularly as it relates to public servants?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen such a bumper sticker. If I had I would have regarded the motorist as having the right to put it on but I would consider it as being in extremely bad taste and extremely inaccurate. Nevertheless, I recognise that some people's form of humour may not be the same as my own or that of other honourable senators. I make it clear that I think all honourable senators, and certainly Government senators, hold the view that the overwhelming number of public servants serve this country well and with dedication and skill. There is, of course, an argument that does not reflect on the individual public servant. That is, that there has been a proliferation of growth in the public sector in the States, the effect of which, in terms of Government expenditure, has been detrimental to the question of government costs, inflation and the welfare of the community. To the extent that one discusses the numbers of public servants and how to deal with them, that is an economic matter. It does not reflect at all upon individual members of the Public Service. They are good Australians doing a good job.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It concerns the delivery of the Australian gold coin by the Royal Australian Mint. In view of the problems relating to the delivery of the 1980 gold coin, will the Minister consider meeting with the Comptroller of the Royal Australian Mint to ensure that procedures can be implemented for the speedy and safe delivery of any future commemorative and other coins of substantial value such as the 1981 gold coin and the 1982 $10 silver Commonwealth Games coin? It seems to me that delivery through the banking system is a safe, secure and established method which could be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer advises me that the problems that arose last year in the distribution of the 1980 gold coin were caused partly by the systems and the methods of the Mint which proved inadequate in the light of the extraordinary interest in the coin. The facilities available to the Mint are currently being examined by departmental officers. They are being considerably upgraded to enable the Mint to cope with its heavy program this year. Revised arrangements for the distribution of the coins are under investigation. Computerised processes are being introduced at the Mint to assist in the handling of future orders. It must be recognised that any large scale operation of this type cannot be guaranteed in advance to be free of all difficulties, but a considerable effort is being put into eliminating all foreseeable problems and in generally streamlining the procedures.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources: Will the Government accede to the demand made by the member for Macarthur, Mr Baume, last Thursday, 5 March-it is recorded on page 499 of Hansard-and impose a levy on live sheep exports in order to encourage further processing in Australia, which in turn will mean increased job opportunities for Australian workers?
—That is a policy matter. I will refer it to the Minister and ask him to give it consideration.
—Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister advise the Senate on the progress of the Government's electoral commitment to set up centres of excellence in Australia?

—I know that the Government is currently active on this matter. I am not aware of the precise point that has been reached on the setting up of the centres of excellence. I will refer the matter to my colleague the Minister for Education in another place and seek information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Australian Government provide food aid to Ethiopia? If so, how is it distributed when it arrives there? Can the Minister assure the Parliament that this aid is reaching the genuinely needy Ethiopian people rather than helping to feed Ethiopian and foreign troops fighting the Eritreans, as is happening with food aid from the European Economic Community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a response.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Government still have plans to appoint a Defence Force ombudsman? If so, can the Government give an indication of when an ombudsman will be appointed?

—As far as I am aware, it is the intention to do so. I do not have any up to date information on the matter and I will refer it to the Minister for Defence and obtain such information as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to you, Mr President. You will recall a question I put to you several years ago regarding the late delivery of the Tasmanian Mercury to the Parliament. Following your intervention, the Mercury was delivered at about 10.30 a.m. on the day of publication, which was most satisfactory. However, the position has deteriorated again and the newspaper is now being delivered to my office the day after publication. In fact, I received yesterday's Mercury just before entering the chamber this morning. I wonder whether we could have your intervention again to make sure that delivery is as it should be.
—I shall be happy to take up this matter again with a view to having newspapers from all States delivered promptly, as I have sought to do over the years. I shall go into the matter immediately.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Telecom Australia intends to introduce a fee of $10 for subscribers with silent numbers; that is, numbers not listed in telephone directories. Will the Minister intervene in this proposal especially on behalf of people such as members of the police force, women living alone, the legal profession, and others who may be victims of nuisance calls and who now will be punished by Telecom as well? Would it not be possible to publish in the directories the name of the subscriber, with the world 'unlisted' instead of the telephone number for persons wishing to retain a private number? Surely this scheme would save the telephone operators valuable searching time.

—It will be necessary to refer this question to the Minister I represent to obtain specific information for the honourable senator. I am attracted by his concern for those who are the victims of nuisance calls, and I will make sure that the Minister is made aware of the listing proposal he has put to the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In view of recent statements by the Tasmanian Minister for Main Roads that work done by tender would mean 'a substantial cutback in the permanent work force with a resultant loss of jobs and skills for Tasmania', can the Minister State whether this would be so in view of the logic that if tender prices were lower, more work, not less, would result and more jobs would be created?

—I am aware that the Tasmanian Minister has recently made a number of public statements criticising the Commonwealth Government's intention to require all construction works on national roads to be subject to the tender and contract process. However, that gentleman failed to mention that the Commonwealth is proposing to require that construction works on national roads only be subject to the tender process. The Commonwealth would not require that the tender process be applied to arterial and local roads, which are by far the bulk of the roads in Tasmania. On those roads, the Tasmanian Government will continue to be free to use its normal day labour force. However, in the interests of efficient use of public resources, it would be wise to try the tender and contract system. The Commonwealth is insisting on the calling of tenders for the few construction jobs on national roads in the belief that this will lead to better value for money and so result in more, not less, work being done.
—That used to be called centralism. What is it called now?

—The Minister for Transport stated that State road authorities will be free to tender in open competition with private contractors for all works on national roads. If the Tasmanian Main Roads Department is an efficient organisation, there is no reason why it should not win a significant number of those tenders offered. This is particularly so when it is recalled that the Tasmanian Main Roads Department is established throughout Tasmania and that no large private road construction contractors are presently established in Tasmania. Senator Walsh might acknowledge that in those circumstances the Commonwealth Government is making a positive contribution to the States, particularly Tasmania, by inviting them to take part in national projects.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that in 1976 the salaries of Family Court judges were the same as those paid to their counterparts on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? As a result of determinations made by the Remuneration Tribunal, Family Court judges' salaries have now been substantially downgraded in terms of relativity. In view of undertakings given to Family Court judges about their status, did this happen by accident and, if so, what steps have been taken to rectify the situation? On the other hand, if it happened as a result of policy, will the Minister outline the policy and its justification?

—Broadly, the points raised by Senator Button can be accepted although he used the word 'downgraded'. Following determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal, the salary levels of Family Court judges have fallen below the relative levels at which they were fixed by the original Family Law Act. In 1976 an amendment was made to that Act which maintained the relativity at that time. However, the Government's policy since it has been in office is that judicial salaries should be determined on recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal. It has been as a result of a series of decisions of that Tribunal over the years that the present situation has developed. I have had a number of representations from Family Court judges in relation to this matter. Representations were again made as recently as this Monday. I am now giving consideration to what steps should be taken in this year's review of judicial salaries by the Remuneration Tribunal. Of course, it is a matter that will have to be determined by the Government and I am not in a position to say what steps will or can be taken.
—I claim to have been misrepresented and seek the indulgence of the Senate to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—On page 544 of yesterday's Hansard of 11 March, which has just been circulated, I am recorded in two division lists as having been present and voting with Government senators. In fact, I did not participate in the votes in question and was absent from the chamber at the time. Although the votes in question were on Standing Orders matters on which honourable senators on both sides of the chamber traditionally have a free vote-accordingly, the guilt by association implied in that record is less heinous than it might otherwise have been-nonetheless, I cannot help but regard it as a serious error, especially in a preselection year. I should like to have the record corrected. I would appreciate also being advised in due course by Senator Kilgariff, who was the teller for the ayes, and the Clerk at the table at the time, how the error came about. I understand the Hansard error was in fact a product of an original error in the official division lists. I hope it was not because I was heard to utter at one point in last night's rather unbelievable proceedings 'Come back, Jim Odgers; all is forgiven'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: — Two questions were asked on matters relating to foreign affairs and I am now able to give some information on them. One matter was with regard to the establishment of a diplomatic post in Bali. The Minister for Foreign Affairs reviews annually the needs for diplomatic representation overseas and the Department puts to the Minister the consideration of individual proposals for the opening of new posts or the closure of existing ones. When planning for the establishment of new posts is undertaken the Government's policies on containing growth in the public sector are borne fully in mind and posts are opened only in response to pressing needs where substantial Australian interests can best be protected and developed by the presence on the ground of a resident mission.

INTERJECT.PARA: With regard to Bali and the requirement that the opening of a new diplomatic mission be assessed against the availability of staff and funds and against competing priorities elsewhere, it has not been possible to open a mission in Bali. However, because of the consular pressures arising from the increasing numbers of Australians visiting Bali and the shortcomings inherent in trying to provide a satisfactory level of consular assistance from Jakarta, the Government is currently giving further consideration to the early opening of a consulate in Bali.
Senator Robertson-It was two years ago. There has been no change in two years.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is recognised that the arrangements have difficulties and shortcomings, and the matter is under consideration at present.

— Senator Sibraa referred to famine relief in East Africa. I am advised that the severe drought, civil disruption, warfare and the movement of large numbers of refugees to normally food deficient countries all have contributed to the food crisis in East Africa. In response, a significant part of our food aid is being diverted to the region. Five countries-Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda and Kenya-will receive almost 70,000 tonnes of food grain valued, with freight, at over $15m from Australia during this financial year. In order to overcome the problems of communication and distribution, Australia has associated its assistance with the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees, the United Nations World Food Program and other United Nations bodies active in the area. Reports both from the WFP and our own representatives show that Australian aid is reaching its intended recipients. Advice received in January from the United Nations agencies indicates a general improvement in the condition of refugees, owing to increased feeding, health care and water supply programs. However, a three-month water supply emergency was declared in Somalia on 5 February because of drought. Australia will be represented at the Africa Refugees Assistance Conference to be held in Geneva in April. I think there may be some other matters which were raised by Senator Sibraa, but I will seek information on them for him.

—I wish to make a personal explanation about the personal explanation of Senator Evans, who said that the records of two divisions yesterday were incorrect. I support that. There was no error on the part of the Clerks; the mistake came from my quarter. I have discussed the matter with the Chairman of Committees, Senator Maunsell. I mistakenly called Senator Evans for Senator Mason when I was taking the count. I apologise.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to administer the airlines system in the interests of the travelling public.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by Sessional Order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance I have raised this morning is a matter that perhaps the Government hopes will go away. It is a subject which thousands of Australians will want to see thrashed out in this Parliament so that finally order may be brought to one of the key factors of our economy-the domestic aviation industry. This industry has been the envy of other members of the business community for many years. With government approval a private corporation, Ansett Airlines of Australia, and a public corporation, Trans-Australia Airlines, are protected from competition. They operate in a closed world where their customers, the travelling public, have no say. It is a world where they are able, under the present Government, largely to decide their own level of profit by regularly seeking and automatically receiving permission to increase air fares. The public is not told how these increases are justified. Still less is the public given the opportunity to question the basis on which the increases are granted.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that honourable senators should go back some years to review the way this cosy cost arrangement developed and to weigh some of the very strong criticisms levelled at it. Rather than go back to the inception of the two airlines agreement in the 1950s, let us go back to just two years ago. I refer the Senate to the substantial inquiry of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review published in 1979 as a report to the then Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon. This report is a sort of John the Baptist volume for the report of the Holcroft inquiry into domestic air fares published a week or so ago. I do not seek to attribute any particular virtues to the Holcroft committee of inquiry by describing the former volume as a John the Baptist one. However, it preceded the Holcroft inquiry by several years. It was an expert study-at least it seemed so at that time-of the domestic aviation industry carried out by the Department of Transport.

I would like to draw from the report of the review one comment of great significance to any debate on the two-airline agreement. The review took up the matter of Ansett's involvement in non-airline activities-in other words, Ansett's interest in finance companies and in other investments not related, even indirectly, to aviation. Some of Ansett's subsidiary companies may be said to be indirectly related to air travel, such as the Great Barrier Reef tourist resorts and things of that kind. On page 76 of volume 1 of the report the review committee said that it did not have sufficient information as to whether Ansett's involvement in non-airline activities acted to the detriment of passengers or freight rates or, significantly, whether those activities affected the two-airline agreement; that is, whether they affected Ansett and TAA. The committee also reminded the Minister that he should satisfy himself that the 'airline industry considerations only' should be taken into account in setting fares and freight rates and in deciding matters such as fleet re-equipment. Three and a half years later has the Minister satisfied himself about those considerations? There has been no indication to this Parliament that he has. The matter is still open for debate.

Talk about Ansett's involvement in non-airline activities became highly relevant with the crash of Associated Securities Ltd in 1979, the year of the commissioning of this report. That company was controlled by Ansett. On its board sat Sir Reginald Ansett, Sir Cecil Looker and Sir Henry Bolte-all members of the Ansett Transport Industries board, all having had bestowed on them knighthoods of ancient orders of chivalry and honour and all of them having had bestowed on them knighthoods which, it is said, can be relatively cheaply obtained in Victoria these days by donations to Liberal Party funds. Associated Securities Ltd was engaged in highly speculative activities which led to losses which have never been accurately quantified. Estimates of those losses range from $18m to $27m and, of course, they were losses which involved many small investors. That incident emphasised just how much Ansett has had the best of both worlds. Not only is it protected by government guarantee but also and at the same time it is free to pursue the most doubtful commercial enterprises and the most speculative of business activities. That sort of activity can be pursued although it bears no relation to the airline industry. It can obviously be sustained, however, by using the enormous cash flow that Ansett gets from its privileged position.

We will never know to what extent, if at all, air fares were affected by the collapse of ASL. The underwriting of the hairier schemes by the use of airline funds holds great potential dangers. I am reminded that Mr Rupert Murdoch, when he was contemplating buying a newspaper in England, said that one of his rivals owned a shipping company. He said it was highly inappropriate in England for the proprietors of a shipping company to own a newspaper. How does he apply that sort of criteria in the Australian context? Associated Securities Ltd is one illustration of what can happen.

How much longer must we wait for this Government to develop any backbone to do anything about it? That lack of resolve by the Government is at the forefront of the most recent upheaval in this industry-the establishment and brutal termination of the Holcroft inquiry. What principles have been transgressed by the way in which this Minister and this Government have treated the members of the Holcroft inquiry? The members of that inquiry were highly respected men-the chief executive of Brambles Industries Ltd-one of the largest Australian companies in Australia; Dr Harold Bell, who for many years has been a senior executive of the AMP Society; and Professor Warren Hogan, Professor of Economics at Sydney University. Businessmen and academics of the distinction of those three men are not always anxious to serve on government committees of inquiry because the demands on their time are too severe.

To accept such a commission inevitably means a sacrifice. They felt that the importance of fare structures in the domestic airlines system of Australia was so important that they were prepared to make that sacrifice of their services as a gesture of public goodwill to grapple with a most important issue for the Australian public. They were prepared to serve on that committee. There is no doubt that they were assured that the inquiry would continue until they were satisfied that they had heard all the relevant evidence and were in a position to make decisions about an industry that has been allowed to become so complex and secretive in its marketing and administrative structure. But what happened? As their hearings proceeded, last September the members of the committee were to get the first inkling of moves affecting their inquiry that were taking place behind their backs. I wish to quote from their letter to the Minister for Transport dated 15 February. It is the letter in which they submitted their report to the Government. It began with the committee members saying that they submitted the report with considerable misgivings. Then they had this to say:

It is also appropriate to record that the Members of the Inquiry felt in some degree misplaced when learning on 9 September that they had been proceeding with an inquiry requiring them to have regard, inter alia, to 'government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition' in ignorance of the fact that the Government was meanwhile negotiating a new ten-year Two Airlines Agreement. That such an agreement had in fact been signed was first made known to the Inquiry by Ansett, which asserted that in its view some lines of inquiry being pursued by us would be irrelevant in the environment of the new Agreement once ratified by Parliament.

The committee should have been alerted by that action of the Government and it should have been alerted much earlier on by the Minister for Transport. It perhaps should have realised that its inquiry was regarded by this Government as a stunt. The inquiry had been established prior to the last election only because dissatisfaction about the cost of air fares in Australia was becoming enormous and widespread. So, to head off criticism, the Government set up this inquiry. It is now clear that the Government never intended to take the inquiry seriously.

As soon as possible after the election on 18 October last year the Government's attitude was exposed for all to see. On 13 November the three committee members met the Minister and he gave them no inkling that the inquiry was to be wound up. Instead, he gave the clear impression that the funds needed to extend the inquiry to mid-1981-a simple machinery matter-would be made available without difficulty. Two things then occurred to change all that. I have already indicated the contempt of the Minister for the Holcroft inquiry by his opening of negotiations with the airlines for a new two-airline agreement. A second event then influenced him to act even sooner than he had planned; that is, the fact that Western Australian members of this Parliament had been putting the heat on the Prime Minister about the level of air fares between Western Australia and the eastern States. I note with interest the fact that not one Western Australian Government senator will be participating in this debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are to have two Queenslanders participating. We are vitally affected in this matter, as are Western Australians.
—They would disagree with you about that, Senator. Have that argument in your party room.
—If you spoke to the substance of the motion we could get on with the debate.

—I would be assisted if you would shut up for a while. Then we could get on with the debate. After a meeting between these members of parliament, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Transport, the members of the Holcroft inquiry were abruptly told on 26 November that they were to complete their findings by 31 January. The reason given by the Minister was that Parliament would know the recommendations of the inquiry before it ratified the new two-airline agreement which he was drawing up. In a Press statement announcing this Mr Hunt had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has asked the Chairman of the domestic air fares inquiry, Mr Holcroft, to conclude his report by 31 January next year so that the Government and the Parliament will have the benefit of the recommendations of this inquiry before proceeding to enact legislation to give effect to a new two airlines agreement . . .

The cynicism in that announcement is almost beyond belief. The Minister's overriding interest was to get the Parliament to ratify the new two-airline agreement. It was an agreement dictated by Ansett and meekly agreed to by the Minister. He knew that he would not get ratification without a public brawl with Western Australian members of this Parliament. The compromise was that they were given the promise that they would be able to weigh the Holcroft recommendations before they were asked to ratify the new two-airline agreement. The Minister's central concern was and is the ratification of this new two-airline agreement for a period of 10 years in spite of all the doubts which exist in this community about the validity of that agreement in the interests of the travelling public. Holcroft and his colleagues were to be sent packing. They were simply holding up conclusion of the deal that Ansett was demanding. They were of no moment.

A number of things flow from that. First of all, there has been an attempt by the Minister to deceive the Parliament and there has been vilification of the members of the Holcroft committee because they dared to question the behaviour of a Minister and, by implication, the Government. Snide attacks have been made on the truthfulness and competence of members of the committee of inquiry. It has been one of the most degrading incidents in the public life of this country in many years. Of course, it is also a degrading incident which ignores the whole substance of the problem, which is the level of domestic air fares in this country. The ending of this inquiry enabled Ansett, TAA and the Department of Transport-surely the three most important elements of this industry-to evade close examination. That is almost like running a Melbourne Cup without horses or having a Country Party national conference not passing a resolution about hanging or something of that kind.

The committee made some comments about the Department's conduct in this matter which I do not wish to quote in detail. They are very familiar, I would think, to honourable senators. If I can summarise, from memory the committee found it passing strange that the Department of Transport was not in a position to give evidence to the committee at an appropriate time. In recent days we have been given information which reveals aspects both of TAA and Ansett that should not be countenanced. I refer to the reports of those two companies which have been tabled in the Parliament. Senator Rae has concentrated on some of the shortcomings of TAA and I follow and agree with many of the arguments which Senator Rae has put about the accounts of that airline. I have in this place identified some aspects of the Ansett operations that I believe fall far short of the standards that should apply to an enterprise operating with Government guarantees about competition and, effectively, Government guarantees about profitability. Sometimes Government members think that we on this side have some sort of obsession about Mr Rupert Murdoch, for example. I assure honourable senators that I have no obsession about him. I have never met him. I understand that he is an outstanding father. I simply make the comment that it is our obligation as an Opposition, whether or not Mr Murdoch be associated with Ansett Airlines, to scrutinise the actions of that airline as it is our obligation to scrutinise the actions of TAA. That is especially so when reports appear in the newspapers like the one in yesterday's Sydney Sun. It stated:
A SECRET letter reveals that Ansett Airlines, through Mr Rupert Murdoch, urged the Federal Government last year to sell TAA to private interests.
The letter, signed by the Federal Transport Minister, Mr Hunt, was sent to Ansett's joint managing director, Sir Peter Abeles.

Ansett also urged the Government-through Mr Murdoch-to introduce automatic fare rises for both the domestic airlines, a move which the minister said would have the effect of keeping up Ansett's profits.
Not to put too fine a point on it, if I might interpolate. The letter continued:
Both proposals were put in talks between Transport Australia officials and Ansett representatives in negotiations on a new two-airline agreement.
Mr Hunt's letter said the talks had followed a meeting between himself and publisher Mr Murdoch, who is the other joint managing director of Ansett.

As far as I can detect, that report has not been denied. Its implications are clear. Mr Murdoch was dictating to this Government future policy about aviation. While the Minister in his letter appears to be rejecting the move and the more monstrous suggestions contained in it, it now appears that he is in fact in agreement after all with a number of those suggestions. It is little short of breathtaking that a private company so shielded from competition by the government can not only evade public accountability but also can have such a commanding influence over matters of policy. The championing by Ansett of its role as one of free enterprise is, in that circumstance, quite ludicrous. It all comes back, of course, to what we were told in that speech of the Prime Minister on 5 December in which he identified the necessity for choice and options in Australian society-choice and options; diversity under the Fraser Government. What sort of choice, what sorts of options and what sort of diversity do we have when a newspaper proprietor, on behalf of his airline, can nobble the Minister in the way the Minister for Transport in this country has been nobbled in the past few months? Ansett occupies a position that is the envy of other companies in Australia yet it displays no sense of obligation to the public which fills its coffers by the payment of higher and higher air fares.

We have heard a good deal recently about air fares between Sydney, Melbourne and Perth. Back benchers on the Government side have been expressing concern about that. But their concern, of course, is a little belated, although welcome. One wonders why they have not taken up with the Government the question of empty seats on Qantas planes flying across the continent-2,000 empty seats a week on Qantas jumbo jets which could be occupied by passengers on domestic routes. That has been established, I think, as a matter of practicality. That would mean capital savings--

TALK.START.PARA: —And fuel savings.

—And fuel savings, of course, for the airlines concerned. What has been the reaction of the Government? Its reaction has been to defer again to the domestic airlines. I ask honourable senators to bear in mind that Qantas Airways Ltd offered the two airlines rights to sell its seats at whatever markup TAA and Ansett chose. That offer, of course, was not taken up; it was rejected out of hand. One can only think that TAA and Ansett refused to reduce their aeroplane fleet and cut down direct involvement in that route for reasons of prestige. While they covered their prestige the Australian air travellers and taxpayers had to foot the bill. Surely it is time that the Government began to exercise some influence in this situation and demonstrated that it has both the will and the determination to do what is best for Australians and not what is best for Ansett and TAA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat here and listened to Senator Button's speech in an attempt to gather the drift of his argument in this matter of public importance. As I read it, it is concerned with the interests of the travelling public. I find that it is extremely difficult to establish what, in fact, he is criticising. Indeed, he has been talking about various matters which are sideline matters and are on the periphery of the issues concerning Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia without coming to the major point which is: To what extent has the Australian citizen been hurt or had his interests damaged in respect of the two-airline agreement? Further, are there any arrangements which have detrimentally affected him? These matters have not been established. In fact, Senator Button's speech has been based on an attack, again on Ansett, which has been typical of his activities in the last few day.
—And personalities within Ansett.

—His leading attacks have been on personalities. I mention in passing the Sun newspaper article which appeared yesterday and was referred to in a question which was asked by Senator Walsh and which was raised again by Senator Button in his speech. That question claimed that Mr Murdoch, out of the blue or in some surreptitious way which has become known to the Press, advocated to the Government the sale of TAA. What an astounding proposition that is. After all that had been spread over the newspapers about a year ago as a matter of some importance. There were, of course, subsequent denials by the Government on many occasions of an intention to sell TAA. Senator Button is, of course, digging as deep as he can to find a relevant red herring to confuse these issues without any basis whatsoever.
—No one is complaining about the digging on your side.

—Senator Sibraa clearly does not understand the matter at hand. Senator Button commented during the debate on Tuesday night in respect of the presentation of the report from Ansett Transport Industries that the financial statements of the airline's operations showed a profit greater than that which was, in fact, disclosed in that report. Yet, he now comes into this place and asks: To what extent have those profits been affected and therefore prices jacked up to the community because of the effect of the Associated Securities Ltd crash. Clearly he has not his thinking straight. If he accepts that there is a financial statement which sets out the profit and loss associated with the airline's operations he then goes on to say: 'They are affected in some way by ASL's particular problems'.
—No, I said that your Government's committee said that, not me.

—Senator Button is the one who is drawing the conclusions and seeking to make the points. Indeed, there is complete confusion in the minds of members of the Opposition in respect of those matters. There are a number of other matters which, I think, deserve attention. But there is probably no more important matter before we come to the case that I want to make in respect of this matter than the Australian Labor Party's policy in respect of the airlines' arrangements. What is its policy? First of all, I refer to the 'Platform, Constitution and Rules' of the Australian Labor Party which, of course, is that Party's bible.
—Are you bringing religion into it now?

—It is Senator Gietzelt's religion. Perhaps he has one or two others, as well, some of them perhaps authored by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.
