Mr Acting Deputy President, I guess you know the Australian Labor Party's platform well. At page 157 of that document under the heading 'Transport' and the sub-heading 'Organisation, Funding and Charges' it states that it is the intention, obviously, to:

SPEECH.PARA: Establish an Interstate Commission, as set out under Sections 101-104 of the Constitution, to co-ordinate interstate transport including rail, road, air, water, and pipelines as provided by the Constitution or transferred to it by a State.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—Clearly what is involved here is that an Australian Labor Party government would seek to implement that platform in such a way that it gains absolute control over the airline industry as it would seek to do by the establishment of an interstate commission in respect of rail and water transport and every other kind of transport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party stands up here today and claims that, in the interests of the air travelling public, it wants competition. At the same time it is trying to implement a policy which is aimed at destroying the airline industry with the intention of establishing one airline only which can then be totally controlled through its means. That is its objective. Hence, we have this outpouring of criticism against Ansett Airlines and against the personalities connected with Ansett Airlines so as to establish a one-airline policy in this country in such a way as to obtain absolute control of the transport system consistent with its general socialistic objectives. This hypocritical party is about to argue, as Senator Button has failed to do, that there is real interest in the travelling public. Mr Morris, the spokesman on transport in the other place, stood up there and claimed that competition is the best way to assist the travelling public. He was talking about competition in respect of pricing. He knows that if the Labor Party came to office-heaven forbid-there would be no possibility of implementing that proposal because he is bound by the Australian Labor Party platform which states quite clearly that the objective of an Australian Labor Party government would be to set up a monopoly air transport arrangement so that there could be no competition. In addition, there would also be the effects which would need to be taken into account in respect of other transport arrangements. We have already seen how socialist governments in the States regulate road and rail transport in such a way as to ensure that the maximum profits are earned for State-owned enterprises. That is a basic objective of the Opposition Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound more like Senator Carrick every day.

—Of course, the truth does hurt, Senator Primmer. I can understand his sensitivities knowing his predilections on certain left wing matters. I wish now to come to the matters which I believe are important in this debate in an attempt to demonstrate to the public that the two airlines arrangement does work in favour of the public generally. Clearly there have been, through the implementation of this arrangement over a long period, considerable very important safety records. There have been reliable and frequent services through the Australian network. Okay, in some cases it may not have served every location in the way it should have, but on the whole it has been done in such a way that it is for the benefit of the Australian public. The range of fare types which is now allowed is considerable. Of course, the rise in the usage of aircraft by tourists and others, particularly in the last few years and since the advent of the jet aircraft, has been astounding and absolutely amazing. This has led to the opening up of new job opportunities in the tourist areas, particularly those in Queensland. This element, of course, could not have come about except through the competition which has been allowed under the previous airlines arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us not dwell on that matter. Let us look at what the proposed new airline arrangements will take into account. A wide range of fare types are already applicable. They include economy, standby, offpeak, group, advanced purchase and night coach and special concessions for children and students. These fares offer a wider range than any that might be made available under other arrangements overseas. For children alone Australian fares are 50 per cent more generous than those available in other countries. Of course, in the general commercial area there is also the 40 per cent off normal arrangements.

If we care to compare prices with other countries-this is surely the real test as to whether the public is being properly served by the airline arrangements-we find that, for instance, in the United States the economy fare between New York and Los Angeles is equivalent to 8.9c per kilometre, compared with the fare of 8.5c per kilometre applicable between Perth and Melbourne. Does that indicate a significant difference against-not favourably inclined towards-the travelling public in Australia? Of course not. The reverse is true. In fact, it is cheaper to travel from Perth to Melbourne than it is to travel an equivalent distance in the United States. Is that a disadvantage to the public? Of course not.

The current situation has been arrived at after extensive reviews and these have been spelt out in logical pattern over the last three years. Of course, preparatory to the new airlines arrangements was the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee, which was established in 1977, which undertook studies and which reported a couple of years ago. As we all know, those findings have been laid open to the public and have received remarkable public comment since they were first made available. Of course, there has been the more recent decision to establish the new airlines arrangement. It followed that policy review, but the aim over the last year or so was to have very serious negotiations with the various airlines to ensure that as many points of view as possible were taken into account and, of course, to establish a new basis for competition within a general framework that kept up the standard of airline service to the community which had been established in previous times. Owing to community concern, that was followed by the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares.

Those two aims have not been inconsistent. The Government made it clear when dealing with the establishment of the Holcroft inquiry that it would appreciate the views of the Holcrost inquiry in respect of air fares and matters of cross-subsidisation in considering the arrangements it would need to come to in the ratification of the airlines agreement. That was a thoroughly consistent approach. Those matters have led to the development of a new policy which will bring even better benefits to the airline travelling public. Quite apart from spelling out those matters, I believe there is one other very significant point to be made about the development of the present airlines arrangement and the way in which it has been occurring.

Firstly, I think we need to acknowledge that the whole airline industry, not only in Australia but also overseas, is about to face a very significant period of structural change and development. We know, for instance, that within the next few years we will be seeing in this country the implementation of wide-bodied aircraft which will be able to fly longer, go further and carry more passengers across Australia than ever before. It will herald a whole new marketing opportunity for the airlines. The commitment of hundreds of millions of dollars by both airlines on new aircraft and spares, ground staff and new arrangements, which will involve government in extra expense on airport development and so on, will certainly represent a major change in the way in which government has to handle aviation policy.

The point I make is whether this is the time to adopt the approach of the shadow Minister for Transport of throwing the whole matter to the winds and declaring an open-go policy-a dog eat dog and may the best man win situation. Such a policy may well achieve the socialist objective of the Australian Labor Party but in the meantime it would thoroughly destroy the golden opportunity we have in this country to establish a new aviation industry which would provide greater benefits for the travelling public and create new jobs in those tourist areas all over Australia at lower costs than would otherwise apply. I believe that therein lies the real interest of the travelling public, not for today, not for 20 years ago and not for last year, but for the future. This Government is concerned about that, whereas the Opposition and its leaders are apparently deadly concerned about achieving their socialist objectives as set out in their platform.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is utter rot and you know it.

—That is Senator Primmer's consistent view. It is well known that he is a great supporter of the ALP platform and of other more radical statements. Many different matters are relevant to this debate. (Quorum formed). I do not have the time to develop certain other matters now owing to the Opposition's tactics in stripping me of my opportunity. Obviously members of the Opposition are feeling the arguments very deeply.
—Neither the time nor the ability or anything else.

—They need to confuse the issues to an extent even greater than Senator Button has done. In relation to Qantas Airways Ltd, Senator Button spoke of some 2,000 aircraft seats being available on flights between Perth and Sydney. He pointed out that these seats could be utilised in a practical way so as to reduce the cost to Western Australians. However, he would recognise, after one or two moment's consideration, that such arrangements are based on flights coming to Australia from overseas and the seats on these flights would be extremely difficult to fill with domestic passengers when one considers the inconsistent timing, the arrangements at airports to handle people who pass through Customs and the need to mix up those matters.
—Is that why you are doing nothing about it?

—I am addressing myself to the problems which the honourable senator has said are very real, but he apparently has not given us any practical solutions to those matters. One other matter concerns the new accountability standards which are set down in the new arrangements. I believe those to be important. Indeed, Senator Button must agree with those new arrangements as he spoke at great length on them during the debate last Tuesday night. I conclude by making it clear that in bringing this matter forward the Australian Labor Party has only one objective; that is, to establish a socialised control of air transport and not to improve competitive advantages to the Australian public as between the two airlines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least the Senate is discussing the problems associated with and faced by the airline industry in Australia. That approach is very different to the approach taken in the House of Representatives when these matters were sought to be ventilated by the Opposition. The Fraser Government gagged the debate. Having heard the arguments of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) one can perhaps understand why the Government might have taken that position.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner spoke for his allotted time and said precisely nothing except he tried to suggest that the Labor Party's platform, which deals with a section of the Constitution which was written in 1900, and which deals with the problems of the transport industry by establishing an interstate commission, in some imprecise and unusual sort of way, would advance the objectives of the Australian Labor Party. When the Constitution was written at that stage I doubt whether the word 'socialism' had even crept into the thinking of the Australian people. At that stage it was nothing more than a flightful fantasy in the minds of the Australian people, least of all the Australian Labor Party. Of course, it is usual for Senator Messner, having no argument to fall back upon, to smear and slander in an attempt to defend the Government's infamous position on this and other issues. After all, it was this Government which in May 1980 set up an inquiry into domestic air fares. By its own admission it was dissatisfied with the state of the industry. That was expressed particularly by Western Australian members.

What was the purpose of the inquiry? Senator Messner never applied himself to the terms of reference. The inquiry was to be independent and public and its members were to apply themselves to the criticisms that had been advanced by the Opposition. The first meeting between the committee and the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) took place in June 1980. Following that meeting the terms of reference were extended in September 1980. However, the committee from the first moment suffered frustration in the preparation of its work because of the attitude taken by some members of the Government.

Public hearings began in September 1980 and continued right through November 1980. In that period the committee met again with the Minister. On 27 November last the Minister wrote to the committee informing it that the inquiry should report within two months. It was only at that stage that members of the committee realised what a sham they were involved in and to what extent the Minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government had been contriving to seduce the electorate. Let us look at Tasmania and Western Australia where, according to public opinion polls, the Government was vulnerable and where, on the eve of the 18 October elections, it was pretty clear that the whole arrangement was a coverup for blatant political purposes. The committee was made an instrument for the Government's motivation. Surreptitiously the Government's purpose for the committee was to complete the two-airline agreement which would see Ansett Transport Industries smoothly and profitably into the next decade.

I remind the Senate that on the eve of the 1972 elections, when the dogs were barking and the McMahon Government was about to fall, the Government, at that time, concluded the airline agreement without consultation with the Parliament and without having regard to the fact that we would have a new government in office. What has been the committee's response to this? The bitterness of the committee's realisation can be seen in its letters addressed to the Minister. The first letter is dated 1 December 1980. It states:
It is the considered opinion of the Members of this Committee that to ask it to finalise, within the two most interrupted months of the year,-
That is December and January-

a report based on a grossly incomplete input of material from the many parties is totally unreasonable. Moreover, we believe that the impracticability makes a travesty of the description of the Committee as being independent and public.

The committee was already making suggestions of improper and impossible conditions imposed upon it by the Government. One has only to look at the recommendation in the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares in paragraphs 1.12, 1.13 and 1.14. Paragraph 1.12 reads:
There was for a considerable period a reluctance on the part of Ansett to cooperate with the Inquiry in a fashion that could be of practical use.

The written submission of the Department of Transport, belated as it was, and the lack of a written submission by the Bureau of Transport Economics made the work of the committee impossible. I return now to the letter from the committee. It continues:
We will, however, in the interests of protecting our own reputations and those of our staff, necessarily have to impose the most stringent of qualifications on the findings in our Report.

It is ironical, is it not, that the committee was subsequently able to make the report that it did. Subsequent to that, the committee heard the most shameful attack on its integrity from its Minister and from the former Minister. It is surely the last refuge of a tottering Minister to try to put the blame on his staff or on a committee that he appointed.

It is necessary for me to remind honourable senators of the standing of those members of the committee whom the Minister sought to portray as either incompetent or malevolent upstarts. Mr Warwick Holcroft, who is now retired, was the Managing Director of Brambles Industries Ltd; Dr Harold Bell, O.B.E., was the Economic Adviser to the Australian Mutual Provident Society and, of course, Professor Warren Hogan is a distinguished academic and sometime adviser to the Government on economic matters. These men can hardly be said to hold a brief for the Opposition. Yet their integrity and professionalism was such that they could not allow themselves to be compromised by the cynical machinations of the Minister, despite their own obvious and sympathetic political persuasions. So it was that on 27 November last the penny dropped for the members of the committee. The offhanded treatment members of the committee received from the Department of Transport-obviously at the direction of the Minister and the Government-the disdainful submission from Ansett Airlines of Australia and the total brush-off from the Bureau of Transport Economics, all fell into place.

The facts of the matter were very clear. The election was over. The support of the Murdoch Press was secure. The new two-airline agreement had been signed and was ready for presentation to the Parliament before the Senate could cause any trouble, which will be a factor as from 1 July next. The committee was a liability to be disposed of and that was the action that was taken by the Fraser Government. This then is the atmosphere and the attitude which pervades the Government's administration of the airline system in Australia. It is geared to purely political ends to ensure that the powerful friends of the Liberal Party are kept in the power to which they have been so dangerously accustomed. Whereas it was Ansett in 1972, it is now Murdoch and Abeles who have assumed the power in that empire in that organisation, to ensure that the Liberal Party is the beneficiary of that power and to perpetuate the coalition Government on the basis of that power.

Of course there is a conflict here. It is certainly not in the interests of the Australian public, least of all those in the far flung parts of our country in Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Queensland or Tasmania, or similarly in the cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. The Minister has admitted as such, with reference to the Western Australian position, in his circular of 3 February 1981 to Government members. He admits that the price on long haul routes is unreasonably high. Yet Senator Messner has the gall to stand up in this place and defend that situation when there are alternatives readily available as is shown in the Holcroft report. The Government's orchestrated reaction to the impending Holcroft recommendations appears to suggest that it had every intention of maintaining those fares for long haul routes at some reasonably high level. Let me quote from the report. It states:
Almost everywhere the Inquiry has attempted to do this-
That is, frame practical recommendations on air fare pricing-
it has run into the virtually impenetrable barrier of the provisions of the Two Airlines Agreement, existing or proposed.

The committee's report reserves as much criticism for the Department of Transport operating at the direction of Government policy, for its failure to elicit adequate public disclosure of financial and performance data by the airlines. We saw this view substantiated only this week with the tabling of the reports to which Senator Button so ably referred on Tuesday evening. They are the subject of the dissatisfaction of not only Opposition senators but also of Government senators. Can we expect this Government to take heed of the committee's 'disquiet'-'disquiet' is the committee's word, not mine-and bring about changes in the two-airine agreement which would require full and timely public disclosure of the activities of the participants in this protected industry?

A covert operation, resulting in the signing of a new airline agreement, is being foisted on the Australian public without public debate and in defiance of the Holcroft inquiry. It will result in Ansett Airlines being secure for 10 years in its ripping off of sections of the Australian community. Let me instance one point in relation to the inquiry. Before doing so, I ask: Are Government senators really sincere in their belief that there is no disquiet in the Australian community, that there is no dissatisfaction with the fare structure, the parallel timetables or the lack of competition in the airline industry? Of course, there is such disquiet and dissatisfaction. The question of using excess capacity on Qantas Airways Ltd flights for long haul routes has been raised often enough. This would mean lower fares for people flying to and from Western Australia. However, under the proposed new agreement, Ansett will be able to prevent the use of that excess capacity on Qantas aircraft. The Minister glibly defends the proposal. This committee, which had the express task of looking at air fares and particularly at the problem on the long haul routes, was unable to consider this apparently straightforward manoeuvre. No wonder the Government is faced with a rebellion from its Western Australian supporters. The cat is out of the bag and well and truly running.

Where are the greater competition and the lower fares which the Government professes to seek? The answer is that they are impossibly locked into the Liberal Party-Murdoch-Abeles-Ansett treasure chest. No Holcroft inquiry will be allowed to unlock that mutually beneficial gold mine which satisfies not only the big corporations but also the funds of the Liberal and National Country parties in this country at election times. The Holcroft committee, despite the hurdles placed before it by the Government, has done the Parliament and the travelling public a great service. It has exposed the pretence carried on by the Minister for Transport, it has revealed the excessive profits being made by Ansett at the air travellers' expense and it has highlighted to all Australians the complicity between the men who control Ansett and this Government.

Honourable senators will recall that during the last parliamentary session the Minister introduced the Australian National Airlines Commission Amendment Bill. It was a phony Bill. That Bill embodied the requests made in January last year by none other than Sir Peter Abeles to the Minister that the financial structure of Trans-Australia Airlines be changed and its profit objectives altered. The major beneficiary of the extra profit that would flow from such an alteration to the airline's structural arrangement would be Ansett Airlines. Increased profits can only be provided by increased fares. Fares have doubled in recent years, slugging the airline passengers from one part of the country to the other. Under that agreement the two airlines must charge the same fares. Where is the competition about which Senator Messner spoke so glibly in his contribution to the debate? When TAA's fares are forced up by this current manoeuvre, Ansett could follow suit.

The real purpose of the amendment to the TAA legislation, as the Opposition said last year, would be to benefit Ansett Airlines, its shareholders and the power group that controls that organisation. Ansett is already making excessive profits, as the Holcroft committee discovered and exposed. Here is the ultimate hypocrisy of this so-called free enterprise Government. When it is a matter of protecting the interests of those sinister corporate powers which help keep it in government, it is prepared to exercise any amount of crude manipulation and administrative or legislative regulation to gain its ends. So much for the Government's pretence about market forces, about competition and about being concerned about the interests of the travelling public. They mean nothing to this Government when it wants to satisfy the influences and the financial interests of those who put their money into the Liberal and National Country Party money bags every time there is an election in this country. That, of course, is one of the influences that the Opposition is interested in changing. We will continue to challenge this Government and the policies that flow from such undue influence of corporations on the decisions of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -What I thought would be a wide-ranging objective debate on air transport and the interests of the Australian public has turned out to be basically a diatribe against the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and one of the commercial operators in the domestic air transport scene in Australia. There has also been a diatribe against departments and their officers. One reason for this is the fact that the Department of Transport did not provide evidence to the Holcroft inquiry, the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. I think the Department of Transport would concede the fact that it was very late with its submission but I think it must also be known that all through the inquiry it co-operated with and provided information to the Holcroft committee. A similar situation applies to the Bureau of Transport Economics. As I understand it, it never intended to put in a submission. The figures that it prepared for the domestic air transport review had been available all the time. Officers of the BTE were also seconded to assist in the Holcroft inquiry. Criticism has been made of the Department of Transport for not disclosing commercially confidential financial and operational statistics. As I understand the situation the Department is not at liberty to disclose those figures without the permission of the airlines involved. In any case, there was nothing in the world to stop the Holcroft inquiry from going to those airlines and obtaining from them the particular figures that were needed. There have been criticisms. Some are justified but many are not.

SPEECH.PARA: If we want to look at the interests of the Australian air travelling public we have to look at the scenario in which the airlines operate. Australia is a land with a population slightly in excess of 14 million people and an area of 7,682,000 square kilometres. Unfortunately, 10 million of those people-70 per cent-live within 35 kilometres of the coast. We have problems with some of our States. For instance, the Northern Territory has a population of only 115,000 people spread over 17 per cent of Australia's land area. Australia is generally recognised as one of the most urbanised countries in the world. The average urban population of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is 86 per cent. Only three OECD countries have a higher urban population-Belgium with 94 per cent, Iceland with 87 per cent and the Netherlands with 88 per cent. But, of course, not one of those countries would make a fair sized cattle station in western Queensland.

Let me compare my own State of Queensland with Victoria. I single out those States because I know Queensland and the problems it has. Queensland has a smaller population than either Sydney or Melbourne yet it has nine jet airports operating every day of the week and numerous airports to take aircraft of F27 standard. In Victoria there is one major domestic airport and a few cricket fields scattered around the countryside from which commuter airlines operate. Australia has these problems.

As against that, there are the economies of scale relating to airline equipment. I have instanced those in previous debates in the Senate. Whereas one airline might have 11 Boeing 727-200 aircraft, a comparable airline in the United States of America probably flies 100 of those, plus Lockheed Tristars, DC8s and whatever else. We do not have those economies of scale in airline equipment. The same position applies to staff. I really think the airlines could do better in their pooling of resources or having another company handling their aircraft in country areas. But we have places such as Rockhampton-my home town-and Alice Springs where we have two companies which have two lots of staff to handle a small number of aircraft. If the traffic density and throughput of aircraft were there, the same number of people could probably handle four, five or six times the volume of aircraft that they are currently asked to handle.

The form in which this matter of public importance is framed presupposes that the Australian travelling public is hard done by. The question is: By what criteria do we judge that matter? All honourable senators in this chamber, in the pursuit of their duties, are privileged to travel overseas. That travel gives us an opportunity to study how other airlines operate, how the average passenger is treated and how the various fare structures stand up. I think that taking into consideration all the constraints that I have mentioned, most of us would agree that our service is pretty good. It has been generally recognised for some time that our air fares, on the short haul trips, are below those of America and our air fares on long haul journeys are above these of America. In the last few years that situation has been remedied. As a matter of fact mention was made here of the claim that Western Australian senators are not taking part in this debate. Of course only a limited number of senators can take part in this debate but in the period that I have been a senator, the Western Australian senators have put the case quite strongly to illustrate the disadvantage suffered by people travelling to and from their State. That fact was acknowledged long before Fair Internal Air Fares-or whatever pressure group is pressuring them-saw the light of day. Western Australian senators were doing the right thing in this chamber by their constituents.

From 1974 onwards, it has been generally recognised that this disadvantage existed. Since then, every time that a fare increase has occurred the flag fall charge has risen at a higher rate than the charge for the distance component. Thus passengers travelling on the long haul routes-whether to Perth, Cairns or Darwin-were disadvantaged. Fares to these places have slowly come back to a price that, in the circumstances, is more reasonable. If honourable senators compare American fares with our fares, before deregulation, on similar distances, they will see that our respective fares are line ball. So again I ask: By what criteria do we judge our fares? If honourable senators look at fares in Great Britain or the Continent they will see our fares are considerably lower, despite all the problems that we have in servicing a country the size of Australia.

Both Senator Button and Senator Gietzelt have laboured us with a fair bit of criticism-to put it mildly-yet I never once heard an alternative plan. I never heard them say that we were badly done by in comparison with other standards. Nor did they give any indication whether they had a plan, and how it would benefit the travelling public in Australia. They were rather light in making suggestions in that area, but that is part of what we get used to here. Sometimes we do have a good, informative, and objective debate. Unfortunately, this debate deteriorated with the first Opposition speaker and the second Opposition speaker did not help him raise the standard.

Honourable senators have made much of the use of Qantas Airways Ltd to fly domestic passengers to Perth and Darwin. Let us briefly look at this proposition. Firstly, if Qantas can guarantee 2,000 empty seats across Australia every week, it is flying the wrong aircraft. I have spoken before and not without some justice in this chamber about the hangups that airline companies have on commonality in air frames and engines. At least it is pleasing to see that Qantas has departed from that approach. I repeat that, if Qantas can constantly guarantee 2,000 empty seats across Australia, it is flying the wrong aircraft. The 747 is a magnificent aircraft which has a very low seat kilometre cost but, if Qantas is consistently flying with a large number of seats empty, those costs are not there for Qantas to utilise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not fill them up domestically?

—If honourable senators look at the domestic problem they will see that Darwin and Perth are served by smaller aircraft which gives them a greater number of services. If we put 747s on that route as Qantas suggested in its submission to the Holcroft inquiry-and we know that it has two spare 747s which it cannot sell-we will see a reduction in the frequency of services. I do not think that is what service is all about. Of course we have the attendant problems of how to differentiate between international and domestic passengers when they go through customs and immigration. Qantas would find that it would have those problems at either end whereas now we just collect our baggage, get off the aircraft and go. So there are many logistic problems in that proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I return to the problem that I look upon frequency of services as an important element in airline services. If we use that excess capacity, what happens when Qantas is delayed overseas? What happens if there is fog at Heathrow airport or an aircraft loses an engine at Bombay? Do we expect domestic carriers to fly empty aircraft there to pick up passengers? What will that do to our air fare structure? There are lots of problems and it is not as easy as it first appears on the surface to provide services to the outlying areas of this country.

The tone of the debate on the two-airline agreement seems to indicate that the two-airline policy primarily is to protect two airlines. Undoubtedly that is what happens but, as far as I am concerned, the two-airline policy is there to provide a regular, stable, scheduled service to all of Australia. What is the alternative? Of course the alternative is deregulation involving all the problems that we are hearing about from the United States. Frankly I do not think we can afford that. We could not afford the upset in the scheduled services. We want to provide services in a country that relies tremendously on air transport. As honourable senators can imagine, we could not afford the disruption of employment with new firms starting up and going to the wall. In America a large number of cities which have a far greater population than our provincial cities are now going without trunk services. This is a cause for sober reflection. Admittedly, in some instances this matter is being taken up by commuter airlines which use smaller aircraft with a higher seat kilometre cost. This is happening and it has caused major disruptions in a country which has a far larger population than we have. Of course if that procedure were superimposed on a scenario such as we have in Australia, I think the problems arising from it would be something that any government would find very hard to live with.

Briefly I touch on a couple of aspects of the Holcroft inquiry. Figures have been taken out-I have heard them broadcast-which indicate a $200 reduction in the air fares to Perth and Darwin. I am referring to the figures on page 275 of the Holcroft report. Unfortunately, what has not been taken into consideration by the people using those figures is the first note (a), which states:
The calculations are based on 1979-80 jet network average cost and traffic data.

Of course there have been changes in the statistics, operating costs and air fare structure since 1979-80. It is significant to note that part of the major changes that have been involved include the fuel component, which is part of the distance component, that has gone up. We cannot possibly give credence to the idea of the $200 reduction. I am not denying that consideration of the next rises should take into account the fact that the rises should be greater on the short haul routes. Much has been said about cross-subsidisation. I do not think there would be an airline in the world which could completely abandon cross-subsidisation. It would be pretty hard to work out.

Much has been said about the figures on page 208 of the inquiry's report. What the figures do not take into consideration, as I understand it, is the fact that there are many multi-stage journeys. My journey from Rockhampton to Canberra is a multi-stage one. Those multi-stage journeys during which the aircraft lands and takes off again do not contain a second or third flag fall component. The Holcroft inquiry has rightly addressed itself to this problem. The inquiry has said that where there is a need for a second or third flag fall component it should be absorbed by the whole network, not by the people who are making multi-stage journeys. In effect, the report indicates that there is cross-subsidisation and that it should be reduced and, at the same time, it indicates that there should be further cross-subsidisation. Taking that into consideration, the figures on page 208 should be looked at in a different light. Indeed, I would question whether they are accurate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators have just heard a very thoughtful speech. Senator Collard obviously has studied the matter in some depth and is an expert in many of the fields covered by the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. However, I beg to differ with his judgments, although I respect his knowledge of the facts. The Senate is debating a matter of public importance about the failure of the Government to administer the airlines system in the interests of the travelling public. One could canvass the truth of several aspects, but I will name just two. One aspect is the shameful, disgraceful parallel scheduling of flights which has been allowed by weak Ministers of the Parliament, both Labor and Liberal, over a number of years. It is disgraceful and absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: Many times I have spoken to senior executives of both Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airline of Australia over an informal lunch and I have said to them: 'A strong Minister-a Minister who had the guts to stand up to you-could force you to change parallel scheduling virtually overnight and you could come to some arrangement'. On every occasion I have had some sort of smiling acknowledgment from them that that would be possible. The absurdity of a situation in which two aircraft take off for a point thousands of miles away within five minutes of each other and land there within five minutes of each other needs only to be stated to be appreciated. I shall say no more about that.

Secondly, there is the question of price, of how people in out of the way areas, particularly in Western Australia, have been savagely disadvantaged over a great period through the process of cross-subsidisation. The Holcroft committee confirmed the worst suspicions of Western Australian senators with the disclosure that cross-subsidisation had cost passengers-essentially Western Australians-an additional $19.8m in 1979-80. I pay a compliment to the Western Australian senators because it was essentially their activities, their concern for Western Australians and their realisation of the political implications of the forthcoming Senate election to Western Australia which virtually caused the Government to establish the Holcroft committee.

Let me give the scenario. It was an election year. An organisation in Western Australia called the Fair Air Fares Campaigners and the Australian Democrats were getting considerable publicity for their claims about the injustices being done to Western Australian travellers vis-a-vis those who live on the east coast. The Western Australian Liberal senators-quite properly, quite cleverly and quite courageously-confronted the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and said that something had to be done. The Prime Minister, in the early part of 1980, established the Holcroft committee. That is the history of the arrangement. The election was then won, a Western Australian Liberal senator scrambled home by the skin of his teeth, and the Prime Minister then saw no justification for having the Holcroft committee continue. I shall quote from the Australian Financial Review of 4 March a report by Ali Cromie which has been confirmed by journalists such as Peter Bowers. There seems to be no doubt that Mr Hunt gives everybody to understand that the report was due in June or July 1981. I think Mr Hunt concedes that. The impetus for containing the inquiry almost certainly came from the Prime Minister. The report in the Australian Financial Review states:
Another Western Australian Member said that at the meeting in the Prime Minister's office on November 26, the Prime Minister asked Mr Hunt when the Holcroft inquiry was due to report.
Mr Hunt had replied 'June, July or thereabouts,' he said.
The Prime Minister then said 'Ralph, tell them to report by January 31,' the Western Australian Member said.
Mr Hunt did tell the committee that. The report further states:
This account of the meeting was verified by a number of Western Australian Members yesterday.

That is a pretty shameful way in which to treat three very distinguished people who gave their time to report on a matter of some significance. It is an act of total political cynicism by the Prime Minister-not by the Western Australian senators but by the Prime Minister-to the Western Australian senators and to the people of Western Australia. One could comment that during the course of the inquiry the Holcroft committee got too close to the truth. It was exposing the question of cross-subsidisation in a devastating way, according to Peter Bowers. It exposed the myth of competition between TAA and Ansett, and denounced the two-airline policy as merely ensuring the preservation of a duopolistic situation.

The Holcroft committee then called the Department of Transport nothing more than a rubber stamp and mentioned other matters very close to the truth. That was obviously untenable to Mr Fraser as he won the election and won the fifth Senate seat in Western Australia. Perhaps the rudest and crudest act was the signing by the Government of a new airline agreement for 10 years while this committee was receiving evidence and determining its report. I find it to be an almost unbelievable discourtesy and rudeness for a government-I do not blame Mr Hunt; he was obviously acting on the instructions of Cabinet-to do that sort of thing and say to a committee which it has set up: 'Please give us your valuable time so that we can help'. The committee's report also is devastating in regard to the total lack of co-operation given to the committee by Ansett and by the Department of Transport.

All I have just said is known. What can be done and what should be done now? As far as the airline policy itself is concerned the Press seems to feel that long haul air fares will now be lowered at the expense of short haul air fares. We are all for that, but surely, bearing in mind the exercise of the Holcroft inquiry, the courage of the Western Australian senators, the support on this side of the chamber for a new look at an airline policy, it is just not good enough to bury it like that. I hope that Western Australian Liberal senators will show the courage which they have shown to this point and not just be bought off by a small matter such as that. That is what Mr Hunt said six months ago. I should think they ought to settle for something much better. There are alternatives.

I have a copy of the Airlines Agreements Act 1952-1973. The Senate will be interested to know that it is a simple piece of paper which states that the agreement between the Commonwealth, Ansett and TAA is approved. The Act is a remarkably simple thing. There are schedules to the Act which are very complicated and very detailed and which set out the various agreements. Section 1 of Schedule 1 states:
This agreement shall have no force or effect and shall not be binding on either party unless and until it is approved by the Parliament of the Commonwealth.

That would mean in simple terms that the Senate will expect a Bill of that description to come before it within the next few weeks because the Government has an obsession with rushing this legislation through Parliament and ratifying this agreement before the newly-elected Senate meets after 1 July. I am sure that members of the Australian Labor Party will not ratify this agreement without some sort of a fight. We will not want to involve party politics in this matter. We hope that senators on the Government side-particularly the Western Australian Liberal senators-will be able to hold up the ratification of this agreement at least until we have some more information. Several options are open. For example we could set up a Senate committee to take over the unfinished work of the Holcroft committee. That appeals to me because I believe that senators of all parties have done splendid work in this area. I am not satisfied with the work of the Government back benchers committee which was set up although I applaud the Government members for involving themselves in that way. But that is not good enough because members do not have the power to call evidence or to force witnesses to attend. We want the Holcroft committee's work to be at least completed. I ask whether it is possible-after reasonable apology to the members of the Holcroft committee-for the Government to ask that that committee be reconstituted, to continue taking evidence and to continue with its report. Of course, that would be the most ideal situation. If this is not possible should the work of the committee be substituted by the creation of a royal commission? The Australian Democrats would not be opposed to that although we lean to the view that it should be members of Parliament, preferably senators, who complete the work of the committee.

We would like to see questions such as the merger of Qantas Airways Ltd and TAA taken as part of the terms of reference. I would like discussed the points Senator Collard raised such as the impossibility of filling the seats between Perth and Melbourne. I say that this is difficult and of course it is difficult. Of course there are problems, but the job of government is to overcome problems. It is inconceivable that we should have so many spare seats in aircraft flying east-west and west-east each day of the week. During the last election campaign when Mr Jack Evans and the Australian Democrats were leading the push to have air fares examined, Western Australian Liberal Party senators adopted a slogan, 'Only Liberal Senators will truly represent Western Australian interests'. We should not put too fine a point on that. I promise Western Australian senators that within the next few weeks they will have that opportunity to stand up in the Senate and be counted when the agreement comes into this chamber for ratification.
Sitting suspended from 1.3 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this matter of public importance, it is a pleasure to defend the fine record of not only the present Government but also of Liberal-National Country Party governments through the years since 1956, because we can see quite clearly and without any ambiguity what the consequences of that policy have been. The end result of the policies followed by this Government is that this country has one of the finest airline systems in the world, if not the finest system.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak to the substance of this matter of public importance which deals not only with the two airlines agreement or the internal airlines of this country, which I think is a rather peripheral part of it, but also with the external airline-Qantas Airways Ltd.

Out of courtesy, I would like to deal briefly with some of the points made by Opposition senators on this matter. Senator Button dealt rather tediously with minutiae and irrelevancies. He persisted in his habit of failing to focus and to discipline the very fine intellect that he undoubtedly possesses. Both Senator Button and Senator Gietzelt seemed to be obsessed with Rupert Murdoch. Do they really believe, now that he owns the Times, the Sunday Times and the News of the World, that a dreadful fate will befall the British Labour Party? What a tragedy for them that the British Labour Party is already in the state of disrepair that the Australian Labor Party is in. Senator Gietzelt dealt with the same sort of irrelevancies as Senator Button. It was an undisguised attack on Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and its principals, Mr Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles. We heard repetitively the theme of how they were operating against the Australian Labor Party and its policies. What are these people saying? Are they really attacking the two-airline policy? Are they really saying that we need only one airline in this country? Are they saying that they want to see applied the socialist theories and practices which have been applied in Europe and which have taken countries such as Sweden and the United Kingdom to their present levels of economic incompetence?

We want to see some competition in Australia. We want to see private enterprise operating wherever possible to provide goods and services for the people of Australia because that is our insurance that in the long term those goods and services will be provided in the most efficient and economical manner possible. Senator Chipp was a bit more temperate in his attacks on Ansett, but apart from the matter of parallel scheduling, he dealt mostly with the report of the Holcroft inquiry. With respect to Senator Chipp, this debate is really not about the report of the Holcroft inquiry. It is a debate on the whole question of how airlines serve the Australian people.

I would like to take a minute to deal with parallel scheduling because clearly it is a matter of annoyance to the Australian people. We have to look at how the two-airline policy has operated in the past when the stipulation that the airlines possess equipment of equivalent capacity and had equivalent fleet sizes led to a situation in which economics dictated that to achieve maximum utilisation of that equipment the airlines had to resort to parallel scheduling. They cannot keep aircraft sitting on the ground and use them for a small portion of the time, particularly in a country such as Australia where all airlines are subject to a curfew at most jet airfields.

The Government has recognised that and times are changing. A very significant event occurred last year when there was a departure from the concept of equivalent fleet equipment in that Ansett and Trans-Australia Airlines made different judgments of what was best for the market. They have now bought aircraft of different sizes. A consequence of that, to provide the economic viability that the airlines need, will be different flight schedules for the Australian people. The Government can take the credit for that because its policy allowed the airlines to depart from the parallel equipment purchase concept.

Let me deal with the substance of the matter of public importance. What are the best interests of the Australian travelling community? The pre-eminent concern is safety which is something that the Australian people take as a matter of course. When one gets into an airliner, one automatically believes that one will reach one's destination. Everyone in this chamber knows that because no group in Australia uses aircraft and air travel more consistently than members of this Parliament. Air safety in Australia is at a very high level and I doubt that it could be lifted to a higher level. I hark back to the theme put forward years ago by the then Department of Civil Aviation-'safety is no accident'.

Safety is the consequence of a very complex sequence of events-an attitude of mind of a large group of people, training, economics, the selection of equipment and, above all, the way the government of the day exercises its regulatory control so that safety at all levels is ensured. It is quite impossible to take so complex a situation as the Australian airlines system and de novo impose on it by regulation something that leads to absolute safety unless it has been built up meticulously over the years bit by bit.

At present that safety is being compromised, not by the Australian Government but by the unions. I refer to the wildcat strikes over the last few years by the Storemen and Packers Union and the Transport Workers Union and their refusal to supply fuel to aircraft at certain airports around this country so that aircraft are consistently operating with higher loads than they need bear to overfly refuelling points to get through their route schedules. This leads to an intangible degradation of the safety of the airlines. What have we heard about this from the ALP? We have heard not a bit, because honourable senators support those same unions. Furthermore, not only are aircraft operating with unnecessary loads but also there is the disruption of the whole of the operational cycle, which comes from operating an airliner on a route while not knowing where the fuel supplies are, and the consequent disorganisation.

The second point in relation to the best interests of the community concerns the frequency of schedules and the very real convenience that comes from the multitude of schedules that are available throughout the Australian airline system. There is an economy of scale in airline travel-the larger the individual aircraft, by and large, the less is the cost per seat mile. But the larger the aircraft the less frequent is the service and, in one sense, the consumer suffers. That is one of the worries about the move to wide-bodied aircraft for those of us who live in the outlying States of Queensland and Western Australia and in the Northern Territory. Australian travellers have the luxury of a wide variety of schedules when they choose to fly.

Another important point in the interests of the consumer relates to the efficiency of transport. Here I am talking about the speed factor. Since 1956 Australian airlines have operated the most modern equipment in the world. That has been a consequence of the progressive and far-seeing outlook of Liberal-National Party governments during that period. It is no accident that that has occurred. If we look at other countries where governments have dominated airline transport with a monopolistic one-airline system, we will frequently find that the equipment that is used in those countries is 10, 15 or 20 years older than the equipment that is used in the more advanced countries. The fact that Australian airlines in their choice of equipment are viewed by other airlines in the world as a guide on what to buy is hardly a sign of incompetence in Government policy.

Another important factor in the interests of the traveller is reliability. The record of on-time departures of Australian airlines is excellent and again that reflects on the policies that the Government through its regulatory authority has exercised over the airlines. The only exception to that record of reliability of any statistical significance is where the unions have intervened and have withheld their services or have taken strike action to prevent aircraft from flying. We have had a very strong lesson of this behaviour over the last month in the dispute involving Qantas Airways Ltd and the secondary boycotts that have flowed from that and which are probably still in operation through the actions of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I am pleased that the Government stood behind the Qantas management and reaffirmed the right of Qantas management and the management of TAA and Ansett and every other airline operator in Australia to use volunteer staff labour when they are held to ransom by irresponsible unions. If the airlines did not have available to them that facility-a facility that has existed ever since airlines started flying operations in this country-passengers would be locked up in aircraft, unable to open the doors, quarantinable garbage on overseas flights would be unable to be removed, toilets would not be cleaned and aircraft would be unable to be fuelled. The public cannot be held to ransom in this way. It is the duty of management to manage-not the unions or the stewards.

What is the position of the Australian Labor Party in this problem? I would have thought that this discussion would have been the very last that the Australian Labor Party would have brought up in this place because it links the Australian Labor Party indissolubly with the actions of these irresponsible unions. Not one word has come from within the ALP about the way all of those travellers were held to ransom overseas. People without any budgetary allowance for such problems-by and large frugal people who had saved for years to go on an overseas trip-were being held overseas without any access to money, unable to pay for accommodation, unable to buy food and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brought on by Qantas under instructions from the Government.

—How many Press releases did Senator Cavanagh issue about their plight and the actions of the unions? Not one! All your leader did was to preach to the public about Prince Charles. He was frightened that Prince Charles might become another Sir John Kerr. At a time when thousands of Australian travellers were stranded overseas and the airline was almost reduced to bankruptcy, what did we hear from the Australian Labor Party? This is what we heard: 'We do not want Prince Charles as the Governor-General'. No concern was expressed for the public at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The fifth point I raise relating to the interests of travellers is the provision of services at reasonable cost. Except for the long distance travellers, I think we have had a record of good costing of fares in this country. In addition, we have had aircraft provided that have been clean and attractive interiors. We have had a very high level of good cabin service. We have had a very efficient booking and ticketing service. In a country with a low population density like Australia and a very vast geographic area, that is no mean achievement at all.

The airline industry is a very complex industry. It needs continuous attention. It needs continual fine tuning. I have plenty of criticism in small detail on the way in which the airline system of this country operates but, undeniably, the Australian community and the Australian Government can take great pride at the level of Australian endeavour that is manifested today in the airline industry. This country was one of the pioneering countries in airline transport. It is a fair claim to make today, as those of us who have travelled in other countries know, that we still maintain on our internal and on our external airline services a position of pre-eminence in the world in a field in which we pioneered. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
