SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate that I have received from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies a report on the social impact of uranium mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals for the six-month period ending 30 September 1980. I now present that report and seek leave to make a statement concerning some of the issues contained in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The report consists of five parts constituting the report proper, and three appendices. The report proper begins with a recapitulation of the main points of the previous report, which was for the six-month period ending 31 March 1980. The remainder of the report consists of a discussion of work methods of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies; a description of some of the projects that the Institute has under way or is planning to undertake; and comments on a number of specific issues relating to the social impact of uranium mining in the region.

The Institute is undertaking a wide range of research activities in the region as part of its task of monitoring developments in the region as they affect Aboriginals. These projects include a compilation of a social history of the Alligator Rivers Region and its people; a number of censuses which will give a clearer picture of the population of the region, its composition and status; a survey of laws and legislation affecting Aboriginals in the region from the beginning of the century to the present; film and photographic records relating to the region and its population; and language studies.

I note with satisfaction that the latest report from the Institute indicates that some real progress has been made in dealing with those problems which have been commented on by the Institute in previous reports. For example, one of the more complex matters which is being dealt with is the development of satisfactory structures to handle the receipt and distribution of mining revenues received by Aboriginals both from the Ranger and Nabarlek projects. Aboriginals receiving income from the Ranger project have successfully established the Gagudju Association which effectively handles the distribution and investment of funds received. Moves are under way to establish a similar organisation for those people who are receiving payments from the Nabarlek project.

This matter has been taken up by the Northern Land Council together with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and officers of these two bodies have been meeting with Aboriginal people to determine the most appropriate type of organisation for this purpose and to work out methods of representation for the Aboriginals concerned. The Institute project team has made an important contribution to these discussions.

Another matter which has been reported on previously is that of heavy traffic on the Cahill's Crossing to Nabarlek road. Whilst the report indicates that there is continuing concern within the community at Oenpelli about the use of the road, it is nevertheless pleasing to note that agreement has been reached between the Northern Land Council, local traditional owners, and Queensland Mines Limited to reduce future road traffic on that particular road. I am advised that the company has upgraded the barge landing at Wunyu Beach, and over 2,400 tonnes of materials have been brought over the landing, thereby reducing the volumes of traffic using the Cahill's Crossing road. Among other measures taken by the company to reduce traffic on this road are the utilization of an aircraft for general and cargo purposes and an increase in the capacity of some of the tankers using the road.

I wish to draw to the attention of honourable senators comments made in the report regarding alcohol. The point is made in the report that the consumption of alcohol is not a preoccupation of the total Aboriginal community living in that region but is confined to a sub-set within the community. The report also indicates that club facilities at Oenpelli have been improved, and this has led to more acceptable and less disruptive drinking habits within the community.

The report draws attention to comments made by the Institute in respect of the Plan of Management for the Kakadu National Park. The issue of Aboriginal participation in the management of the park and comments by the Institute have been given due consideration by my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment. Whilst the question of participation in park management has not been the subject of any representations from Aboriginal organisations such as the Northern Land Council, the Gagudju Association or the Gunbalanya Council at Oenpelli, the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service has indicated a continuing willingness to consult with the Aboriginal people with regard to this matter. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service engages in consultations with the Gagudju Association over a wide range of management matters. Recent discussions have been held regarding concern expressed by some individuals about housing, outstations and the culling of horses and buffalo in the park.

Another area of concern commented upon in the report is the intrusion into Aboriginal land of unauthorised visitors. It is, of course, necessary for people other than local Aboriginals to have permits to enter Aboriginal land. Following action initiated by the Standing Committee on Social Impact, the Committee-which is located in Darwin and comprising senior representatives of the Northern Territory Government, the Northern Land Council, the Institute, and my Department-held consultations with the Northern Territory Police, Aboriginals at Oenpelli, and officers of my Department. As a result of these consultations, a check-point and boom gate will be established on the road leading from the East Alligator River to Oenpelli. Members of the local community will man the check-point, with the support and co-operation of the Northern Territory Police. This will provide real control of road access into Arnhem Land from the west. In other parts of the region, the implementation of the Kakadu National Park Plan of Management will further assist in the control of visitors.

Whilst in no way wishing to understate the difficulties with which the Aboriginal people are confronted in the face of extensive development in the uranium province, I am satisfied that there has been some very real progress made in dealing positively with those matters which are from time to time identified by way of these reports as problem areas. The Institute identifies these problem areas and the Standing Committee on Social Impact determines the action needed to deal with the problems identified. This scheme is ensuring that the adverse impacts of development on the local Aboriginal population have been kept to a minimum. At the same time, the local Aboriginal people are being assisted to ensure that, at a time of their choosing, they are in a position to take advantage of the economic benefits which flow to the Aboriginal people living in that region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I have moved this motion in relation to Item 2, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, guidelines relating to the provision of financial assistance under the Act, and Item 3, guidelines relating to the provision of legal or financial assistance other than under the Act.

I welcome the appearance of the documents as an important contribution to the freedom of information and as a contribution to more open and rational decision making than has been the position in this area in the past. I have been nagging the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to produce the documents ever since I have been a member of parliament and especially in a series of Estimates committee hearings over the last two and a half years. It is always to some degree satisfying as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be well aware, to see one's nagging bearing fruit, however belatedly.

Item 2 concerns financial assistance given under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in respect of certain kinds of applications, namely, those under section 140 to challenge the validity of organisation rules, actions under section 141 to enforce a compliance with valid organisation rules and under section 159 to inquire into alleged irregularities in organisation elections-the organisations in each case usually being trade unions. Some quite substantial outgoings have been made in recent years under these various heads, in some cases notorious pieces of litigation like the long standing saga involving Messrs Egan and Maher and indeed in some matters in which I was personally involved as a counsel. The appropriation in 1980-81 for this purpose is put at $75,000 which is roughly in line with the kinds of outgoings that have been made available under these heads in the past. Whether, however, those outgoings both in the past and proposed for this financial year represent what should be the position so far as aid and assistance to individuals making challenges under the rules are concerned and are sufficient is a matter of some argument and certainly it is the view of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which has been closely involved in endeavouring to consult with the Attorney-General in the preparation of these guidelines, that the outgoings have not been substantial enough and that the Attorney has adopted far too cautious and negative an approach in the granting of legal aid in this area.

The guidelines set out in the document are at first sight reasonably unexceptionable. They refer to considerations of hardship and considerations of reasonableness in all the circumstances of the case. They refer to aid being granted only to individuals rather than organisations and only to individuals to the extent that they themselves are not indemnified by organisations or anyone else. There are further provisions which identify additional criteria in this sort of language, for example, in paragraph 4.2 which reads:
In determining the amount of financial assistance to be granted regard will be had to what is considered to be a reasonable period in which to conclude the proceedings.
And again in paragraph 4.3 which states:

In determining whether financial assistance should be authorised regard will be had to the justice of the applicant's case in relation to the magnitude of the costs likely to be incurred by him in the proceedings.

There is an inevitable degree of vagueness in those sorts of phrases, but perhaps it is inevitable vagueness given the nature of the case, and I do not stop to take exception to the drafting on those grounds alone. I simply record my gratitude that considerations of this kind are being put openly on the record and identified as considerations which are to govern the discretion of the decision maker and, as a result, can thus be sensibly addressed by parties seeking legal aid.

I am concerned, and the ACTU and the Labor movement have been concerned, about the vesting of discretions of this kind in the Attorney-General, who may very well not be the best person to make sensible informed decisions as to what the justice of a particular case may be or what might be a reasonable grant of aid in particular circumstances. It has been the submission of the ACTU to the Attorney-General-a submission which I and the Australian Labor Party wholeheartedly endorse-that decisions of this kind ought not to be subject to the sole discretionary decision-making power of the Attorney-General; rather, they should be subject to the certification of the Industrial Registrar-he is the most administratively appealing-or some other figure in the industrial system who can be relied upon to have a sensitive and balanced understanding of what the merits of these sorts of cases are likely to be. For that reason, I regard the guidelines document as inadequate, requiring further consultation and further thought by the Government with a view to its revision. It is a step forward on the present situation, however, and I acknowledge it as such. I simply hope that the Attorney will follow through his originally stated intention of consulting with the National Labour Consultative Council, not going it alone but producing a jointly agreed set of guidelines rather than a unilateral set, which seems to be the case at the moment.

Item 3 on the list of papers is a document which deals with all categories of financial assistance in public interest and test case litigation, other than that which is afforded through the normal legal aid system. It refers to grants of legal aid in Aboriginal Land Commissioner hearings, Administrative Appeals Tribunal cases, Security Appeals Tribunal cases involving Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, racial discrimination cases, Repatriation Review Tribunal cases, trade practices cases, and litigation arising under non-statutory schemes such as public interest and test cases, overseas custody cases, child removal cases and environmental cases. Simply to list the matters with which this guidelines document deals is to indicate just how important the guidelines are, and indeed how wide-ranging any detailed discussion of the document would need to be to touch all the points that should be made.

I do not propose in all the circumstances to engage on any wide-ranging discussion but simply to make one or two points that arise from the fairly superficial reading of this document that I have had time for. Again, we are dealing with what is potentially a very large area of government outgoings. Some $175,000 has been allocated for this purpose in the current Budget. I simply hope that that money at least will be spent, and that if it looks like being overspent the Government will not hesitate to make further appropriations available. In the last financial year, 1979-80, only $34,700 was spent at the Attorney's discretion in granting financial assistance in all these various categories. To my mind, that clearly demonstrates an excessive caution on the part of the Attorney in granting legal aid assistance in these sorts of cases, and I hope that the document before us foreshadows a substantial relaxation in the Attorney's attitude.

As I have said, on the basis of what has necessarily so far been only a superficial reading, the new guidelines seem to be generally more adequate and more acceptable than was the case with the conciliation and arbitration guidelines. Again, however, I wish to reserve any final position in this respect until there has been an opportunity to look at them in more detail. One particular area does stand out, however, as representing possibly a backward step in the provision of assistance by the Government, and I refer to that part of the document which deals with the granting of legal aid in environmental test cases, again a hugely important and growingly important area of public interest litigation. This is the one area in which it is possible to compare in detail the new document with existing practice because this is the one area in which a guidelines document has been formulated and circulated previously. A guidelines document was issued in 1978 by the Attorney-General's Department. A brief comparison between that earlier document and the current one is enough to give me some concern that a bit of a retreat, a bit of backward-stepping, is going on here rather than the forward-looking, more sensitive approach that one was rather led to expect by the Attorney's bringing forward this document. I refer to two examples of the sort of thing I mean. In the new guidelines provision, one of the bases on which the Attorney-General is to exercise his discretion, is described as follows:

The matter in issue should relate to preservation of the environment or wildlife from damage or destruction adverse to the national interest. Ordinarily the environmental issue will only arise in relation to Commonwealth activity or under a law of the Commonwealth.
That is to be compared with language, on the face of it similar but in fact rather different, in the 1978 guidelines document, where the equivalent passage states:

The issue involved must arise within a Federal territory or under Federal law or, if within a State under State law, the issue should affect the national interest or such a substantial public interest as to be of national concern.

The key difference, of course, is that there is an explicit reference in the earlier document to environmental litigation under State law; whereas the present document, although that could be regarded as being indirectly subsumed in it to the extent that there is reference to litigation in the national interest, does not refer to litigation under State law. What concerns me, and it ought to concern the community, and certainly the Australian Conservation Foundation and the national environment protection movement, is the possibility that these new guidelines will be interpreted and applied by the Attorney in such a way as to limit and to refuse the application of financial assistance to environmental groups and individual litigants in these cases when the legal basis of their action is under State law.

These sorts of situations arise all the time because many environmental issues are ones that can be pursued at law only through State planning agencies, tribunals and courts. I have on my desk at the moment, and the Attorney will be aware of it, one such application in respect of an attempt to preserve from destruction a small area of parkland within the Dandenong Ranges. The basis of that application to the courts is very much State law, but it is argued that the implications involved for the national interest in the preservation of the Dandenongs are such as to justify a grant of Commonwealth aid. It may be that the Attorney is, and will continue to be, willing to grant legal aid in these cases where some nexus with a larger national interest can be established, but I am concerned, and I am sure many other groups will be concerned, at the removal from the guidelines document governing environmental litigation of the explicit reference to State law.

One other matter I point to as a further illustration of my concern is the reference to opinions being obtained by counsel as a precondition for aid being granted in environment cases. Paragraph 23 of the new document states:
Counsel's opinion as to the prospects of success of the proposed proceedings will ordinarily be required.
In the 1978 document there was a rather more substantial treatment of this issue in the following terms:
Where legal issues are involved the applicant should additionally make available any solicitor's or counsel's opinions on the prospects of success if already obtained.
This is the key to the difference between the documents:

Alternatively, and by way of contribution, it may be reasonable to require the applicant to provide counsel's opinion on the prospects of success or it may be decided that as a preliminary step financial assistance should be granted to enable the applicant to obtain counsel's or senior counsel's opinion, depending upon the complexity of the case.

In other words, what is being contemplated here is that a preliminary application for assistance in order to procure the initial counsel's opinion should be acceded to by the Attorney-General before the applicant actually commits himself or herself to embarking on litigation. As a practical matter, in the real world the financial assistance is often needed most at that threshold level when one is getting counsel's opinion to determine whether the matter can justify litigation. Again, it represents a step backwards if financial aid is not to be forthcoming in the future at this stage. It may be that the language of the new document is wide enough and general enough to cover that pre-existing situation. But I am worried and I think a number of groups with a real interest in this matter will be worried that the Commonwealth, despite surface appearances, is going backwards on this issue.

It is impossible to satisfy everyone in matters of this kind. It may be that on further examination I will be wanting to make some further representations to the Attorney-General and seeking even more substantial provisions than those which I have foreshadowed here today. I repeat that, generally speaking, my attitude and the attitude of the Opposition to these documents is one of approbation of the Attorney-General for bringing them forward and putting his cards on the table in this way. I repeat that this is one of the few occasions on which my main motive in rising has been not to blame but to praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that the act of taking note of these papers today has in fact denied other senators an opportunity to lay before the Senate detailed evidence of how the guidelines in fact operate and why such large costs are sought from the Attorney-General. Senator Evans suggested, quite rightly, that he had had a only limited time to look at the guidelines and therefore did not wish to raise substantive points based on evidence.
—We did not know they were coming up today. We just got the list.

—Thank you, Senator Missen. I had the benefit of receiving copies of the documents, but I did not receive them in sufficient time to have sent from my office in Tasmania detailed information which would have been most interesting to the Senate and, I am sure, to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) concerning the operation of the guidelines. I do not have a vocadex machine in my office here, so the detailed information could not come up in that way. Bearing this in mind, I discussed this matter with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button. He indicated that he would not be moving for the Senate to take note of the paper listed for today and that the matter could be dealt with on the next day of sitting, which would be Tuesday week, at which time, of course, all of this evidence would be available. I agree with Senator Evans that cases such as the Egan case need elaboration and, indeed, exposure because a substantial amount of money was involved in that case.
—I did not use the word 'exposure'.

—I have been corrected. I should have just said 'elaboration'. Other cases, including the plumbers case, need some elaboration. It must be said that very often the fault lies not with the complainants or with the defendants but with the court. The actions of the court in some cases do mean that costs escalate. The provision of detailed evidence on that must wait for another day.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Evans mentioned, the Attorney-General has budgeted for $175,000 for the provision this year of financial assistance by the Commonwealth other than under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I believe that some of the guidelines have been laid down because of financial constraint. The money is not always in the bin. That being the case I cannot understand why the Attorney-General does not go ahead and ask for costs when costs are there for the asking. For example, in the recent case involving the Defence of Government Schools Committee an amount of between $250,000 and $500,000 must have been spent by the Commonwealth in defence of that case. The costs were there for the asking. As I understand it, the Commonwealth has not sought costs. The costs could have been obtained from both the relators and the plaintiffs.

Among the relators, of course, were stalwarts such as Ian Black, Wally Curran, John Halfpenny, and Bill Hartley. They are entitled to take their cases to court but they must do so having regard to the effect that that will have both on the question of justice which they are attacking and on the taxpayers. On the one hand, I cannot see why the Attorney-General permits the taxpayers to pick up the tab on behalf of the relators and plaintiffs in that case and on the other denies sufficient funds for appeals relating to Aboriginal Land Commission hearings, Administrative Appeals Tribunal cases, Security Appeals Tribunal cases, racial discrimination cases, repatriation appeals tribunal cases, trade practices cases and the cases involving various non-statutory schemes. The mind boggles at why the Government cries poverty when it comes to those cases and does not apply for costs when it wins a case.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make a few comments on behalf of the Opposition on the report prepared by the Institute of Aboriginal Studies on the social impact of uranium mining on Aboriginals. Obviously the topic is a serious and complex one. The Opposition is not at all happy that the social impact of uranium mining on Aboriginals is properly understood or, indeed, that its deleterious effects will be properly redressed. However, I welcome the opportunity to make a comment on this report because when the last report on this topic was tabled my predecessor in this responsibility, Mr Stewart West, was not given the opportunity to speak in the other place.

I wish to comment on the distribution of mining reserves. The disbursement of funds resulting from the Nabarlek agreement is still fraught with difficulties, but investigations are currently being undertaken by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Northern Land Council. However, since the last report the Gagudju association has been incorporated. This association now has one full time employee, a legal adviser, and an accountant and has purchased the Cooinda hotel. It is in operation and its functions are expanding. We concede that all these matters are positive developments, but adequate machinery for the distribution of up-front money from Nabarlek has yet to be established. I point out that the report highlights the desirability of establishing an organisation such as Gagadju in the eastern sector of the Alligator Rivers region to handle the administrative arrangements. It is also worth noting that the report states that only seven Aboriginals are employed at Ranger and five by Queensland Mines Ltd at Nabarlek. Eleven of the 12 Aboriginals are employed in bush regeneration programs and one is an office worker. I make the comment that it seems that little benefit has flowed or will flow to Aboriginal people through employment in the uranium industry.

The second matter on which I wish to make a few comments is the matter of consultation. The report points out that a survey conducted by the project director found a high level of confusion among Aboriginals concerning organisations and events in the Alligator Rivers region. Aboriginals who had held public office had a much higher level of awareness than those who had not. The Institute is to produce a directory of people and organisations in the region. But I stress that the effectiveness of consultation and communication with traditional Aboriginal people must continue to be an area of major concern and we are not satisfied at all that effective communication is taking place.

The Institute's major criticism of the Kakadu National Park plan of management was that there was a total absence of any executive or managerial role for traditional owners of the Park in the management of what is, in effect, Aboriginal land. A plan to that effect lapsed when the Parliament was prorogued and it has to be retabled in this Parliament. I urge the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to take note of the importance of allowing traditional owners to participate in the management of the Kakadu National Park. Although I have received a letter from the Minister pointing out that he has received no representations from Aboriginal organisations regarding that participation, it does seem, nonetheless, to be a desirable development and one which the Institute of Aboriginal Studies has certainly endorsed. I hope that the Minister will give serious consideration to finding ways of allowing traditional owners to participate in the management of the plan when it is represented to the Parliament.

On control of land, especially as it concerns roads, the report pointed out that Aboriginal people were very concerned about non-Aboriginal encroachment on roads east of Cahill's Crossing and further and further into Arnhem Land. The Aboriginal people consider that the Ranger-Jabiru development is the cause of these encroachments. Next is the Oenpelli road problem. In 1980 the Minister informed the Senate that after consultation with traditional owners and the Northern Land Council the problem had been resolved. The Institute committee considers that continued heavy use of the road remains a problem and a major matter of concern to Oenpelli people. It is perhaps the most serious direct impact of the Nabarlek mining operation on the local Aboriginal population. To support the report in that respect I can say only that when I was in the Northern Territory recently I had several representations from Aboriginal people from that part of the Territory who were concerned that the encroachments were taking place and that the enforcement authorities were not acting to back up the Aboriginal people when they complained of encroachment. So I also ask the Minister to turn his attention to that matter.

In conclusion I say that the Opposition welcomes the fact that this report has been presented to Parliament. It will be of continuing concern to the Parliament, and to the Senate, to see that the social impact of uranium mining on Aborigines is monitored and that where developments are seen to be deleterious some form of redress is taken. I think the Institute of Aboriginal Studies is to be congratulated for its report which is a thorough and constructive one. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I shall make a few remarks about the schedule of special flights for 1 July 1980 to 31 December 1980. I want to remark about some of the information I have been able to gather from that report in the short time I have had to look at it. In my view the guidelines as set out some years ago are not being strictly adhered to. As I have said before in this Parliament, I have no objection to any person travelling on VIP aircraft as long as everybody gets an equal opportunity to do so. Looking at the schedule and the flights of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) I see that members of his own party or of the coalition parties have travelled on a flight on one occasion and the Executive Director, Mr Eggleton, has travelled on three occasions. There might even be more occasions but I have been able to pick up only three. That is a matter to which I object. Looking at the names of passengers with Mr Hayden on the VIP flights I see that no candidates or executive officer of the Australian Labor Party travelled on those flights. If it is good enough for the Prime Minister to take members of parliament, that is members of his party, and his Executive Officer, Mr Eggleton, with him, particularly during the election campaign, then I say that that privilege ought to be extended to the Leader of the Opposition so that he too can take the National Secretary of the Labor Party with him on campaigns if he so desires. He may not want to but he should have the opportunity.

I am also concerned about whether, when Mr Eggleton travels on these VIP flights, there is, in fact, a recovery cost of the equivalent fare from the Liberal Party of Australia, in the same way as journalists and newspapers have to reimburse the Government when journalists travel on VIP aircraft. I have made the request in the Parliament on numerous occasions that when these manifests are tabled alongside the name of each passenger who travelled the occupation and qualifications of that passenger should appear. When one looks through the list, particularly at the pages referring to the Prime Minister, one can see that there is page after page of the names of passengers who travelled on some of those flights. It would take a couple of years to do some research in order to find out what their occupations are-whether they are candidates, journalists, members of the Liberal Party Executive or whatever. I have made this request before but apparently it has gone unheeded. I make the request again because taxpayers who are financing these flights are entitled at least to know who the Prime Minister carts around the country with him.

As I have said, I have been able to pick up three occasions on which Mr Eggleton has been a passenger. Those occasions were during the election campaign. The Government is very much opposed to the proposals put forward by the Labor Party that candidates ought to be financed by the taxpayer according to the number of votes the party receives. Government members violently object to this proposal but they are not adverse to carting their own people around on VIP aircraft at the taxpayer's expense. They are not consistent. I put forward another proposal: Either these people do not go or the Government extends that facility to the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Labor Party. If they want to take some of the executive officers of the Labor Party with them when electioneering they ought to be able to do so, as the Prime Minister does.

When the VIP manifest was tabled last year I think I picked up that some members of the Prime Minister's own party travelled with him. On this occasion I was able to pick up the occasion on which Mr Katter, the honourable member for Kennedy, travelled from Canberra to Mt Isa and Senator Kilgariff and Mr Calder travelled from Canberra to Mt Isa and to Darwin. It may well be that there was no commercial flight on that day and that they were able to get back to their electorates very quickly. But my colleague, Senator Robertson, may have had to wait some days to get back to Darwin.

TALK.START.PARA: —He stayed in Canberra.

—He had to stay in Canberra. That was on 19 September when the election campaign was just starting to gear up. One of those members I mentioned was not a candidate but no doubt he was pretty active in campaigning for Mr Tambling during the election campaign. So those members were able to get back quickly to Darwin by means of a VIP aircraft. As the sitting Labor Party senator, Senator Robertson, has pointed out by way of interjection, 'he had to stay in Canberra.' In my view, this is most unfair. I hope that the Government will take cognisance of what I have said today. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION BILL 1981RACIAL DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original Human Rights Commission Bill introduced in 1979 was described at the time by all, except the Government's most blindly loyal supporters, as being weak, empty, superficial and dangerous. It has not improved since that time and the Opposition despairs that it ever will improve. In the language of the Women's Electoral Lobby in a recently issued statement, what is needed from a Human Rights Commission is something in the nature of a washing machine to clean up the nation's dirty linen. What we have, in contrast, is a not very efficient refrigerator doing no more than freezing at their present, not very extensive level, such limited rights as Australians already have and not doing anything to significantly improve the situation. The Opposition believes that this Bill should be withdrawn, rethought and redrafted. Copies of the Opposition's amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time have or should have been circulated. It makes clear what the Opposition believes the deficiencies of the Bill to be. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide for-
(A) its application to the laws and practices of the States and the Northern Territory;
(B) the full application, without the reservations and declarations embodied in Australia's ratification, of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights;
(C) the specific adoption in judicially enforceable form (along the lines of the 1973 Human Rights Bill) of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights;

(D) the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to investigate and report upon possible breaches of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (which includes guarantees of the rights to form and join trade unions, social security, an adequate standard of living, work, physical and mental health, education and to take part in cultural life);
(E) the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to enforce the rights contained in the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women;
(F) the expansion of the powers and functions of the Commission to give it a more effective enforcement role, especially in relation to civil and political rights; and

(G) in relation to racial discrimination matters, the retention of the independent status and functions, and especially the power to report directly to Parliament, of the Commissioner for Community Relations'.

The 1981 Bill is, in all its essentials, the same as the Bill which Parliament spent so many days-18 in all-debating in 1979 and early 1980. There are one or two minor amendments of some utility. They are to require members of the Commission to disclose pecuniary interests, presumably an acknowledgment to the Bowen Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public and Private Interest, and to remove one basis for the Commission's refusing to exercise its jurisdiction, namely an applicant's lack of sufficient concern or interest in the proceedings. I have no doubt that Senator Missen and perhaps one or two other honourable senators on the other side of the chamber will make much of these sorts of changes in order to preserve something of their self-respect when, as it appears likely, they will not cross the floor in support of either this amendment or any of the potential Committee stage amendments that occupied our attention the last time around.

It is clear that, apart from the matters of this kind which are, as I say, of some utility, no basic concessions have been made to any of the fundamental objections to the previous Bill which have been expressed both on this side of the chamber and within the Government's own ranks, namely, its failure to extend to the States; its failure to create judicially enforceable rights of any kind; its failure to give the Commission any effective teeth; and its destruction of the status and independence of the Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Grassby.

The only significant difference between the old Bill and the new lies in that group of provisions which extend the jurisdiction of the Commission to possible breaches of rights declared by the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child and the Declarations on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded and the Rights of the Disabled, all of which are designed to defuse the abortion issue which ground this Parliament and indeed this Bill to a halt last year.

It must be said, although I say it to some extent with bated breath, that it seems this particular result-the defusing of the abortion issue-has been rather neatly and effectively secured by these new provisions. In the original Bill, of course, the focus was solely on the terms of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. No specific reference in the text of the Bill itself was made to the rights of the unborn or anything that could be construed as having relevance to the abortion issue. It was, of course, the intention of the Simon amendment, so-called, to build into the text of the Bill itself a reference to the rights of the child before as well as after birth. The text of the present Bill again contains no explicit provision with respect to the position of the unborn. But it does, as I say, extend in its operation to the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. The text of that Declaration is set out in the Schedule to the Bill, and there is one provision in the preamble of that Declaration in the following terms:
Whereas the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth.
That is language which seems, on the face of it, to give each side some ice on which to slide.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the preamble.

—It is in the preamble. I will make that point clear in a moment, Senator. It gives each side the possibility of claiming something of a minor victory and that, after all, is the essence of a successful compromise. The anti-abortion lobby has some language to refer to relating to the protection of the unborn. On the other hand, those who, like me, think that abortion is none of the law's business and certainly none of the Human Rights Commission's business can console themselves with the thought that the language in question is almost completely meaningless and, to the extent that it does have any meaning, occurs only in the preamble, and does not create any substantive right. To the extent that it might be thought of as referring to the existence of some substantive right, it can be regarded as merely consistent with a familiar aspect of present Australian law, namely, that there is some legal protection for the rights of the unborn, quite apart from the abortion context, to the extent that a person who as a foetus was injured, for example, in a car accident, can after birth sue in respect of that pre-natal injury. As a result of considerations of that kind, it seems that neither side has any ground on which to get unduly upset as to either the presence or absence of what, to that side, are offensive provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one side effect of this extension of the jurisdiction of the Commission to the rights of children, the rights of the mentally retarded and the rights of the disabled. That is that we now have an extension of the Commission's function away from dealing purely with what might be regarded as the traditional civil and political rights-namely, freedom of speech, Press, assembly and association; the rights of people in relation to the operation of police power and the criminal process; rights to privacy; and rights not to be discriminated against-to what might be described as essentially social, economic and cultural rights. Those are the rights to education, social security, medical care, a decent standard of living and so on. These are the kinds of things which cannot be secured just by governmental goodwill or by a stroke of the legislative pen. Rather, if these sorts of rights are to be secured, that can be done only by some significant mobilisation of community financial resources. As a result, it is not strictly to the point to talk about these sorts of rights being enforced by the Commission, the courts or anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —They may not even be human rights.

—I do not want to get too bogged down in a semantic argument of this kind. I would say that they are human rights, but of a different character from the traditional civil and political rights which can be readily enforced by commissions, courts and means of that kind. These sorts of rights, although they are in another sense quintessentially human rights, are the kinds of things which, as I have said, demand something more than mere good will. They demand mobilisation of resources-a mobilisation which in the case of many Third World countries, with all the good will in the world, simply cannot be applied. In respect of these sorts of non-traditional civil and political rights a commission is limited essentially to the world of investigation, report, research, education and publicity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that, given this extension which is clearly now envisaged for the Commission's basic activity away from the traditional civil and political rights towards the social, economic and cultural rights, there is at least one additional category of jurisdiction which the Commission now might usefully be given. After all, it is certainly arguable that it will have little else that is useful to do. That suggestion is that the Commission be given the power to investigate and report on breaches of the really big document in the social, economic and cultural rights area. I refer to the 1966 International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights which Australia signed on 18 December 1972 and which was ratified by this Government on 10 December 1975. As paragraph (D) of the amendment states, this document:

. . . includes guarantees of the rights to form and join trade unions, social security, an adequate standard of living, work, physical and mental health, education and to take part in cultural life . . .

The importance of these kinds of rights in the depressed conditions in which Australians currently find themselves can hardly be overstated. In compliance with Australia's obligations under this particular Covenant we have already reported at least twice to my knowledge to the appropriate United Nations body, submitting very substantial documents claiming a degree of conformity to the obligations contained in that Covenant. These documents amount to what can really only be described as voluminous apologias in which about the only positive achievements recorded are those that are left-overs from the Whitlam Government. I refer to community health services, aid to disadvantaged schools, the family law legislation and children's service programs of various kinds.

The sections on Aborigines in Australia's report to the United Nations on its conformity with the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights makes very dispiriting and unpersuasive reading, especially in the light of reports which appear from time to time-the most recent one, from the New South Wales Aboriginal Lands Trust, appeared yesterday-about the deplorable conditions in which Aborigines, not in the Northern Territory or somewhere in the outback but in north-western New South Wales, are now living. Also, it might be noted in passing that the section on juvenile offenders in Australia's 1980 report to the United Nations does not sit very easily with the announcement, again recorded in yesterday's Press, that the New South Wales Government is planning legislation involving up to three days' solitary confinement for young offenders committing so-called misconduct while in corrective institutions.

I simply make the point that there is undoubtedly plenty to do in this area of human rights and under the specific obligations created by that Covenant. Given that the Commission is the kind of Commission that it is under this legislation-without real teeth-and given that its jurisdiction has already been extended by this new Bill into the area of the rights of the physically and mentally disabled and the rights of children, it seems to the Opposition to be appropriate to take the extra step of giving the Commission a jurisdiction over this area as well. That is the substance of paragraph (D) of the Opposition's amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. It is a suggestion to which we would hope to receive a very serious response from the Government.

Another significant specific extension of the Commission's jurisdiction which the Opposition, and indeed at least half the nation as well, would welcome, is the inclusion of the 1979 United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, a convention which was signed by Australia in July 1980 but which has not yet been ratified. Paragraph (E) of the Opposition's amendment is the one which specifically refers to this matter. I leave it to my colleague, Senator Ryan, who will speak later in this debate, to indicate what the effective enforcement by the Commission of the rights in this area would mean. She will also spell out, I hope, the Opposition's intention, especially if the Government should reject this amendment, to proceed later in the life of this Parliament with a private member's Bill on the subject of sexual discrimination and equal opportunity. However, all that being said, the heart and soul of this Bill remains the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It is in respect of the crucially important rights in this area that there is still a disturbing litany of weaknesses in the Government's position. The first, most obvious and most notorious of those weaknesses is that described in paragraph (A) of the Opposition's amendment-that is, its failure to apply to the States and to the Northern Territory.

It is obvious that while, as I will mention later, the Commonwealth Government itself is no slouch in infringing rights, the really large scale problems in this area are, have been and always will be in the area of the States. However, I will leave it to some of my later speaking colleagues to describe with the loving care and attention that they will undoubtedly give it, for example, the condition of political democracy in Queensland -in the Parliament, in the electoral system and in the ban on street marches, which still exists as a legislative proscription. I will leave it to my colleagues to talk about the incidence of racial discrimination which still exists in this country and which is particularly alive and well in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. I will leave it to them to speak on abuses of police power which are alive and well and amply documented in relation to Queensland in the Lucas committee report, in relation to Victoria in the Beach committee report and in relation to Western Australia, New South Wales and elsewhere in the country in the proceedings of numerous judicial hearings. I will leave it to others to talk about the condition of privacy which is very much at risk in every State and Territory in Australia except, in this instance, in New South Wales with its excellent privacy committee machinery which has been so successful in tracking down, identifying and resolving problems in this area. I will leave it to others, too, to talk about the condition of sexual equality which is very much at risk despite, in some instances, the existence of legislation right around Australia.

The problem of the application of this Bill to the States remains the most obvious single weakness in the whole Bill. Until it is remedied by the Commonwealth's adventurously using the constitutional power which I and the Opposition believe and always have believed is available to it under section 51 (xxix), the external affairs power, measures like this Bill will never be anything more than feeble, whimpering, half measures in the human rights arena.

A less obvious but equally spectacular weakness is that described in paragraph (B) of the Opposition's amendment. The problem here is this: When Australia finally got around to ratifying the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on 31 August last year after the debate on this Bill in its first incarnation had been concluded, Australia did not do so on the kind of basis which has proved good enough for every other one of the 66 nations which have ratified the Bill. That is to say, it was not good enough for Australia to make, at most, a handful of reservations and declarations-in some instances for other countries there had been no reservations or declarations at all-about the application of the Covenant to Australia. What we did when we ratified the Bill was to do so with reservations or declarations of a significant kind limiting the extent of our enthusiasm for the rights in question. We did this in respect of 14 separate articles out of the 53 in the treaty itself. We refused to accept at all the application of the Covenant to the States-not a position which has been adopted by any other one of the federal nations which have so far ratified the covenant. We refused to accept the application of the one-vote one-value principle to our electoral boundaries. We refused to accept the principle of non-discrimination in the content of the law as distinct from the way in which it is applied. We refused to accept unqualified rights of privacy and we declared that our protection of the rights of free speech, assembly and association was already such throughout the country that 'the right is reserved not to introduce any further legislative provision on this matter'.

We had the hide to object to 14 separate articles. The only country to make more objections than us was the United Kingdom, with one more objection, making it 15. Most of those objections, when closely scrutinised, had to do with a concern about the parent country, the United Kingdom, not interfering with local laws and customs in what was left currently of its previously far flung empire. Thus, for example, the existence of some rather exotic marriage practices in the Solomon Islands was thought to be potentially offensive to a provision of the Covenant; so, in respect of that one of the 15 declarations or reservations to which I referred was made. But, in this respect, the United Kingdom, still being an imperial power, albeit a pretty tiny one these days, was in a special position not shared by Australia. Australia's 14 reservations are to be compared with an average number of reservations for all the other 65 countries put together of three per country overall. If one excludes, as it may be proper to do, the non-western European countries, one finds that in the case of the western European countries the average is six overall. That might be a more legitimate ground of comparison given that those countries tend to be more honest in acknowledging the rights that in practice they will not observe. So, even by that standard, even by drawing those kinds of lines and looking only at exactly comparable countries, we find that more than twice as many declarations and reservations have been made by us.

I regard that and the Opposition regards that as a matter not for any kind of pride at all in that we have finally ratified the document, but of national shame that we should have done so in such a shoddy fashion. Indeed, the Government, it appears, was only too happy to keep hidden the terms of that ratification, shoddy document that it is. It certainly was not overtly trumpeted. The terms of it became known to me only in answer to a parliamentary question on notice, the answer to which was given in early December last year. But we find that it is not the original list of rights as everyone expected and which was the case the last time round in this Bill that the Commission is being required to have regard to, to investigate and to report upon. The rights which are now within the Commission's jurisdiction are the shoddy, emasculated, residual list of rights-what is left over after those reservations and declarations, those 14 exceptions, have been taken out. It is just what is left over. It is not the full and original list. This represents a very significant limitation on the role of the Commission, one which has tended to go utterly unnoticed but one which will not go unnoticed so far as the Opposition is concerned.

The Government's behaviour in this respect, in ratifying the Covenant on this emasculated and limited basis, is entirely consistent with its whole record and performance in the human rights area. I have been critical, in passing, of the role of the States in these respects but it is even easier to be critical of the human rights record of the Fraser Government itself. One has only to think that the Government which is now bringing us the Human Rights Commission Bill is, after all, the Government which brought us the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation allowing effectively unrestricted spying on Australian citizens, which seems now to be the case with the endorsement, at least, of Mr Justice Wilson even if it was not obvious before that. It is the Government which brought us the creation of the new Australian Federal Police Force without simultaneous safeguards on the exercise of that police power in the nature of a detailed criminal investigation code. It is the Government which has brought the nation atomic energy legislation containing unprecedented penalties for citizens dissenting against uranium mining and processing. It is the Government which has brought us new narcotics legislation with alarming, unprecedented and insufficiently restricted new powers in the police and the courts. It is the Government which has brought us, as we all know, a mass of new industrial legislation of a savagery quite unprecedented in Australian industrial relations history. It is the Government which mounted, albeit in a bumbling and ineffectual way, a major exercise in the suppression of its conduct of the Defence papers case. It is a government which has been guilty not only of positive misdeeds but also of infringing human rights through omissions and inactivities. Particularly conspicuous in this respect has been the Government's failure-the now notorious failure-to use its constitutional power to protect the Aboriginal people of Noonkanbah from the deprivations of the Western Australian Liberal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all have our failings.

—We all have our failings, Senator, but I fear some of us have more than others. The other weaknesses of the Bill, and there are many, can be dealt with, honourable senators may be delighted to know, a little more briefly because they have been the subject of considerable previous attention in both Houses. I am referring to the subject matter of paragraph (C) of the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. In that paragraph the complaint is made that this Bill does not create judicially enforceable rights; rights, that is, which will not only be the subject of investigation and report by the proposed new Commission but also will actually stand up in court; rights which will mean something when weighed against legislative enactments which infringe human rights, when weighed against executive or police behaviour which infringes human rights or attempts to bypass them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not appropriate that there should be judicial enforceability of all classes of human rights. I have already indicated in respect of social, economic and cultural rights that I do not think any reference to judicial enforcement makes any sense at all. But it is certainly appropriate for the full range of civil and political rights which are the essence of this Bill. That has been the Opposition's position all along. I summarise by saying that we believe that the proper approach here is to redraft the Bill in substantive form along the lines of the ill-fated 1973 Human Rights Commission Bill which was not proceeded with because of the opposition to it in this chamber.

Paragraph (F) of the amendment makes it clear that the Opposition believes that the Commission needs-again in the context of civil and political rights, where its role should be to do more than simply investigate and report-further powers, including more extensive powers of evidence gathering, more extensive conciliatory powers and powers to initiate litigation when particularly recalcitrant cases are involved. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) acknowledged, in his second reading speech that this might be the next step in the development of the Commission, but the point is that the condition of liberty in Australia demands something more here and now than the limp, toothless, pussy-cat Commission which is before us in this Bill.

Finally, I refer to paragraph (G) of the Opposition's amendment. Perhaps the most dangerous feature of the Bill is involved here. I refer to its emasculation of the independent status and functions of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Whatever the Government may say about the continuation of the formal powers under the Racial Discrimination Act, about their preservation in the structure of the new Commission-the Attorney-General makes these points in his second reading speech-the reality is that the existing Commissioner, Mr Grassby, is not to be made a member of the Human Rights Commission in the sense of being a full status commissioner. He will not retain the power to report independently to Parliament, as he has done so vigorously and effectively over the last five years. He will lose to the new Commission as a whole the power of deployment and detailed control of the staff resources notionally under his wing. These matters were debated at great length last year and in 1979 when the then Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill was debated and passed. I do not propose to repeat those arguments here in any detail. However, this point gives me an opportunity to state our attitude with respect to the other measure which is being debated cognately-the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1981.

This Bill is, on the face of it, a small technical measure which merely changes a reference in last year's Racial Discrimination Amendment Act from the Human Rights Commission Act 1980 to the Human Rights Commission Act 1981. On the face of it, that is not the sort of thing anyone is likely to want to make a fuss about. But the reality is that because the racial discrimination amendment legislation and the legislation creating the new Human Rights Commission are so closely inter-related and involve as they do, the integration of the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations into the Human Rights Commission, because that integration cannot proceed and will remain inoperative unless and until this small machinery measure is passed today and because the Opposition does not now, any more than it previously did, accept the basis on which that amalgamation is proceeding, it is our intention to oppose the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1981 outright, as we did with its predecessor last year.

The Fraser Government is fond of posturing internationally on the human rights stage. Because it is thought to be to our diplomatic advantage to do so, we have been profoundly statesmanlike in talking about human rights abuses in southern Africa, some Middle Eastern states and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Equally, when it has been thought to be advantageous diplomatically, economically or militarily to ignore human rights abuses, we have resolutely turned a Nelsonian blind eye as a nation to those abuses, never more obviously than in the case of the Philippines and Indonesia and to a lesser extent in the case of Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and South Korea. The same applies to the legislation before us today. The only reason Australia is enacting this legislation, the only reason that this Government is bringing it forward, is that the Fraser Government thinks that by doing so, by being seen to be implementing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, we will be able to cut a better, more genuine, figure on the international stage. In the process we are hypocritically ignoring the real abuses which do exist in the Australian human rights scene, nowhere more obviously than in the States of this nation. In doing so we are showing, I fear, just how accurate was, for example, the statement on 26 January 1981 of the President of the Queensland Young Liberals, Mr George Brandis, who was reported as saying of the Fraser Government:
The Federal Government has got to get serious about its commitment to human rights . . .
Over the last five years there's been a lot of talk about the rights of the individual, and sadly little achievement.

I endorse those remarks that come from deep within the bosom of the party. The passage of this Bill, unamended as I fear it is likely to be at the conclusion of the second reading debate, will continue that unhappy tradition to which the President of the Young Liberals has referred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is almost relieved to have heard Senator Evans's speech delivered in the way that it was, on the basis that on the last two occasions Senator Evans rose to discuss matters coming within the jurisdiction of the Attorney-General-that is, earlier today on the guidelines for the provision of financial assistance relating to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and prior to that on the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill-he opened his remarks by saying that he would like to take the opportunity to compliment the Attorney-General for the progress that had been made. If that had occurred three times in a row my colleague, the Attorney-General probably would have started wondering whether something had gone wrong with the whole process of law reform for which he has been responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to repeat the full range of criticisms which I made of this legislation when it was debated in 1979 and the analysis of it which I made on 8 November 1979, other than to say in relation to the criticisms that I have made about the non-application of this legislation to laws of the States that that is a position which I still hold and a position to which I will say something later in my remarks today.

It will be remembered in recalling the history of this piece of legislation that it foundered on the disagreement which developed between the Senate and the House of Representatives on the so-called Simon amendment. The Human Rights Commission Bill 1981 has come forward as a compromise proposal between those who thought that it was necessary to write into the legislation specific references to the rights of the child which other people interpreted as an attempt to write into human rights legislation some binding anti-abortion point of view and those who believe that it is unnecessary to make any reference to that particular subject within the terms of the Human Rights Commission Bill. The compromise that effectively has been reached has been to include within the Bill Schedule 2, which refers to the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child, and, to pick up several other points of criticisms that were made, Schedule 3, which refers to the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, and Schedule 4, which relates to the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled.

I accept that as a perfectly fair and proper way in which to go about reconciling different points of view which exist in the Australian community. It is a perfectly fair and proper way to seek a balance between those whose opinions on human rights and the definition of the term 'human rights' differ markedly. As far as the Declaration of the Rights of the Child is concerned, the Declaration per se is one which I have always supported and have always thought was a perfectly proper declaration and I have no problem accepting its terms and indeed its spirit. The fact that I do not interpret all of the words in the declaration as meaning precisely the same as other people does not detract from my point of view.

The second thing I say about that declaration is that I believe it is important, whenever possible, to give some sort of domestic legislative effect to all of the international convenants to which Australia has become party. If we become party to international convenants or to United Nations convenants and declarations-whether they be the principal one with which this Bill is concerned or whether they concern the rights of the child, the rights of the mentally handicapped, the rights of the disabled or indeed international obligations under the Antarctic treaty or whatever it happens to be-I am in favour of giving them some form of domestic legislative basis. I think that this is something which has been accomplished by this Bill and is another reason why I support the proposal now before us. I next turn to the reservations made by Australia in the ratification process and, in particular, to the reservations which relate to Article 50. Honourable senators will recall that Article 50 states:
The provisions of the present Covenant shall extend to all parts of federal States without any limitations or exceptions.
In the ratification process the Australian Government declared as follows:

Australia advises that, the people having united as one people in a Federal Commonwealth under the Crown, it has a federal constitutional system. It accepts that the provisions of the Covenant extend to all parts of Australia as a federal State without any limitations or exceptions. It enters a general reservation that Article 2, paragraphs 2 and 3 and article 50 shall be given effect consistently with and subject to the provisions in Article 2, paragraph 2.

Under Article 2, paragraph 2, steps to adopt measures necessary to give effect to the rights recognised in the Covenant are to be taken in accordance with each State Party's Constitutional processes which, in the case of Australia, are the processes of a federation in which legislative, executive and judicial powers to give effect to the rights recognised in the Covenant are distributed among the federal (Commonwealth) authorities and the authorities of the constituent States.

In particular, in relation to the Australian States the implementation of those provisions of the covenant over whose subject matter the federal authorities exercise legislative, executive and judicial jurisdiction will be a matter for those authorities; and the implementation of those provisions of the Covenant over whose subject matter the authorities of the constituent States exercise legislative, executive and judicial jurisdiction will be a matter for those authorities; and where a provision has both federal and State aspects, its implementation will accordingly be a matter for the respective constitutionally appropriate authorities (for the purpose of implementation, the Northern Territory will be regarded as a constituent State).

To this end, the Australian Government has been in consultation with the responsible State and Territory Ministers with the object of developing co-operative arrangements to co-ordinate and facilitate the implementation of the Covenant.

Whilst that might be a fair enough statement of executive judicial and legislative divisions of power within Australia, it seems to me, nevertheless, to shirk somewhat the responsibilities which one would have thought a national government would assume in terms of its relationship between itself as a national government and other national governments throughout the world. As I said on the last occasion when I was speaking on this piece of legislation, regardless of the catalogue of woes which Senator Evans would want to lay before the Parliament, the essential assaults on the civil and political liberties of Australian citizens are those assaults which occur as a result of State legislation.

It is State legislation-whether it be street march legislation, the right to tamper with mails, the right to intercept the mail of people in mental hospitals, or the disgraceful State mental health Acts around Australia-which is clearly the primary example of the way in which the citizen has his civil and political rights infringed upon. This criticism has been made, I think, quite forcefully in a recent statement put out by the International Commission of Jurists which has sought to make two points. The first point that it makes is that it believes, as I have said, that the assaults on the rights of the citizens which take place under State law should in fact be overridden by the Australian Government making use of the powers which it has under the foreign affairs head of power of the Constitution and through the operation of the Human Rights Commission. It also goes on to make a point to the effect that it believes, for a number of reasons which we will come to in a moment, that the way in which Australia has made its reservations are themselves contrary to law and, in particular, contrary to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. Another point I wish to observe at this stage is made by way of criticism by the International Commission of Jurists. In its statement it reported:

We are critical of this reservation . . . It may, we believe, be regarded by other nations as 'fundamentally inconsistent with the object and purpose of the Covenant' so as to be legally void. Other nations may also decide to object to the reservations.

The statement then goes on to quote Mr John Dowd, a Liberal member of the New South Wales State Parliament who is also the president of the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists. It states:
Mr Dowd pointed out that such other federal states as Canada, West Germany and India felt no need to attach a similar reservation when they ratified the Covenant.

I think that to a large extent, in terms of the protection of civil and political rights, one might be in a position to discount the views of the Indian Government from time to time. But I think the fact that comparable federal nations such as Canada and West Germany have not found it necessary to enter this federal reservation is a point which ought to be borne in mind and indeed a point which I think is legitimately criticising the attitude which the Australian Government has taken. The body of the International Commission of Jurists report goes on to state as follows:

Therefore, in view of the fact that the subject matter of the Covenant concerns matters largely within State jurisdiction, implementation of the Covenant is and will remain in the hands of parties other than the party responsible for signing and ratifying the treaty. The only action that the Australian government will take is to consult with those states . . .

There is no undertaking implicit in this statement, which is simply concerned with administrative methods of communication. Nor does it affect the basic premise that in many areas implementation of the Covenant will be the responsibility of the States and that any co-operative arrangements will be made within this framework.
Indeed, the Federal Attorney-General, Senator Durack, when announcing ratification on the 5th August 1980, stated as follows:

Although they (the States) can't do so as a matter of international law, they are assuming and agreeing to the principles of the Covenant with the reservations that we are making. It is essentially up to those states and the Northern Territory . . . to exercise those responsibilities under the Covenant, insofar as it applies to their own laws and practices under them.

I interpolate to say that it is one thing for a State or for a Territory authority to say, with all due pious regard to the Commonwealth or to the Commonwealth Attorney-General, 'Yes, we give you our undertaking that we will observe the terms of the international covenant', when in fact we know full well that Governments such as those of Western Australia and Queensland have no intention whatsoever of abiding by some of the civil and political rights which are laid down as being appropriate in this international covenant. The International Commissioner of Jurists makes a point which I mention in this debate in the hope that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) might be able to reply to it. I do so as a person who is not a lawyer but who accepts that a criticism is being made by the ICJ that I would like to have included in the record. If, in fact, the criticism is wrong, I would appreciate being advised in due course by the Attorney-General that the criticism is ill-founded. The criticism by the ICJ is based on its belief that the reservation made by the Australian Government is contrary to article 19 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties-and I quote:
. . . which preclude reservations which are incompatible with the object and purpose of the Treaty.

Furthermore, if the reservation in effect amounts to a failure to perform the essence of the Covenant, then it may be argued that it is a breach of Article 27 of the Vienna Convention on the law of treaties which states that
'A party may not evoke the provisions of its internal law as a justification for its failure to perform a treaty'.
Article 19 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties reads:
A State may, when signing, ratifying, accepting, approving or acceding to a treaty, formulate a reservation unless:
(a) the reservation is prohibited by the treaty;
(b) the treaty provides that only specified reservations, which do not include the reservation in question, may be made; or
(c) in cases not falling under sub-paragraphs (a) and (b), the reservation is incompatible with the object and purpose of the treaty.

I would value the Attorney-General's comment as to whether the criticism is legitimate. It is not that the ICJ alone makes the criticism. Mr James Crawford, senior lecturer in law at the University of Adelaide, makes precisely the same point regarding Article 19 of the Vienna Convention in a paper he has written. The paper states:
Even if Art. 50-
That is referring to the principal covenant-

is not interpreted to prohibit a federal reservation, similar considerations tend to show that such a reservation is contrary to the object and purpose of the covenant (including Art. 50). Such a reservation, in Australia's case, would exclude most of the important rights in the Covenant from the scope of direct federal responsibility, and would thus emasculate their force for Australia. Further, grave problems of reciprocity would arise. A unitary State would be in a fundamentally unequal position vis-a-vis Australia, since it would have no reserved State domain of its own to rely on. A federal State would need to determine whether the principle of reciprocity of reservations applied to its own reserved domain, or to the range of matters within the Australian State domain (as interpreted from time to time). It is not clear which would apply.
Then a most interesting point is made, particularly in relation to Article 50. Mr Crawford states:

A strong argument can thus be made for the invalidity of a ratification accompanied by a federal reservation. Even if this argument failed, or most States did not in practice object, it would be open to any present or future State party to object on its own behalf and to exclude its participation in the Covenant vis-a-vis Australia. It is not difficult to imagine the Soviet Union-there is an interesting point-(which sponsored Art. 50) making such an objection, in which case Australia would have no standing to challenge the Soviet Union's violations of the Covenant.
