Even if there was no such objection, Australia would be limited to protesting those Soviet violations within its central legislative authority (since the Soviet Union is itself formally a federation).

It seems then that a federal reservation could well be invalid, and even if it was not, would substantially dilute Australia's position and standing under the Covenant. It would thus tend to defeat the foreign policy purposes which impel Australian ratification in the first place.

I would like to hear the Attorney-General's comment on this. It has been remarked about places such as West Germany and Canada that no other federal states have made such reservations. Indeed, when looking at the operation of other international covenants, it is interesting to note specifically what section 64 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms states. It reads as follows:

1. Any State may, when signing this Convention or when depositing its instrument of ratification, make a reservation in respect of any particular provision of the Convention to the extent that any law then in force in its territory is not in conformity with the provision. Reservations of a general character shall not be permitted under this Article.
2. Any reservation made under this Article shall contain a brief statement of the law concerned.

Despite that, European nations have managed without those sorts of reservations to enter into an effective ratification of the European Convention. They have established international judicial machinery under it. Even states like Great Britain have been quite happy, despite its historical tradition of separateness from Europe, to allow the European Court to pronounce on questions of civil and political rights in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. I also want to make the point that I regret the Australian Government has decided not to lodge a declaration under Article 41 of the Covenant. Such a declaration would allow the Human Rights Committee to receive and consider complaints made by one national government against another. Canada, New Zealand and a number of western European nations have made such declarations. Twenty-two nations have also ratified the optional national protocol to the Covenant whereby individuals may send petitions to the Human Rights Commission. Australia has not done so. I also ask the Attorney-General whether it is proposed at some future date to make a declaration under Article 41. If this is not proposed, why is this so? What is the current thinking behind the Government's decision not to lodge such a declaration?

I wish to make only one or two other brief points. The first is that perhaps if one does a little digging, one might find a little gold. A point is raised in the Bill-I make no more of it than to put it on the record-in respect of the functions of the Commission. Under the heading 'Functions of the Commission', clause 9(1)(c) states:

. . . on its own initiative or when requested by the Minister, to report to the Minister as to the laws that should be made by the Parliament, or action that should be taken by the Commonwealth on matters relating to human rights.

I pose the question that if the Commission on its own initiative thinks that the Commonwealth should make laws regarding the position of, for example, Aborigines in the Northern Territory or Western Australia, does it have the right to come to the Commonwealth Parliament and the Attorney-General and make those recommendations? In other words, does the clause operate, in fact, to allow a little more scope than one otherwise would have thought?
I am glad to see the removal of what was clause 10 (4) (f) in the previous legislation. In the 1979 Bill clause 10 (4) (f), in relation to complaints, stated:
The Commission may, in its discretion, decide not to hold an inquiry as a result of a complaint if-(f) the complainant does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint.

By the time the Senate had finished with the clause it read 'the subject matter of the complaint is not of sufficient concern to the complainant'. The Bill, in its third form, removes that restriction all together. I am glad to see that. I am sure that my colleague Senator Missen, who was instrumental in making that original change and pushing for its deletion would be pleased. I think that the amendment to the Bill in fact strengthens it. Having said how much I worry about the reservation made to clause 50, I want to say that there are three other reservations which I am very glad to see placed in the Bill. I am very glad to see the reservation regarding Articles 2 and 26 which is cast in such a way that it allows the Commonwealth to make laws specifically for the advantage of Aboriginal people. We say in the reservation:

The provisions of Articles 2 (1) and 24 (1), 25 and 26 relating to discrimination and distinction between persons shall be without prejudice to laws designed to achieve for the members of some class or classes of persons equal enjoyment of the rights defined in the Covenant. Australia accepts Article 26 on the basis that the object of the provision is to confirm the right of each person to equal treatment in the application of the law.

I think it right that we make that reservation so that our own laws which positively discriminate in favour of classes of people do not themselves come within the scope of critical comment. I am even more delighted by our reservation to article 19, which reads:

Australia interprets paragraph 2 of article 19 as being compatible with the regulation of radio and television broadcasting in the public interest with the object of providing the best possible broadcasting services to the Australian people.

The felicitous inclusion of the phrase 'in the public interest' is one to which attention will be drawn time and again, I suspect, should any attempt be made to weaken the term 'public interest' as it appears in broadcasting and television legislation, which may be the subject, I understand, of some future concern to this Parliament. Having made the point in our own reservation that we are prepared to regulate broadcasting and television in the public interest, we will see the public interest become a central figure of debate elsewhere.

I make only one passing comment on the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill. When the original Bill was last before the Senate, I was one of those Government senators who voted against the third reading. I still regret that our numbers were one short. Had we had one more, the numbers would have been equal and that Bill would not have succeeded. I do not resile from the views I had at that stage about the position of the Commissioner for Community Relations. I do not know whether I follow and accept the point put forward by Senator Evans, that is, that failure to pass this Bill at this time to change the references from the 1980 legislation into references to the 1981 legislation in fact has the effect that he claims. Therefore, I cannot see that the point he makes about dividing and opposing the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill, which, as I said, only changes the date from 1980 to 1981, is a matter of substance in the way in which he put it.

I conclude by saying that I am one of those who is prepared to make progress slowly. To get something on the books which can be useful, which at a later stage may be the subject of expansion and the powers of which can be tested and to get a commission into operation and a piece of legislation in place, no matter how imperfect one thinks it may be, are an important first step. Therefore, I am glad to be able to support the passage of this legislation through the Senate. If the comments made on both sides of the chamber about the significance of using Commonwealth power to attain civil and political rights for all Australians, regardless of where they live, come forward once again and the States, despite the assurances given by the Attorney-General, do not play ball in terms of providing those civil and political rights for their citizens, I hope that as time progresses we can look to an expansion of the functions of the body which we will shortly be establishing, and, I hope, the Commission will have a great deal of success, a great deal of public support, a great deal of parliamentary support and a significant role to play within the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Evans to the motion for the second reading. I do so, I might say, with a very profound sense of deja vu and, I hope, not apathy. Certainly one feels that we have been through this series of arguments many times. Therefore, in the interests of expediting the passage of this legislation, which I believe to be extremely important, I do not intend to dwell on matters already covered by Senators Evans and Puplick. Suffice to say that I maintain, as does the Opposition, that the reach of the Commission in its being restricted to the Australian Capital Territory and matters arising under Federal laws, in the fact that none of the rights to be the concern of the Commission are judicially enforceable and in the fact that many reservations were given by the Australian Government when it adopted the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to my mind impair the efficacy of what we are doing. However, I believe the Bill ought to be passed into law as soon as possible in order that we may move from the limbo in which the Australian Government's response to the clear needs of the Australian people is at the moment.
—Are you not seconding an amendment that the Bill should be withdrawn?

—Yes, but I am assuming what will come to pass on Tuesday, if not today. I am anxious that this legislation, even in the truncated form that no doubt it will take, should pass into law as quickly as possible in order that we may move from the limbo in which Mr Peter Bailey and his staff are placed at the moment into a situation in which the Commission has the full status of being established by the will of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I confine my remarks on the Bill to the extension of the jurisdiction of the Commission to enable it to deal with a new series of declarations. In other words, rather than being confined to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the human rights to which the Commission may have reference are extended to include, amongst others, those rights which are recognised by such declarations as the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons. I think that this is a very significant and important advance in this legislation.

The Senate will recall that in September 1979 I introduced for debate a motion concerning the International Year of the Child. In that debate I said, amongst other things, that it was important that this Parliament, along with all the other Australian parliaments, took practical, concrete and effective steps to ensure that the child, the most vulnerable and defenceless person in the community, was given adequate protection, whether that protection be given by way of criminal law involving penal statutes, civil statute law enabling a child-or someone on its behalf-to sue for damages when some harm is done to it or by an encouragement of the common law in its growth in the protection of the child. I pointed out that in the preamble to the international Declaration of the Rights of the Child these words occurred:
Whereas the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth.

I pointed out then, as I repeat now, that in many instances our present legal system is deficient in ensuring that protection-not only in respect of the child after birth. I outlined some of the cases of child abuse, sexual abuse, including incest, and so on which we know occur in the community and which could detrimentally affect a young child. I also pointed out that our legal system inadequately dealt with the protection or securing of the rights of children who were born, for example, physically or mentally defective as a result of suffering some injury within the womb. For example, there is no national legislation and no accumulation of State legislation adequate to deal with a recurrence of the thalidomide incident. Honourable senators will recall that children were harmed in the United Kingdom, in this country and in many other countries as a result of their mothers taking a drug-I think it was a sedative-which had been inadequately or negligently tested and put on the market by the pharmaceutical company concerned. Certain damages were secured for the children as a result of a series of legal and political manoeuvres, but all the settlements, as I recall, were out of court and there was no actual testing in the legal sense of the right of the child to recover damages for an injury suffered whilst within the womb.

We know that some of the common law jurisdictions are moving in a way which enables a child or someone acting on behalf of a child to recover damages when a child within the womb is injured as a result of a car accident in which somebody else has driven negligently or in a blameworthy manner and injured the child, the child being found on birth to be defective as a result of the injuries. Much more difficult questions arise as to what should be the position, what should be society's response, when a pregnant mother negligently drives a vehicle and it is involved in an accident as a result of which the child within the womb suffers an injury. Then there is the case of a mother who deliberately defies medical advice and continues, while carrying the child in the womb, to take excessive alcohol or drugs of some form or misuses medication which impairs the physical or mental well-being of the child and that becomes apparent after birth. There are many instances of situations in which our community is inadequately responding to the need to provide legal safeguards for the child before as well as after birth. I hope that with those brief comments I have indicated that the matter goes well beyond the question of abortion which has occupied so much of the time of this chamber.

I believe that what is attempted in this Bill is a correct response to the preamble to the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. I believe that Senator Evans may have made a comment which suggested that because the part of the preamble from which I have quoted is merely a preamble no human right is conferred. Of course, in speaking of the need to secure special protection for the child and the need to erect legal safeguards, it is recognised there that there is an obligation in the national community to provide those safeguards. Where one has an obligation one has a corresponding right. I think it is fallacious to argue that when in the Preamble an obligation is clearly cast on the national community corresponding rights are not also created in the child who, as I have said, is vulnerable and defenceless before as well as after birth. The merit of this legislation as opposed, for example, to the Simon and Martyr amendments which were moved on previous occasions, is that there is no 'too close' definition such as would be appropriate if we were dealing with a criminal statute. In that situation, in order to maintain our own integrity and to ensure that the community knew exactly what was being made subject to penalty, one would need to go into all sorts of arguments about conception and so on.

In this legislation we are dealing in a very proper manner with the matter of giving to the Commission a very general mandate, among other things, to inquire into and report upon when occasion arises the adequacy or inadequacy of acts or practices within the Federal sphere which impinge upon the rights of children whether before or after birth. It seems to me that this is entirely in harmony with the suggestions that Senator Lewis and I were making during debates on previous occasions. I believe that in this legislation we have the opportunity of which Senator Chaney spoke in his remarks on the legislation on a previous occasion. We have an opportunity to enhance the quality of debate surrounding the protection of the child. Until now it has not really been a feature of the discussion within the Australian community. It has been conducted in an atmosphere of emotion and, as I have suggested, has concentrated somewhat too narrowly on abortion. One needs to be sensitive to a far wider range of issues.

I believe that a commission which is composed of persons of integrity and of commitment to the notion that the Australian family as a whole needs to recognise that within it there are those who cannot speak for themselves and those who are defenceless and vulnerable-for example, children-will make available to this Parliament reports which will then enable us to take the proper political responsibility of ensuring that adequate legal safeguards are brought into operation within the Australian Capital Territory-within the sphere of Federal laws in the first instance-but then perhaps using them as models at the very least for State jurisdictions to adopt in order to secure human rights in this area I am speaking of, particularly for the vulnerable and defenceless children within our community.

Despite the defects which I have mentioned and which are such that I have to vote for the amendment which has been moved by Senator Evans, the features of the Bill which are new will, in my mind, so enhance the work of the Commission that we ought to try to expedite the passage of the legislation so that we will see the Commission in operation as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, I think, in a unique position in this debate because I am the only member of the Senate who voted against the passage of legislation of this nature when it was last considered by the Senate. I voted against it because I was aware of the Government's desire to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and I thought that the Human Rights Commission Bill was quite inadequate. I thought that if it were rejected by the Parliament the Government, still wishing to ratify the covenant, would be forced to bring in a more effective Human Rights Commission Bill. In that, somewhat to my surprise, I turned out to be completely wrong. The Government ratified the Covenant without the passage of the Human Rights Commission Bill. I found that surprising.

SPEECH.PARA: Except on the matter of abortion, to which I will come in a moment, the Bill now before the Senate is essentially the same as the one debated previously. My objections, of course, remain. Those objections were firstly, the lack of any effective or any enforcement power at all given to the Human Rights Commission; secondly, the power given to the Minister to by-pass the Commission and give its power to the States; and, thirdly, the use of conclusive ministerial certificates given by the Attorney-General to prevent disclosure of documents in certain listed areas such as would prejudice security, defence and international relations or permit the revelation of communications between a Minister and a Minister of a State, Cabinet documents and so on. I do not object to their not being disclosed. But I do object, as I did when I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, to the Minister's decision being conclusive and not being examinable by any body such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That provision remains in the Bill now before us. Most of all, my concern was that the scope of the Bill does not cover State laws under which most potential infringements of civil and political liberties must fall. It seemed to me then and it seems to me now that what we are doing is not in accordance with the Covenant to which we are adhering. Article 50 of the Covenant states:
The provisions of the present Covenant shall extend to all parts of federal States without any limitations or exceptions.
Paragraph 2 of Article 2 of the Covenant states:

. . . each State Party to the present Covenant undertakes to take the necessary steps, in accordance with its constitutional processes and with the provisions of the present Covenant, to adopt such legislative or other measures as may be necessary to give effect to the rights recognised in the present Covenant.

There is an attempt to do this in this present Bill under clause 11 by providing for the making of co-operative arrangements with the States. I agree that there is something to be said for this approach as a first step. Surely we should be able to co-operate effectively in this matter of human rights. After all, as has been pointed out by Mr Justice Kirby, despite the great differences of history, culture and language, European countries have been able to produce a European convention on human rights. The Council of Europe has produced more than 100 conventions on such diverse subjects as extradition, the legal status of migrant workers, transplantation laws and the suppression of terrorism. Can we accept, in our federal system, that we can achieve less than a formerly disunited Europe? I do not think so. It must be admitted that the present approach in this Bill is rather timid. Even if the joint Commonwealth-State organisations are set up they will not necessarily deal with the civil and political rights of State laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —They may bypass the Commission, though.

—Yes, but they may deal with the laws if the States want them to. It must be admitted that the States have agreed to the ratification of the Covenant. That is fine. But what happens if the States do not perform effectively in this area? For how long is it reasonable or proper for us, as the Federal Parliament and as part of the organisation which has ratified this Covenant, to accept it? For how long will this failure be compatible with our responsibility under the Covenant to take the necessary steps to give effect to the rights recognised in the Covenant in all parts of the Federation without any limitations or exceptions? Because, despite what we said in our reservations, we do have the power to override the States to make these rights effective. We must not hold ourselves out to the international community as being powerless in this respect. We may not choose to use the power but we certainly have it if we want to use it.
—What, under the foreign affairs power?

—Yes, under the foreign affairs power without a doubt. We may not choose to use it, but we must not pretend that we do not have it. In this fundamental respect though, I do think that the present Bill goes as far as is politically feasible at the moment. But that is not the end of the matter. The history of this type of co-operative approach is not very encouraging. There have been successes, but not many. As a State senator I am an ardent defender of the decentralisation of power, when this is appropriate, for good administration or for political freedom. But when a State is abusing civil or political rights or is refusing to have examined whether it is abusing civil or political rights, I believe that this Parliament has a right and a duty to act. When the Bill was considered by the Senate last time, I asked for an assurance from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that if after a reasonable period, say three years, it was obvious that the co-operative arrangements were not working, would he be prepared to use the power that this Parliament has under the foreign affairs power to make these rights effective. As a member of the international community in good standing, to use the Attorney's own words, I do not see how we could do less. But I received no such assurance. Therefore, I voted against the Bill when it was considered last by the Senate.
—It is a five-year clause.

—Yes, it is a five-year clause under the so-called sunset legislation, but that is a very long time for considering this matter. I do not think we should, in ratifying the Covenant, have to wait for five years before the Parliament can consider again whether the workings of it are satisfactory. I do not think that is an acceptable time span. What has happened, of course, is that, in August last year, the Covenant was ratified. I am afraid that rather torpedoed the approach I took that if we did not pass the Bill the Government would be forced to bring in a better one. It ratified it without being able to get from Parliament a Human Rights Commission Bill. It ratified it with important reservations. These have been mentioned by previous speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: I will concentrate on one aspect. We have purported to attach a general reservation to the effect that constitutional processes of Australia preclude implementation by the Federal Government of those provisions of the Covenant affecting matters over which the States have jurisdiction. I do not think that is true. I think we have the power if we choose to use it. I accept that we do not choose to use it at the moment. I do not think it is correct to say that we do not have the power. Incidentally it is important to note that other countries with federations, such as Canada and West Germany, have not thought it necessary to place such a reservation in their covenant. In the Attorney-General's statement about ratification he stated:
Although they--
He was referring to the States-
can't do so as a matter of international law, they are assuming and agreeing to the principles of the Covenant with the reservations we are making.

It is essentially up to those States and the Northern Territory to exercise those responsibilities under the Covenant, insofar as it applies to their own laws and practice under them. In effect, while accepting our obligations to extend the rights of the Covenant throughout Australia, we have, at the same time, asserted that our responsibility for implementation of those rights is limited to those matters where we exercise jurisdiction as the Federal Government. In my view-I am fortified in this view by a report by the International Commission of Jurists-this may well be in breach of international custom. In fact, as the International Commission of Jurists pointed out, this may well be in specific breach of Article 27 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties which states:
A party may not invoke the provisions of its internal law as a justification for its failure to perform a treaty.

Like Senator Puplick I would be very grateful if the Attorney, in his response, could deal in detail with his attitude to that provision in the Vienna Convention. I hope that the Government will keep in mind, when watching the development of the Human Rights Commission's activities and of the performance of the States in this field, the provisions of the Vienna Convention.

I turn now to the matter which bedevilled us and which, in fact, we were unable to resolve-the so-called abortion issue, which was raised because of an amendment to the previous legislation which was passed by the House of Representatives. I think Senator Evans summed this up very fairly when he pointed out how it was being defused by including, as schedules to the Bill now before the Senate, not only the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, but also the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons. I am sure we all remember that those amendments, which I believed were ill-considered, stalled the progress of this Bill when we considered it before. As I construed the Human Rights Commission Bill which we dealt with before, it did not prevent the Human Rights Commission, at its discretion, from considering the rights of unborn children and of the mother and of the father.

I was worried-I opposed the amendment for this reason-that the amendments were not really intended to give or would not have the effect of giving the Human Rights Commission this power which it did not need as it already had it but were designed to use the Human Rights Commission as a propaganda forum for a particular point of view on one issue of human rights. For that reason, at the time I opposed the amendments. I am satisfied now that the subtle changes introduced by the Attorney-General have, in fact, achieved a satisfactory compromise. It will be possible, as I believe it always was, for the Human Rights Commission to look at these important issues of the rights of the unborn child but not to have its proceedings totally disrupted by being used as a propaganda forum for a point of view on one aspect of human rights. For that reason I applaud what the Attorney has done in this field. I now support the passage of this Bill. I do not believe it is a good Bill but it is better than nothing. Although, in my view, it is a weak and timid Bill, it is the best we can get at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment so ably moved by my colleague, Senator Gareth Evans, to the Human Rights Commission Bill. I wish to make some remarks particularly concerning paragraphs (E) and (G) of the amendment which the Opposition has moved. We are engaged in a very disappointing episode in this chamber this afternoon. After the lengthy debate in both chambers over a number of months concerning the need for human rights protection in this country, we have finally been presented by the Government with legislation for a commission which will do nothing to enforce human rights and very little indeed to monitor some of the worst abuses of human rights in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no longer a matter of dispute that there are serious violations of human rights of many kinds in Australia. I say that recognising that in relative terms Australia is one of the more progressive and humane societies in which one can live. We know that. I notice, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you nod in agreement. Indeed, the trade union movement which you have so ably represented for many years has been one of the reasons why workers in this country and their families have a higher standard of freedom than exists in many other countries in the world. But we are not content to rest on our laurels. We must admit that among certain disadvantaged groups, in particular the Australian Aboriginals, there are gross and continual violations of human rights. As I said, it is profoundly disappointing that now, when legislation in the human rights area finally comes before the Parliament, the Government is not, in fact, bringing in anti-discrimination legislation. We are not setting up a human rights commission with any executive powers to enforce the provisions of the various international conventions referred to in the legislation. We are simply setting up a commission which will be able to monitor, investigate and report upon some violations of human rights in this country but not upon all violations.

We have many criticisms of the present legislation and the more significant ones are embodied in our amendment. Of course, our main criticism is that there is no effective power in the legislation to protect human rights. The Human Rights Commission will subsume the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations and deprive it of its statutory independence and right to report directly to Parliament. I will have more to say about that matter later. The Bill does not apply to the States of Australia and, of course, it is in some States of Australia-notably Western Australia and Queensland-that the most serious violations of human rights concerning Aborigines take place. The Commission's jurisdiction does not extend to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women which was signed by the Government at the Mid-Decade Conference for Women held at Copenhagen in 1980 nor does it extend to the International Convenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. It will provide no monitoring at all of violations of the rights of women in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rot!

—Senator Walters seems to disagree; so no doubt she will support the amendment moved by the Opposition which will make specific reference to the convention concerning discrimination against women. If she is concerned to see women protected she will have no choice other than to support our amendment. Of course, the Labor Government had embodied in the Racial Discrimination Act a section enforcing the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. However, the effectiveness of that Act has been seriously eroded by the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: With the passage of the Human Rights Commission Bill, we will have a body which will make some attempt to monitor provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons. But, as I have said, two very important conventions are ignored. However, one of the two most important inadequacies concerns the effectiveness of the Human Rights Commission with regard to the protection of people who are discriminated against on the grounds of race. Until now, the Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Al Grassby, has been a very effective voice in bringing to the attention of the nation discrimination on the basis of race experienced by people living in Australia. He has been able to report to the Parliament. He has done so regularly and his reports have been very important documents to which the Parliament has had to pay some attention. He will lose this independent right and, of course, in so doing, he will lose his effective voice for all those persons who are discriminated against on the basis of race or ethnic origin.

As an example of the effectiveness of Mr Grassby's work, I will refer to his 1980 report to the Parliament in which he examined discrimination against Aboriginal people in a wide range of areas important to their lives and dignity. He documented discrimination through the legal system, by the police, in the area of employment, in housing, in hotel services, in the media, in health services and in education. In the 1980 report of the Commissioner he also saw fit to devote one entire chapter to racial discrimination by the Western Australian Government and the Queensland Government. On 3 December last year in the Senate I raised the matter of human rights violations by the Queensland and Western Australian governments. These matters, of course, have been raised not only by honourable senators in this place but also by Aboriginal people in various international forums. Indeed, Australia has been reprimanded in reports coming from international organisations for its treatment of Aboriginal people, particularly in the States of Western Australia and Queensland.

Mr Grassby's findings revealed that racial discrimination against Aboriginal people in both States is widespread and, worse than that, it occurs with the compliance of the Queensland and Western Australian governments. In response to inquiries by the Commissioner for Community Relations into a matter of alleged racial discrimination by the Department of Mr Hassell, the West Australian Minister for Police and Traffic and for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell stated:
. . . the government of the State of Western Australia is not a matter over which you have, or ought to have, the slightest jurisdiction.

Mr Hassell went on to tell Mr Grassby that it would be quite fruitless for Mr Grassby to raise such matters as racial discrimination in employment with him again. This was the response of the Western Australian Minister despite the fact that section 6 of the Racial Discrimination Act binds Australia and each State. I think this section of the 1980 report of the Commissioner for Community Relations which refers to Mr Hassell and his response, highlights the fact that when no enforceable powers are provided for the practical application of legislation such as the racial discrimination legislation or, now, the Human Rights Commission legislation, State governments which are hostile to the spirit of that legislation simply refuse to co-operate. On 27 May 1980 the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, wrote to the Commissioner for Community Relations on the matter of complaints he had received from the Western Australian Premier, Sir Charles Court, about a report on racial discrimination at Fitzroy Crossing issued from Mr Grassby's office. Senator Durack stated:
It is a matter of some concern that a document issued out of your office should give rise to criticisms of this nature.

Clearly it is a matter of some concern to the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government is concerned, but what is its concern? Its concern is to avoid any possible embarrassment to its political allies in Western Australia and Queensland. Its concern is not to protect human rights in those States and its concern is certainly to avoid any confrontation with those States when they refuse to act in the spirit of Federal legislation. For these reasons, when we see the human rights commission legislation coming before us with no powers over the States we feel, of course, totally pessimistic about the effectiveness of such legislation.

The concern of the Fraser Government with regard to human rights seems to be much a promotional concern. It seems to be very much confined to the ability of the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, to parade himself in international forums as some sort of champion of human rights. When it comes to the real test of his and his Government's intentions with regard to human rights, when he is put to the test, as in the examples I gave from the Commissioner for Community Relations report, he simply backs down; indeed, the Attorney-General actually chastises the Commissioner for Community Relations for daring to expose the behaviour of one of his political colleagues. Is it any wonder that the Opposition feels very disappointed and very pessimistic with the human rights situation in this country.

I pass briefly to the other area where there is an exclusion of concern for human rigths. This is the area concerning women. Women seem to be the only group identified as disadvantaged who have not been explicitly included through the Convention referring specifically to them in the proposed legislation. There is specific recognition now of racial minorities, children, the disabled, and the mentally handicapped but not of women. Surely we do not need to argue in this palce the need for protection of women against various forms of discrimination.

This very week in this Parliament we have had very large delegations of women who are part of the women's refuge movement in this country. Any honourable senator who took the time to meet with those delegations and to discuss their problems must be, as I was, horrified by the enormous discrimination that many women still experience, by the enormous disadvantages that many women-the sorts of women who end up in women's refuges to seek some sort of temporary shelter-have to experience. One has only to go through the whole area of housing, access to employment, access to legal services, access to accommodation, access to credit to purchase a home, treatment by State housing commissions and so on to find an overwhelming dossier of misery and discrimination. Those are the circumstances facing some women in this country. Yet despite the Government's making such a fuss and attempting to draw unto itself such kudos for signing the Convention in Copenhagen, it seems to find it unnecessary to attach that Convention to the legislation.

I make mention of the media statement put out a couple of days ago by the Women's Electoral Lobby, a body which has been extremely active in the last 10 years in the defence of women and in promoting improvements in the status of women. Of course, the Women's Electoral Lobby actually advocates voting against the Human Rights Commission Bill. It stated:
The Bill as drafted confers no further rights on women, aborigines, other disadvantaged groups, or anyone at all.
A Commission set up under the proposed legislation would be ineffective, inconsequential and would have no teeth.

The Bill has so many exclusions to the obtaining of information by subpoena that it is almost impossible to make a case. If you overcome this hurdle your case can be disallowed as against the public interest. Persons who are subpoenaed can refuse to testify on the grounds of self-incrimination . . . unlike the procedures laid down for Australian Royal Commissions.

There are no real sanctions in the Bill-the commissioner can write a letter to the culprit or table a report in some future Parliamentary session. The Bill does not provide the right of appeal to the judiciary.
I find it necessary to agree with the following conclusion of WEL:
The Bill is window dressing by the Australian Government to fool other nations into believing that Australia is carrying out its obligations under the Convention on Human Rights.

The failure to provide specific reference to the Convention outlawing discrimination against women will mean that there will not be regular and consistent monitoring of the sorts of discriminations I have averted to. I believe that this will mean that there will be even a greater need for Federal anti-discrimination legislation. I wish to make some brief remarks on that matter.

At this stage three States-South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria- have already introduced anti-discrimination legislation and there have been moves towards it in Tasmania. Queensland and Western Australia have evinced no intention at all in this regard, nor has the Northern Territory. Because of the failure of some States and the Northern Territory to take any steps to provide legislation to protect women against discrimination, I assert that the Commonwealth Government ought to enact anti-discrimination legislation. It clearly has the powers to do so in some areas and the outstanding and apparent area in which the Commonwealth Government could enact anti-discrimination legislation is in the area of Commonwealth employment which, of course, is a very large and significant area of employment for women and one in which women experience great difficulty in obtaining equality of opportunity. One has only to look, for example, at the employment practices of the Department of Defence to see how discriminatory the present Commonwealth Government is as an employer.

I believe there are other areas where the Commonwealth Government has constitutional powers. They may have to be tested through the High Court, but I believe they have constitutional powers to outlaw discrimination in finance and banking. Of course, these are extremely crucial areas because so many women are discriminated against by lending institutions in their attempts to secure a home for themselves and their families. The Commonwealth Government clearly has some powers. I think those powers would be extended very readily if it were willing to do so; unfortunately, it is not.

Given the problems in those States which will not legislate to protect women against discrimination, the Federal legislation could take precedence. Federal legislation could cover areas not within State powers but could also apply in those States where there is unlikely to be any State enacted legislation. The objective of that legislation would be to ensure that in areas such as education, training, employment, taxation, the social security system, access to finance and access to the law, people were not discriminated against on the ground of sex alone. Where such discrimination did take place, the law ought to provide the victim with an effective remedy.

I foreshadow, at this point, that I will be moving a private member's Bill after July in this place because I am so concerned at the inaction of the Government in this respect. In the meantime, I urge all honourable senators to look very seriously and carefully at the second reading amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Gareth Evans. In particular, I exhort the Attorney-General to adopt our suggestion that the Copenhagen Convention, the Convention outlawing all forms of discrimination against women, should be appended along with the other United Nations conventions. If the Attorney-General is not willing to do that, I would be very interested indeed, as would all the women of Australia, to hear his explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all women. Just refer to the ones who follow you.

—Senator Walters seems to be unaware that it is the Government of which she is a supporter which signed the Convention and which has expressed its intention to ratify it. I would think it is a matter of concern to all women, whatever their political views. If the Government has signed the Convention, why is it not prepared to attach it to the Human Rights Commission in the way it has attached other international conventions which it has signed? Finally-and I feel more pessimistic about this, given the effectiveness of Mr Grassby and the extent to which his effective work has embarrassed the Government with regard to its colleagues in Western Australia and Queensland-I urge the Senate to vote for our amendment because it will lead to the re-establishing of the independent status and independent powers of reporting to the Parliament of the Commissioner for Community Relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last August, along with 65 other countries, the Government ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. As a result, we are now committed to set up some mechanism to ensure that the Covenant is observed. It has been debated in many places that this is not necessary, that we in this country do not need the sort of legislation that is now before us, that its provisions only overlap other areas, and that Australians have recourse to ombudsmen and common law. This may well be. I do not believe that it will overlap in this area. Clause 10 sub-clause 4 of the Human Rights Commission Bill sets the matter out very clearly. If the Commission believes that some other remedy in relation to the subject matter of the complaint is reasonably available to the complainant or that the subject matter of the complaint could be more effectively or conveniently dealt with by some other statutory authority, the Commission may, in its discretion, decide not to hold an inquiry as a result of a complaint.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed Commission will set up a system of which I believe the ordinary man will be able to take advantage. I refer to the person who would normally shrink at the thought of resorting to legal action, who would not know how to go about it and who would believe that all that would do would be to cost him, and cost him dearly, in dollars. The main feature of clause 12 is that the Commission's emphasis should be on informality in the settling of disputes and that it should not be bound by rules of evidence. This, I believe, is the benefit and the beauty of this Bill. The ordinary person will be able to have a complaint investigated without having the concern and worries of finance or the concern and worries of the legal aspect of what that person believes has been discrimination against him. That clause also enables the Commission to keep a person's name confidential if it believes that this is necessary. The Human Rights Bureau set up by the Government in August as an interim measure has proved that this legislation is necessary. It has already received complaints and requests for information in the general field of human rights. The cost of running this Commission will not be great. We have been assured by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that he expects its annual cost to be $850,000.

Human rights legislation has been debated in this chamber many times. We first debated it on 25 September 1979. It was again debated on 13 November 1979. It was again debated in February, March, April and May of 1980. Senator Evans spoke on it again today. I just made a quick check and ascertained that he has already spoken for a total of three hours and 24 minutes on this legislation; yet he was able to speak for another 34 minutes in the debate today. That is not something that I aim to achieve. I believe that we have debated this Bill very thoroughly. As has been stated today, the subject of the disagreement between the two Houses was the rights of the child. The debate became an abortion debate. I agree that in the end it was a debate on abortion. I believe that the Government has come to a very happy decision. I commend it for that. It has been able to put to all those people who were involved in that disagreement a compromise or, as Senator Hamer says, a subtle difference. I am not sure what the subtle difference is-perhaps he can explain it to me later-but I for one am very happy with the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —A compromise by some other name.
—Perhaps it is a rose by another name.
—It is spelt h-a-p-p-y.

—Yes, I am very happy. The charter has been extended to include declarations on the rights of the child, the rights of the mentally retarded and the rights of the disabled. Rather than read those declarations, I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DECLARATION OF THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD
Proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 20 November 1959 (resolution 1386 (XIV))
PREAMBLE

Whereas the peoples of the United Nations have, in the Charter, reaffirmed their faith in fundamental human rights and in the dignity and worth of the human person, and have determined to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom,

Whereas the United Nations has, in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, proclaimed that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status,
Whereas the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth,

Whereas the need for such special safeguards has been stated in the Geneva Declaration of the Rights of the Child of 1924, and recognized in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and in the statutes of specialized agencies and international organizations concerned with the welfare of children,
Whereas mankind owes to the child the best it has to give,
Now therefore,
The General Assembly

Proclaims this Declaration of the Rights of the Child to the end that he may have a happy childhood and enjoy for his own good and for the good of society the rights and freedoms herein set forth, and calls upon parents, upon men and women as individuals, and upon voluntary organizations, local authorities and national Governments to recognize these rights and strive for their observance by legislative and other measures progressively taken in accordance with the following principles:
Principle 1

The child shall enjoy all the rights set forth in this Declaration. Every child, without any exception whatsoever, shall be entitled to these rights, without distinction or discrimination on account of race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status, whether of himself or of his family.
Principle 2

The child shall enjoy special protection, and shall be given opportunities and facilities, by law and by other means, to enable him to develop physically, mentally, morally, spiritually and socially in a healthy and normal manner and in conditions of freedom and dignity. In the enactment of laws for this purpose, the best interests of the child shall be the paramount consideration.
Principle 3
The child shall be entitled from his birth to a name and a nationality.
Principle 4

The child shall enjoy the benefits of social security. He shall be entitled to grow and develop in health; to this end, special care and protection shall be provided both to him and to his mother, including adequate prenatal and post-natal care. The child shall have the right to adequate nutrition, housing, recreation and medical services.
Principle 5
The child who is physically, mentally or socially handicapped shall be given the special treatment, education and care required by his particular condition.
Principle 6

The child, for the full and harmonious development of his personality, needs love and understanding. He shall, wherever possible, grow up in the care and under the responsibility of his parents, and, in any case, in an atmosphere of affection and of moral and material security; a child of tender years shall not, save in exceptional circumstances, be separated from his mother. Society and the public authorities shall have the duty to extend particular care to children without a family and to those without adequate means of support. Payment of State and other assistance towards the maintenance of children of large families is desirable.
Principle 7

The child is entitled to receive education, which shall be free and compulsory, at least in the elementary stages, he shall be given an education which will promote his general culture and enable him, on the basis of equal opportunity, to develop his abilities, his individual judgment, and his sense of moral and social responsibility, and to become a useful member of society.
The best interests of the child shall be the guiding principle of those responsible for his education and guidance; that responsibility lies in the first place with his parents.

The child shall have full opportunity for play and recreation, which should be directed to the same purposes as education; society and the public authorities shall endeavour to promote enjoyment of this right.
Principle 8
The child shall in all circumstances be among the first to receive protection and relief.
Principle 9
The child shall be protected against all forms of neglect, cruelty and exploitation. He shall not be the subject of traffic, in any form.

The child shall not be admitted to employment before an appropriate minimum age; he shall in no case be caused or permitted to engage in any occupation or employment which would prejudice his health or education, or interfere with his physical, mental or moral development.
Principle 10

The child shall be protected from practices which may foster racial, religious and any other form of discrimination. He shall be brought up in a spirit of understanding, tolerance, friendship among peoples, peace and universal brotherhood, and in full consciousness that his energy and talents should be devoted to the service of his fellow men.
DECLARATION ON THE RIGHTS OF MENTALLY RETARDED PERSONS
Proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 20 December 1971 (resolution 2856 (XXVI))
The General Assembly

Mindful of the pledge of the States Members of the United Nations under the Charter to take joint and separate action in co-operation with the Organization to promote higher standards of living, full employment and conditions of economic and social progress and development.
Reaffirming faith in human rights and fundamental freedoms and in the principles of peace, of the dignity and worth of the human person and of social justice proclaimed in the Charter.

Recalling the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenants on Human Rights, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child and the standards already set for social progress in the constitutions, conventions, recommendations and resolutions of the International Labour Organisation, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children's Fund and other organizations concerned.

Emphasizing that the Declaration on Social Progress and Development has proclaimed the necessity of protecting the rights and assuring the welfare and rehabilitation of the physically and mentally disadvantaged,
Bearing in mind the necessity of assisting mentally retarded persons to develop their abilities in various fields of activities and of promoting their integration as far as possible in normal life.
Aware that certain countries, at their present stage of development, can devote only limited efforts to this end.

Proclaims this Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons and calls for national and international action to ensure that it will be used as a common basis and frame of reference for the protection of these rights:
1. The mentally retarded person has, to the maximum degree of feasibility, the same rights as other human beings.

2. The mentally retarded person has a right to proper medical care and physical therapy and to such education, training, rehabilitation and guidance as will enable him to develop his ability and maximum potential.

3. The mentally retarded person has a right to economic security and to a decent standard of living. He has a right to perform productive work or to engage in any other meaningful occupation to the fullest possible extent of his capabilities.

4. Whenever possible, the mentally retarded person should live with his own family or with foster parents and participate in different forms of community life. The family with which he lives should receive assistance. If care in an institution becomes necessary, it should be provided in surroundings and other circumstances as close as possible to those of normal life.
5. The mentally retarded person has a right to a qualified guardian when this is required to protect his personal well-being and interests.

6. The mentally retarded person has a right to protection from exploitation, abuse and degrading treatment. If prosecuted for any offence, he shall have a right to due process of law with full recognition being given to his degree of mental responsibility.

7. Whenever mentally retarded persons are unable, because of the severity of their handicap, to exercise all their rights in a meaningful way or it should become necessary to restrict or deny some or all of these rights, the procedure used for that restriction or denial of rights must contain proper legal safeguards against every form of abuse. This procedure must be based on an evaluation of the social capability of the mentally retarded person by qualified experts and must be subject to periodic review and to the right of appeal to higher authorities.
DECLARATION ON THE RIGHTS OF DISABLED PERSONS
Proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 9 December 1975 (resolution 3447 (XXX))
The General Assembly

Mindful of the pledge made by Member States, under the Charter of the United Nations; to take joint and separate action in co-operation with the Organization to promote higher standards of living, full employment and conditions of economic and social progress and development.
Reaffirming its faith in human rights and fundamental freedoms and in the principles of peace, of the dignity and worth of the human person and of social justice proclaimed in the Charter.

Recalling the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenants on Human Rights, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child and the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons, as well as the standards already set for social progress in the constitutions, conventions, recommendations and resolutions of the International Labour Organisation, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children's Fund and other organizations concerned.
Recalling also Economic and Social Council resolution 1921 (LVIII) of 6 May 1975 on the prevention of disability and the rehabilitation of disabled persons,

Emphasizing that the Declaration on Social Progress and Development has proclaimed the necessity of protecting the rights and assuring the welfare and rehabilitation of the physically and mentally disadvantaged,

Bearing in mind the necessity of preventing physical and mental disabilities and of assisting disabled persons to develop their abilities in the most varied fields of activities and of promoting their integration as far as possible in normal life.
Aware that certain countries, at their present stage of development, can devote only limited efforts to this end,

Proclaims this Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons and calls for national and international action to ensure that it will be used as a common basis and frame of reference for the protection of these rights:

1. The term ''disabled person'' means any person unable to ensure by himself or herself, wholly or partly, the necessities of a normal individual and/or social life, as a result of a deficiency, either congenital or not, in his or her physical or mental capabilities.

2. Disabled persons shall enjoy all the rights set forth in this Declaration. These rights shall be granted to all disabled persons without any exception whatsoever and without distinction or discrimination on the basis of race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinions, national or social origin, state of wealth, birth or any other situation applying either to the disabled person himself or herself or to his or her family.

3. Disabled persons have the inherent right to respect for their human dignity. Disabled persons, whatever the origin, nature and seriousness of their handicaps and disabilities, have the same fundamental rights as their fellow-citizens of the same age, which implies first and foremost the right to enjoy a decent life, as normal and full as possible.

4. Disabled persons have the same civil and political rights as other human beings; paragraph 7 of the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons applies to any possible limitation or suppression of those rights for mentally disabled persons.
5. Disabled persons are entitled to the measures designed to enable them to become as self-reliant as possible.

6. Disabled persons have the right to medical, psychological and functional treatment, including prosthetic and orthetic appliances, to medical and social rehabilitation, education, vocational training and rehabilitation aid, counselling, placement services and other services which will enable them to develop their capabilities and skills to the maximum and will hasten the process of their social integration or reintegration.

7. Disabled persons have the right to economic and social security and to a decent level of living. They have the right, according to their capabilities, to secure and retain employment or to engage in a useful, productive and remunerative occupation and to joint trade unions.
8. Disabled persons are entitled to have their special needs taken into consideration at all stages of economic and social planning.

9. Disabled persons have the right to live with their families or with foster parents and to participate in all social, creative or recreational activities. No disabled person shall be subjected, as far as his or her residence is concerned, to differential treatment other than that required by his or her condition or by the improvement which he or she may derive therefrom. If the stay of a disabled person in a specialized establishment is indispensable, the environment and living conditions therein shall be as close as possible to those of the normal life of a person of his or her age.
10. Disabled persons shall be protected against all exploitation, all regulations and all treatment of a discriminatory, abusive or degrading nature.

11. Disabled persons shall be able to avail themselves of qualified legal aid when such aid proves indispensible for the protection of their persons and property. If judicial proceedings are instituted against them, the legal procedure applied shall take their physical and mental condition fully into account.
12. Organizations of disabled persons may be usefully consulted in all matters regarding the rights of disabled persons.
13. Disabled persons, their families and communities shall be fully informed, by all appropriate means, of the rights contained in this Declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, in a very peculiar fashion, has been able, to his own satisfaction anyway, to decide that the Declaration of the Rights of the Child can be divided in two-the first part being the Preamble. I am not quite sure of the second part but it is the rest of the Declaration. He has said that the Preamble does not matter anyway; it is just the rest, whatever the rest happens to be, that matters. However, in the document I have had incorporated in Hansard, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child as proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 20 November 1959, resolution 1386, includes the Preamble. I feel that Senator Evans is backing a rather weak old horse if he is trying to exclude the Preamble from that Declaration.
—As distinct from a strong old horse.

—He is not a very old horse. Maybe he has a lot to learn. He is not, of course, trying to exclude any of the parts of the declarations relating to the mentally retarded or the disabled. I wonder why? It is something I find difficult to understand.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I heard Senator Ryan say that women are not human, that they need to be treated as a separate entity, that they do not come under the human rights provisions, that they should have some special convention of their own included in this human rights legislation. She can speak for herself. I believe that I am human. I believe that, under this Bill, I am perfectly equal to my male colleagues in the Senate and have an equal right to go to the Commission and lay any complaint that I feel I am justified in making. If Senator Ryan does not believe that she falls in that category, that is her problem. She spoke about the disadvantages faced by the women who are part of a convention that is in Canberra at the moment and who sat in Kings Hall yesterday. I do not know how many honourable senators saw them. Certainly, they would not speak to any of my male colleagues. They would not even speak to any male reporters. We had Richard Carleton out there trying to get one of the female reporters to talk to them because they would not speak to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean when you say that you had Richard Carleton out there?
—He was out in Kings Hall. He was wondering what it was all about.
—You had him out there?
—No, I did not have him there.
—In Kings Hall?

—In Kings Hall. If they behaved like that, perhaps they are not human. I do not know. Senator Ryan has tried to convince us today that women need a special mention. I disagree with that proposition. We are not a minority group. As a matter of fact, we are a majority group. I believe that we could well have an equal number of complaints to put before the Commission as any other group would have. I believe that Australia is one of the countries in which human rights for all, perhaps with the exception of the unborn, are considered to be the normal way of life. This Bill sets an example in identifying to all the countries of the world the priority that we place on freedom for all human beings. Because of that, I support the Bill before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Missen for yielding to me. My comments will be very brief. I understand that it would help the Government if this Human Rights Commission Bill were passed. I, along with other honourable senators, spoke at length on a similar Bill on 13 November 1979. The Bill before us today is essentially similar to that one, with a few amendments. It pleases me less than the original Bill. I want that put on the record. I complained on behalf of the Australian Democrats that the original Bill was weak and lacked teeth and did not apply to the States. I said that it did not contain a Bill of Rights and many other matters. I am sorry to say that this Bill is even weaker than that one. For that reason the Democrats will support the amendment moved by the Opposition to the motion for the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: On the last occasion I congratulated Senator Evans and Senator Missen on their speeches. On this occasion I congratulate Senator Evans and agree essentially with most of what he said. Had I spoken after Senator Missen, I am sure that I would be congratulating him similarly on his thoughtful contribution. The Democrats are firm in their support of the thrust of the various amendments that the Australian Labor Party has put forward. In particular, we believe that the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for its application to the laws and practices of the States and of the Northern Territory. Surely it is in those areas that 95 per cent of breaches of human rights take place. Some States, notably Queensland and Western Australia, are more notorious than others for allowing the violation of civil rights.

We are very apprehensive that this Bill, with its companion Bill, will destroy or emasculate the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations. I do not hold any brief for anyone now in that organisation, but the Australian Democrats believe that it has performed a valuable service and is capable of exposing racial discrimination in Australia. I repeat what I said on 13 November on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We strongly oppose the emasculation of this organisation and its virtual destruction. I could go on for some time, and I have notes and a speech prepared to do just that. However, as it would be essentially a repetition of what I said on 13 November I will just say for the record that the Australian Democrats are deeply disappointed that the Government has not made the amendments suggested by Senator Evans, Senator Missen, Senator Puplick, me and many other speakers during the debate in November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak yet again on the Human Rights Commission Bill and the additional amending Bill, the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill. The discussion on these Bills has been a long saga, dating from November 1979. On that occasion I made a lengthy speech in which I was highly critical of the Bills and of the extent to which we were proceeding to implement the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I did not think the Bill was adequate then, and I do not think it is adequate now. I have at all times been pledged to the implementation of the policy of the Liberal Party, put forward at elections, to proceed with the establishment of a commission which investigates breaches of rights, which investigates laws and 'acts and practices' and which proceeds to report to the Parliament. I was not happy, and I am still not at all happy, about the deficiencies in this Bill. I will refer to them in a moment, and they have been referred to already today. It is a Liberal commitment to implement the policy in this way and not by means of a bill of rights. We pledged in the 1977 election and again in the last election to proceed with this type of legislation. Consequently, my decisions on these matters are hedged around by the commitment I believe we have.

SPEECH.PARA: I have come to the same conclusion as did Senator Tate today; that is, this Bill should be passed into law as soon as possible. We should expedite the passage of the Bill, and I will attempt to do that by not supporting the amendment moved by the Australian Labor Party, many aspects of which are highly commendable but which I believe would have the effect of ensuring that we did not get a Human Rights Commission in this country for some considerable time. We endeavoured in debates more than a year ago to amend the legislation. In fact, with the additional amendment in this Bill today, I think that some six of the 12 amendments I moved on that occasion have now been incorporated in the Bill by the Government. The major matters we sought to incorporate into the legislation then we recognise have not been successfully incorporated.

The changes that have now been made in the Bill are such that they will overcome some of the problems and certainly some of the controversy which has surrounded this legislation. We have discussed the terms of the Bill reasonably and relevantly in this chamber, I think, but on two occasions debate in the House of Representatives has been devoted almost entirely to a battle on the subject of abortion. The amendments moved in that House concentrated entirely on that aspect of the Bill. They lifted part of a preamble from one of the declarations that is now in the Bill and proceeded to highlight that and to require the Human Rights Commission to concentrate on that activity. I and others fought against that proposal, and we are glad to see that so far it has not been persisted with. As others have pointed out, the Government has incorporated some three declarations in this Bill. While I listened to Senator Walters I thought that perhaps we might also have an extra declaration, the declaration of the rights of the sexual minority, namely, men. However, we have not gone that far. Senator Ryan has also pointed out that the covenant relating to the elimination of discrimination against women is not amongst the declarations included. Like her, I hope that speedy action will be taken to include that covenant.

The three declarations included in the Bill-the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons, and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons-have been supported by this country. We have voted for them and we applaud their inclusion. I certainly have no objection to those declarations being included as documents to be looked at by the Human Rights Commission. I probably do not accept the same interpretation of those documents as some of my colleagues do, but I believe that they are worthwhile documents, worthy of consideration in the deliberations of the Commission. From that point of view, we could have no possible objection to the action the Government has taken in including them in the documents to go before the Commission. There was always power in the Bill for the Government to incorporate further documents, or international instruments, as they are called. That would require a process of agreement by the States but I hope that the other documents referred to today will also be included by way of that process.

A great deal has been said today about the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the way in which we have done this, with a record number of reservations. There are 14 reservations in all, and I think that some of those reservations are of great importance. The reservation under Articles 2 and 50 relating to our position as a Federal state, refusing to include responsibility in regard to the laws of the States, is very serious and one which I regret very much. A number of reservations have been strongly criticised by the International Commission of Jurists, and I believe validly criticised. I will not repeat the criticism made by my colleagues Senator Puplick and Senator Hamer, who have mentioned aspects of this reservation. I agree with their points, but I wish to mention further aspects. We have not made the declaration which would allow interstate complaints, that is, complaints between various states of the world, to be made and dealt with. We have not made the declaration that would enable that to be done. What is more, we have failed to ratify the Optional Protocol to the covenant under which individuals may appeal to the Human Rights Commission. I do not know why we have not done that. As a country with a pretty good record on human rights, I believe that we ought not to have such poverty of spirit that we will not allow individuals to take their complaints against our country to the human rights machinery of the United Nations. Ratification is important because under the terms of this Bill the Commission is to consider the covenant in the light of what is ratified by Australia. Our failure to ratify the optional protocol restricts the ambit of the activities of the Commission. I believe that the particular restrictions under Articles 2 and 50 of the Federal clause are such that this matter is very serious. I will quote another aspect of the commentary on the ratification of the International Commission of Jurists. It reads:
The general reservation covering this gap is considered to be not just insufficient but at best voidable if not void abinitio rendering the ratification itself null and void.

Senator Puplick at more length has discussed the way in which this may conflict and probably does, with Article 27 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. I suggest that grave doubt exists as to whether our ratification is a valid one. Certainly it is one in which we will be very much criticised by councils of the world because I think we have not taken full steps to implement this Covenant. I believe that in the ratification there is a great deal of deficiency regarding our activities.

The other matters of change in the Bill now before us which I think are of some interest include one which has been mentioned today and which is now excluded, namely clause 10 (4) (f) of the Bill. This provision originally restricted persons who wanted to complain to the Commission against human rights activities. They needed an interest-an expression which has a legal meaning and which would be restrictive. I sought to have this clause removed when the Bill was debated here in 1979. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) then substituted what I thought was a somewhat improved expression of concern but which did not have the same restrictive legal meaning. I am now pleased to see that the Government has taken that clause out altogether, so that means that complaints and complainants need not show an interest. The interest in human rights should be sufficient in itself and we should not impose conditions restricting people from approaching the Commission to get justice.

I refer to another alteration to this Bill which I do not think has been mentioned today and that is that the Commissioners' terms of office are not to exceed five years. That clause is put in to be consistent with the 'sunset' clause. That clause was originally inserted in the Bill on the initiative of my colleague, Senator Lewis. Consistently with that clause a term not exceeding five years is included. In a small way these changes improve the Bill but grave deficiencies still remain. Quite apart from the ratification problems we have the problems of State laws. I am concerned, not that we want to interfere with State laws or force a change and override the States but, as was tried previously-unfortunately, the Government indicated that it would not accept this-I see a need for the Commission to be able to investigate State laws, to compare State law with other State laws and with Commonwealth law, and to be able to criticise those differences.
