In the course of this criticism I say this: It may well be that even with the Bill as it now stands, there is some power in the Commission to investigate some State laws. I do not know whether the Commission will have the courage and initiative to do that. I draw attention to a statement which was made by Mr James Crawford, a lecturer in law at the Adelaide University. In a speech to a convention last year he stated.

As to matters presently governed by State law the only relevant head of jurisdiction is s.9 (1) (c), which refers to 'laws that should be made by the Parliament . . . on matters relating to human rights'. Now it is quite clear that this is not restricted to matters on which the Commonwealth has already legislated, which are covered by s.9 (1) (a). Therefore it must relate to proposed reforms on matters within Commonwealth power but presently governed by State law. It follows that the Commission can investigate, with a view to proposing reforms, any subject matter of State law provided that the Commonwealth can legislate for it. So the question becomes: what is the extent of Commonwealth legislative power over matters covered by the Convention?

It may well be that there will be some room for investigation in areas which at present are covered by State laws but over which the Commonwealth has some power. I hope such powers will be exercised by the Commission. Nonetheless, so far as we are concerned, both in regard to laws and investigation of acts and practices there are very grave restrictions on the area in which the Commission can act. It is unlikely that it will step into any area of State law unless it specifically has that power given to it in the Bill. I think that this will prove to be a deficiency in the Bill and one which after some time will require amendment. There is still no provision for civil remedies. However there is a provision that, after a person has gone through all the trouble of making a complaint and being heard, possibly a report will be made and the report will come to this Parliament, where we may or may not take any action. I think it is a grave deficiency that no civil remedies are provided in this Bill as there are under the Racial Dicrimination Act. In time this will be shown to be a deficiency which needs remedying. There remains the criticisms we made on previous occasions, such as the possibility of by-passing the Commission under clause 11 of the Bill. Likewise, remains the deficiencies-what I call the freedom of information deficiencies-mentioned by Senator Hamer. This includes the conclusive certificates, the ability to keep from the Commission facts and documents which ought to be before it and the secrecy provisions which I hope will be altered when the freedom of information legislation is finally passed through this chamber. These are continuing defects to the possible and useful development of this legislation.

We have heard a number of criticisms of this Bill from the Women's Electoral Lobby. I agree with WEL that a Commission set up under the proposed legislation would be ineffective, inconsequential and without teeth. I hope that the criticisms the Lobby and I have made will prove to be not as great. I do not agree that the exclusion of information is such that we cannot necessarily expect the Commission to do an effective job. I think that the criticism by WEL about disallowing public interest has been misconceived. I think it has misread the clauses in the Bill. Nonetheless the criticisms which it made are very substantial. Apparently the Women's Electoral Lobby overlooked the fact that clause 10 (4) (f) has been removed from the Bill. Nonetheless, I believe that the criticisms made to us by organisations means that we must be even more vigilant in the implementation of this Bill. We will have to watch it very carefully in the next few years.

Of course reference has been made to the second Bill, the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill. This Bill alters only the dates. Last year we had a considerable debate on this Bill. A number of us opposed the Bill and sought to defeat it because it had the effect of taking the Commissioner for Community Relations from his separate position, submerging him into the Commission-it did not make him a commissioner-and very much inhibiting his power of report to the Parliament. That decision was made. A vote was taken in this chamber and the Bill passed in both Houses. It would be pettifogging now to try to hold up this legislation by not voting for an amendment which merely changed the date from '1980' to '1981'. I for one will not do that because I want to see this legislation come into operation. I accept, most regrettably, the racial discrimination aspect of this legislation. I have sought to defeat it, but having failed to do that I do not intend to trivially hold things up at this time. As I have said, many of us are committed to the legislation and are committed to seeing some implementation of the Covenant. When I spoke here on 8 November 1979 I said:

If my amendments are not adopted we will be passing something that will be a weak, sickly Bill. I would rather that that be done as a first step. At least we would learn whether the Bill can be effective. It is even possible that I could be wrong; that the Bill could be better than I now believe it to be. I am an optimist but I would rather see a commission of some weakness set up than nothing at all.

That continues to be my position and my commitment to my constituents. One does not accept that one can always obtain what one wants in the Parliament. I believe that the amendment which the Australian Labor Party has put forward today is very attractive in its way. There is very little in that amendment with which I do not agree. I believe that most of the criticisms advanced against the Bill are sound, but to redraft it and to have it sent back and thrown back again would, I believe-I have reason for this belief-mean that we would not see a commission operating for probably some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably for many years.

—Probably for many years, as Senator Lewis has said. Consequently, one cannot risk that course. It is better to have a commission, restricted and retarded in its powers though it may be, which at least can collect evidence of the elements and the aspects of breaches of human rights in this country. It will be a commission which can highlight these breaches which will turn up-even without the specific power. We know of certain human rights restrictions which we know operate in various dark corners of this country. We know that facts will come forward as the result of the Commission's work. I believe that one cannot take a hole-in-corner attitude. One cannot just throw this Bill back and be sure not to succeed. We must however be more than ever vigilant, and ensure that, in the somewhat slender and weak condition in which this Commission starts, we in the Parliament recognise that we have a continuing obligation to monitor its course. We must see that the reports and examinations by the Commissioner for Community Relations, though he cannot report independently, are coming to light for the public and the Parliament. It is for this reason that I support the Bill as it stands now and hope that it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to repeat what I have said both inside this chamber and outside it concerning the Human Rights Commission Bill and related legislation. We are debating the motion that the Bill be read a second time to which an amendment has been moved by Senator Evans. I state simply why I cannot vote for or against the amendment as it is presently drafted. I find very few problems with paragraphs (A), (E) and (G) of the amendment. So far as paragraphs (B), (C) and (F) are concerned, I believe that, in giving greater emphasis to the rights enshrined in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and by not mentioning the rights enshrined in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, including those rights before and after birth, rights of mentally retarded persons and the rights of disabled persons, there is a fault in the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as paragraph (D) is concerned, I would be very hesitant to provide to the Commission, as established, those rights to form and to join trade unions, as are included in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. I believe that this is a matter which ought properly to be dealt with by implementation of the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. However, I am tempted to vote for Senator Evans' amendment, particularly because of what has been said in respect of paragraph (A)-'Its application to the laws and practices of the States and the Northern Territory'. Much has been said about this legislation in regard to Queensland and Western Australia. However, we do not have a full complement of senators from either Queensland or from Western Australia. I am tempted to vote for the amendment, expecting that it would be carried so that it would in effect result in this legislation being delayed until Tuesday week when, of course, we would have a full complement of senators from Queensland and from Western Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have anybody in particular in mind?
—In the persons of Senator elect Martyr and Senator elect-I am unable to go further into this matter other than to say that for those reasons I cannot support nor would I vote against the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the Senate has obviously supported the new proposals of the Government in regard to this Human Rights Commission Bill to widen its charter to include reference to the declarations of the rights of the child, of the mentally retarded and of the disabled. That is the major new initiative that has been taken by the Government in regard to this measure, and it is one which I trust will now be accepted not only by the Senate but also by the House of Representatives and will enable the Human Rights Commission to be established.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a great disappointment to me that it has taken so long to achieve that purpose. Soon after I became Attorney-General I undertook the task of endeavouring to establish this Commission. My first disappointment was that after very lengthy discussions with the States when there seemed to be some chance of them forming a joint Commonwealth-State human rights commission, that was not possible. Then, of course, when we embarked upon the course of confining the Commission to practices under Commonwealth laws, that attempt was frustrated by a division between the two Houses.

I am very pleased indeed that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber seem to support those new proposals by the Government. It is a disappointment to me, however, that the Opposition has seen fit to move an amendment which in effect, will defeat the Bill because the amendment would not allow the Bill a second reading. The Bill would require redrafting along several lines which the Government has made quite clear that as a matter of policy it will not accede to. Even though there are some members on the government side of the chamber who are disappointed about those matters, I am very pleased that Senator Missen, Senator Puplick and Senator Hamer, who have been critical of some aspects of the Bill, see the wisdom of establishing the Commission.

I think the Parliament has generally underrated the significance of establishing a Human Rights Commission which has very wide powers and it is proposed now even wider powers. Senator Ryan has expressed her criticism, and indeed the Opposition has included in its amendment the view that the powers and the functions of the Commission ought to extend to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. The Government has not included that aspect because that Convention has only recently been signed by Australia. At the moment we are discussing with the States the basis on which that Convention could be ratified. The Act will contain powers by which the charter of the Commission can be extended to include covenants of that kind, and, indeed, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights as well if it seems appropriate at some future time to include them. However, we believe that the Commission should be established at this stage with a charter along the lines which we have delineated to see how it operates in those areas before we move to other fields which in due course may well be added. I do not propose to canvass again all the arguments. Time is running out. I hope we will be able to pass this legislation by this evening because there is some other business to attend to, as I understand it, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner.

I will mention one matter that has figured quite prominently in this debate. It concerns the ratification of the International Covenant by the Government last August. I think the significance of that step taken by the Government has been underrated and too great an emphasis placed on reservations and declarations made at the time. The major reservation has been referred to as the reservation to a Federal system. I think that to some extent, however, that reservation has been misunderstood because it is made quite clear:
Australia accepts that the provisions of the Covenant extend to all parts of Australia as a Federal State without any limitations or exceptions.

We have assumed at the international level the obligation for the Covenant's applying to Australia as a whole. As I have pointed out, this obligation will be implemented at a Federal level by the Commonwealth Parliament and at the State level by the State parliaments. It will be implemented in accordance with our Federal system. The obligation exists as one applying to the whole of Australia. Australia will have to report under Article 40 about the methods by which it is observing its responsibility. That is one of the major reasons why we have established-and the States have agreed to establish-the Ministerial meeting on human rights so that the obligations under the Covenant of both Federal and State governments can be discussed. I hope that, if there are difficulties, they can be solved. I believe that the reservation is consistent with the Vienna Convention mentioned previously. All the advice I have received from public international legal experts and experts from the Foreign Affairs Department leads me to believe that the reservation as such is valid and in accordance with that treaty. Article 27 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties states:
A party may not invoke the provisions of its internal law as justification for its failure to perform a treaty.

That does not deal with the reservation at all but with the observance, application and interpretation of the treaty. We recognise that. It is a fact that we cannot invoke the provisions of an internal law to justify non-performance of the regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what else would you be doing when you report that Queensland has not faced up to its racial laws?

—We would have to report this. As I said, we would have to explain what we are seeking to do in order to conform with the Covenant. The significant point is that as a result of very lengthy discussions with the States over 18 months or more we obtained the agreement of the States to the ratification of this Covenant. Both the Federal and State governments took the responsibilities being assumed under this Covenant very seriously indeed. That is why there are a number of specific reservations where we say we cannot accept certain responsibilities.
—You won't do anything to fix that law up and you are in breach of the Covenant; it is nonsensical.

—We have not assumed an obligation in regard to the specific reservations. Therefore, we have not acquired the obligation to implement them at this stage. I think those points cover the major new matters introduced into this debate. As I said, although I am somewhat disappointed in not having the time to cover some of the major issues again, I have done so in the past as indeed other senators who have spoken in this debate have done. I refer to what I have said in the past in relation to those major issues. I believe that the Parliament is taking a most important step in passing this Bill and in establishing a Human Rights Commission which I believe will prove to be a major initiative by the Government. Mr President, I trust that the Senate will defeat the amendment and give passage to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement on the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate the ministerial statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The purpose of this statement is to provide the Senate with an opportunity of debating our present taxation system and more specifically, to explain in detail the reasons why the Government decided a short while ago not to introduce a broad-based indirect tax. This statement does not announce changes to the tax system or to existing levels of taxation. I hope it will contribute towards a more informed and objective debate on the subject of taxation. Such a debate cannot occur unless the Government plays its part in disclosing its own thinking and makes available essential information. This statement is intended to do that. No economic subject excites quite the level of interest as that of taxation. Few subjects produce such little common ground between different sections of the community. In many ways our existing taxation laws represent an uneasy and not altogether logical compromise between conflicting interests and pressures in the community. It seems on occasions that the only area in which there is broad agreement is that taxation should be reduced.

The taxation system is an integral part of our economic structure. As such, tax changes cannot take place in a vacuum. Taxation, government spending, budget deficits and inflation are all directly connected. Coping with them is part and parcel of the task of running a modern economy. The Government's views on taxation cannot be divorced from its underlying philosopy. We are, and have always been, a Government that believes that individuals should be free to make their own choices and that private enterprise should be given room to play the leading role in the development of the economy. This leads us inevitably to the view that the Government's role should be as small as is consistent with providing the basic environment within which individual freedom and private enterprise can thrive. Unless taxation changes are consistent with and achievable within the existing economic framework they will frustrate, rather than serve, the Government's economic objectives.

The most dominant influence on the level and shape of our taxation system is of course the size of government. Those in the community who espouse the cause of bigger government are in fact arguing for still higher taxation. Unless debate in Australia on the subject of taxation fully acknowledges the direct link between levels of taxation and levels of expenditure that debate can have little meaning. Taxation cannot responsibly be reduced unless the room for those reductions is provided by reductions in government spending. This Government is prepared neither to finance additional expenditure, or reduce taxation, through the inflationary process of expanding the budget deficit.

Whilst opinion as to the desirable shape of our taxation system will vary sharply in the community it is possible, I believe, to state some broad goals. I believe it essential that any taxation system be fair, efficient and, to the maximum extent possible, complement the general economic policies of the Government. In saying that a taxation system should be fair, that immediately implies that it should be fair in the sense that all of those on whom parliament imposes an obligation to pay tax should in fact pay tax. This, of course, leads to the subject of tax avoidance and evasion to which I shall return later in this statement.

The concept of fairness also implies that tax should be levied according to capacity to pay. The extent to which this principle should apply must in turn be tempered by the recognition that if marginal tax rates become too high, adverse effects on incentives occur with consequent loss of economic efficiency and productivity and greater resort to tax avoidance. The criterion of efficiency requires that not only should the system be administered in an efficient manner but governments should avoid changes which, although providing certain gains, involve complicated and cumbersome administrative procedures to operate, thus impairing the overall efficiency of the system. It is, of course, fundamental that the taxation system ought to complement the economic policies of the government of the day. This involves a whole host of considerations, including the effect of different forms of taxation upon inflation, incentive, investment and economic activity, and the balance between different sectors of the economy. Achieving this objective will often involve a judgment about a requirement or change which might serve one particular area of economic policy but not necessarily another. Such a judgment was very much involved in the Government's recent consideration of whether or not a broad-based indirect tax should be introduced.
International Comparisons

Whilst any international comparison has its defects, no discussion of the Australian taxation system is complete without some comparisons of the level of tax in this country with that in the rest of the world. Those comparisons show that, overall, Australians are less heavily taxed than people in most industrialised countries. The most recent figures published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are in respect of 1978 and show that total tax revenue at all levels of government as a percentage of gross domestic product averaged 35.8 per cent for the 22 countries for which data are available. For Australia the figure was 28.8 per cent. Only four countries had a lower overall tax burden.

The comparable figure for the United Kingdom was 34.5 per cent, the United States, 30.2 per cent, West Germany 37.8 per cent and socialist Sweden a staggering 53.5 per cent. This fact does not show that Australian taxes should be higher. Indeed it is our objective to reduce them further. In the Government's view this fact reveals that Australia has a strong tradition of dealing with many aspects of individual security in the private sector. The Government believes that its own objectives of limiting the role of government to encourage a vigorous private sector in Australia are in harmony with the dominant values of Australians expressed in this statistic. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing these particular comparisons.

TALK.START.PARA: — However, it is important to bear in mind that although we rely rather more heavily on personal income tax than other comparable countries, our absolute levels of personal income tax are lower than the OECD average. Once again, to illustrate from Table 1 the OECD average for personal income tax was 14.5 per cent of GDP in 1978; the Australian figure was 12.6 per cent of GDP. As Table 2 shows, in 1978 Australia ranked ninth of 22 member countries in terms of reliance on all types of consumption taxes, but were twenty-first in terms of 'general' or sales taxes, and on other taxes such as excise and customs duties and levies.

SPEECH.PARA: This difference reflects Australia's large collections from 'specific' taxes such as the crude oil levy and traditional excise duties on beer, potable spirits, tobacco products and petroleum products. Together these yield almost three times as much revenue as sales taxes. Moreover, these specific taxes, together with sales tax on motor vehicles and parts, account for over 80 per cent of our total taxes on goods and services. Since 1978, of course, the contribution from the crude oil levy has risen sharply and in the current year is estimated to yield almost 10 per cent of Commonwealth taxation revenues.

In summary, therefore, our overall tax burden is lower than the average of the industrialised world. We do, however, rely rather more on personal tax as a source of revenue, although our level of personal tax is still lower than the OECD average. To the extent that we collect revenue through indirect taxation, such collections tend to be concentrated on a very limited number of consumption items.
Trends in Taxation and Expenditure

It has been the common experience of western countries during the past 25 years for both expenditure and tax to rise as proportions of GDP. Australia has been no exception to this general pattern, although a number of particular observations can be made about our own experience. In the post-war period up to 1973-74, there was little change in Commonwealth tax receipts as a proportion of GDP, although the proportion of State and local tax receipts roughly doubled during that period. However, Commonwealth tax receipts rose from 21.3 per cent of GDP in 1973-74 to 23.2 per cent of GDP in 1975-76, during which time Commonwealth expenditure as a proportion of GDP rose from 24.6 to 30.7 per cent.

During the five years this Government has been in office, Commonwealth tax receipts as a proportion of GDP have risen from 23.2 per cent to an estimated 24.8 per cent in the current financial year. During this period, however, in contrast to the earlier period, there has been a substantial reduction in the deficit. This is due in large measure to the expenditure restraint applied by this Government. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table providing relevant information.

TALK.START.PARA: — Full tax indexation applied in 1976-77 and 1977-78. The standard rate scale was half-indexed in 1978-79 and in the current financial year. SPEECH.PARA: Major exploration incentives have been provided to the mining industry as well as incentives to the tourist industry and incentives for energy conservation. Various proposals have been put to the Government to allow full income splitting for all married taxpayers. Some taxpayers in this category, by reason of their professions or businesses, already enjoy the benefits in whole or in part of income splitting. SPEECH.PARA: To respond in part to what it saw as an imbalance in the tax system against single income families, the Government increased the dependent spouse rebate last year by 34 per cent from $597 to $800 per year. In all our analysis of changes to the taxation system, we should never lose sight of the impact of inflation upon a progressive tax scale. I can best illustrate by pointing out that in 1954-55 the maximum marginal rate began to apply at almost 18 times average earnings. By 1969-70, it begain to apply at 8 times earnings; by 1975-76 at 2.8 times average earnings; and by 1979-80 at 2.6 times average earnings. The dominant influence producing that trend has clearly been the effect of high rates of inflation on money incomes, which was particularly severe during the early 1970s.
Recent Review of Taxation Mix

The Senate will be aware of the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) last November that the Government had decided to examine certain options for change to the present taxation system. We particularly had in mind whether the time had come to shift a greater burden of the revenue raising effort towards general consumption taxes, thus enabling reductions in personal income tax. The purpose of that exercise was to assess the desirability of altering the mix or combination of taxes, to the extent possible, in the context of reducing the overall burden of taxation; it was not to bring about an increase in the overall taxation burden. In conducting this examination the Government already had available to it a wealth of material canvassing options for changes to our system. These included in particular the very comprehensive Asprey report completed in 1975.

As well as receiving advice from the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasurer sought the views of a number of industry groups as well as those of the trade union movement and the Government's Taxation Advisory Committee. The Government was conscious when it commenced its examination that there were strong arguments both for and against greater reliance on indirect taxation. The arguments for a change included:
(1) greater community sensitivity towards personal income tax, being as it is the most visible form of taxation;

(2) the economic advantages of a different mix of taxation, particularly if a greater reliance on indirect tax takes the form of applying to a broad range of goods and services. I cite particularly the need to avoid disincentive to saving, investment and risk taking and to obtain greater flexibility in demand and revenue management;
(3) indirect taxation is somewhat harder to evade and avoid than personal income tax; and
(4) the possibility that revenue from the crude oil levy would grow less rapidly in the years immediately ahead.
The major arguments against a change were seen as-
(1) the effect of any change on the consumer price index, particularly at a time when inflationary expectations are delicately balanced;
(2) the consequences of any additional anti-inflationary measures the Government might find necessary to apply;
(3) the regressive effects that certain forms of indirect taxation can have, although these effects will vary in intensity according to the items included in any broadened indirect tax base.

There were essentially three options for change. These were extending the coverage of the existing wholesale tax to additional goods and also imposing a tax on selected services; introduction of a general retail sales tax, that is a tax paid by consumers at the final point of sale; and a value-added tax which would be imposed at all stages of the production and distribution chain for goods and services. A multi-stage VAT was rejected fairly quickly because it would have imposed an enormous paper work burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities. A retail turnover tax had some strong arguments in its favour, particularly its lack of bias on expenditure patterns and its ability to generate substantial revenue from low rates of tax.

It was calculated that the potential value in any one year of sales of goods and services to consumers was some $70,000m and after allowing for those items which for constitutional or practical reasons it would be very difficult to tax, it was believed that the potential base for a retail turnover tax on goods and services was in the order of $55,000-$60,000m. However, a retail turnover tax would have involved a very extensive licensing system, and the necessity for a significant increase in the number of taxpaying units-perhaps as many as 350,000-and administrative staff-perhaps 3,500. There was the further complication that a period of two years would have elapsed before a retail turnover tax on goods and services could have been fully in place.

We concluded that, if we were to broaden the indirect tax base the simplest method would be to extend the existing wholesale sales tax to some goods now exempt and to impose a tax on selected services. Administratively, the former would be quite straightforward and could be implemented quickly; in the main it would involve a small number of relatively large businesses with developed accounting systems.

The supplementary tax on selected services posed rather more difficulties and could have taken more than 12 months to implement, depending on the number and character of the services that might be taxed. Although the practical problems posed by an expression of the wholesale tax base and the introduction of a tax on selected services would have been considerably less than those involved in the other options before the Government there were, nonetheless, a number of difficulties involved in such a change.

There was of course the very basic question of whether there should be any exemption in a broadened wholesale tax base. For example, were 'basic foodstuffs' to be exempt and, if so, which ones? Should prescribed medicines be included? Should goods subject to excise be exempt? Should inputs to further production such as building materials be exempt? In this connection, it is worth noting that if food and clothing, for example, were exempt this would more than halve the coverage of expenditure and thus the revenue base.

There was also the problem of the rate structure. Whilst a single rate of tax would have been very attractive from an administrative point of view, the graduation in the existing wholesale tax scales suggested that goods and services which could not properly be regared as necessities should be taxed at a higher rate than commodities seen as essential to everyday life. The introduction of a tax on selected services would, of course, have broken new ground. That, of itself, would have involved the difficulties of educating the large number of new taxpayers and recruiting and training administrative staff. There were also some problems to be resolved on how to avoid double taxation of goods which form part of a service.

It should also be noted that given certain constitutional and other constraints, the base for taxation of services is somewhat more limited than might be imagined. For example, some obvious candidates like betting and gambling are already the subject of state taxes, while interstate passenger and freight movements fall outside the Commonwealth's taxation powers. In addition, it would have been undesirable to tax public services such as those provided by educational institutions and hospitals.

Throughout its consideration of this issue, the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax. The Government was aware when it commenced its examination that any increase in indirect taxation would affect the consumer price index. However, it was not until detailed projections of likely price effects as a consequence of particular levels of indirect taxation and also the cost to revenue of compensating personal tax reductions became known that the total implications of a shift towards greater reliance on indirect tax were fully appreciated by the Government.

There was-and perhaps still is-a fairly widely held view in the community that a quite noticeable reduction in personal income tax can be achieved through a relatively modest increase in reliance on indirect taxation. That, regrettably, is not the case. Let me illustrate by describing the considerations which finally led to the Government's decision. In deciding whether to broaden the wholesale tax base or to retain the status quo, the Government was caught in the dilemma of not wishing to move towards greater reliance on indirect tax without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions whilst being anxious to minimise the inflationary consequences of collecting additional revenue.

It soon became apparent that both of these objectives could not be achieved. It was not possible to raise sufficient additional indirect taxation to provide noticeable personal tax relief without adding to the consumer price index in a major way. For example, to reduce the existing personal income tax scale by one cent at each step would cost the revenue $610m in 1980-81. Therefore, to convert the existing 32/46/60 rate scale into, say, a 27/41/55 rate scale, a total cost to revenue of about $3,000m would be involved. As a general rule, each additional $500m raised through indirect taxes results in direct and indirect additions to the consumer price index of almost 1 per cent. Furthermore, there are additional flow-on consequences for the consumer price index through the wage system which are hard to quantify.

There was the disturbing possibility that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission could not be persuaded to discount effectively for the price effects of a shift towards greater reliance on indirect taxation. It will thus be seen that in order to have raised sufficient revenue to bring about the personal tax reduction I have mentioned, the direct and indirect price effects would have been about 6 per cent, with at least the strong possibility of substantial additional flow-on consequences via the wage fixation system.

I should emphasise that the example of reducing personal taxation which I have just used does not in any way misrepresent the cost to revenue of various changes to the burden of personal income tax. For example, full tax indexation in 1980-81 would cost the revenue about $1,000m. A $100 increase in the tax-free threshold would cost $200m and a $100 increase in the dependent spouse rebate would cost $170m. Apart from these revenue considerations there would also have been a noticeable addition to expenditure as a consequence of the automatic indexation of pensions and benefits-in the order of $75m for each 1 per cent addition to the CPI-as well as the costs of any other compensatory action which may have been thought necessary in respect of those on low incomes. In reaching its decision, the Government naturally gave thought to future revenue trends. This involved not only making certain assumptions based on likely growth in the community, but also having regard to the fact that under existing policy, proceeds of the crude oil levy might begin to level out in real terms in the next couple of years. It should be said that these projections are necessarily difficult to make and reflect a large number of assumptions and judgements.

The Australian economy is now growing very strongly. Provided the right economic policies are continued, the prospects are for reasonable levels of sustained growth through the 1980s. As I am sure the Senate will appreciate, the impact of this on revenue collections from the existing taxation base is quite considerable. One of the by-products of greater economic activity is an increase in taxation revenues as the tax base grows. Whilst, once again, projections are difficult to make with precision, there is gathering evidence that the growth in prospect in the Australian economy over the next four or five years will prove stronger than had been anticipated even 12 months ago. As a graphic illustration of this, the indications are that private sector capital investment in 1980-81 is likely to grow by about 20 per cent in real terms. These developments endorse the view that, provided rigorous expenditure restraint can be applied and maintained in the years immediately ahead, a responsible fiscal outcome can be achieved without a rise in the overall tax burden. It should nonetheless be noted that even in a situation where the overall tax burden did not rise at all, or even fell, personal income tax would under present policies be likely to assume a greater share of that burden.

Important though these practical difficulties and future revenue considerations were, the fundamental reasons for the Government's decision was its concern at the impact on inflation and inflationary expectations of any significant shift towards greater reliance on indirect taxation. This Government has fought long and hard to restore domestic economic conditions of growth and stability and to retrieve this country's international reputation as a low inflation, economically stable nation. There is no more conspicuous hallmark of these achievements than our continued ability to contain inflation. Perceptions and expectations assume great relevance in economic matters. Rightly or wrongly, no economic indicator is more universally regarded as a barometer of a government's success or failure in economic management than the consumer price index. Therefore, and despite obvious advantages from many other points of view, the Government came firmly to the conclusion that the inevitable squandering of the gains made and maintained in the fight against inflation in recent years was a price it was not prepared to pay.
Other Taxes

No statement of this kind would be complete without some reference to other forms of taxation. Unlike most other OECD countries, Australia does not impose any general capital taxes at the federal level. Other OECD countries levy one or more of capital gains taxes, net wealth taxes or death duties. Australia does not have a capital gains tax or a net wealth tax and, as I noted earlier, the Commonwealth has ceased levying gift and estate duty and of course the States have either removed or substantially cut back their probate duties. With the exception therefore of taxes on specific forms of property, such as local government rates and State land taxes, Australians are very largely free of capital taxes. If the experience of other countries is any guide, general capital taxes are unlikely to raise substantial amounts of revenue unless imposed at very high rates. If that were to occur, there would be a real risk of undersirable effects on the tax structure and the economy. It is a plain fact that if any capital gains tax were to exclude basic holdings such as the family home, then in order to yield large amounts of revenue it would be necessary to impose it at a quite significant rate on other assets.

The Government is opposed to the introduction of a resources tax. It believes that many of the advocates of such a tax ignore the disincentive effect such a tax would have on investment and development in Australia. They also ignore the contribution which companies earning very large profits make towards Commonwealth and State revenues through the existing tax structure. This occurs not only through company tax but also royalties paid to State governments. A recent mining industry survey showed that, of 81 mining companies questioned, government charges and taxes represented 56 per cent of the companies' pre-tax operating profits and that the companies involved paid a total of $1,113m to different governments in 1979-80.

The tax system is not the only mechanism through which the Government can ensure that Australians receive a fair share of the development of our natural resources. Our foreign investment policy, which will be fully applied, requires as a general rule Australian equity participation of at least 50 per cent Australian ownership, or 75 per cent Australian ownership in the case of uranium projects. Recently questions have been raised as to whether sufficient opportunity exists for the small investor to participate in resource development. It is undeniable that in recent years there has been a marked trend towards larger equity holdings by institutions at the expense of the individual investor. The taxation system is frequently blamed for this development and it may well be that the existing taxation treatment of inter alia dividend income has discouraged the small investor. The matter is not, however, free from doubt and such evidence as is available suggests that the trend I have mentioned has occurred in those countries which treat dividend income more generously than does Australia as well as those which have a similar approach to ours. This matter has been the subject of submissions to an investigation by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. The Government will await with interest the views of that inquiry on this subject. I should make it plain that the Government is anxious to respond in an appropriate way to the desire of individual Australians to participate in our development.
Tax Avoidance

A conspicuous feature of this Government's approach to taxation has been its uncompromising attack upon tax avoidance. The Government is determined to deal with those who seek to avoid payment of their fair share of taxation. Such people push the tax burden more heavily on to the great majority of citizens who are responsible taxpayers. They are justifiably resented. The Government's record on tax avoidance and evasion is evidence enough of its resolve to bear down on it. Since 1977, nine Bills incorporating some 24 legislative measures against income tax avoidance arrangements have been introduced. Other amendments have been enacted to deal with sales tax avoidance arrangements. More measures directed against income tax avoidance have been announced in four separate statements issued by me in the past year. All areas of avoidance have been tackled. We have acted both against schemes creating deductions and against schemes which attempt to shield income from tax. We have adopted a policy of banning the carry forward of paper losses from schemes entered into before the operative date of remedial legislation.

Decisive action has also been taken against tax evasion. Last year, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed into law. This legislation was an entirely appropriate and necessary response to fraudulent conduct designed to prevent the collection of lawfully payable tax. It contains penalties of five years gaol and fines of up to $50,000 for those who act, or aid or abet someone to act, to prevent the collection of lawfully payable tax. Honourable senators will be aware that the Government has been engaged for some time in the task of re-writing section 260 which is the general anti-avoidance provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Those who criticise the time taken do not appreciate the significant task involved in this exercise. The Government has the twin aim in this area of devising an effective anti-avoidance section whilst not getting in the way of legitimate commercial transactions and arrangements. The balance to be struck is a delicate one and considerable care is required if both these aims are to be realised.

The work on section 260 has involved not only officers of the Australian Taxation Office but also the obtaining of advice from private counsel. The Treasurer has also sought the advice of the Government's Taxation Advisory Committee which in the 12 months of its existence has provided invaluable private sector professional comment upon taxation legislation. The process of re-writing section 260 is near to an end and the Treasurer hopes soon to present it to Parliament. Proper time will be allowed for comment before Parliament is asked to approve the new section.

In recent days the Treasurer has told the House that section 136, which deals in principle with transfer pricing arrangements by certain companies, is also under review, particularly as a consequence of the decision of the High Court last year in the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation Ltd case. The case appears to indicate that the power of the Commissioner of Taxation to fix an arms length price is considerably less than previously believed. I repeat previous assurances given to the Senate that this Government will remain tenacious in seeking out and dealing with taxation avoidance arrangements.
Conclusion

Debate on taxation can never be wholly conclusive. It is an inherently controversial subject. Opinion as to the appropriate shape of our taxation system will vary sharply throughout the community. It has not been possible for me in this statement to canvass all aspects of our taxation system. I have, however, endeavoured to put consideration of our taxation system into a better perspective and to state some of the realities which must be accepted if sensible debate on taxation is to occur. The most dominant reality is that governments cannot tax less unless they spend less.

This Government remains committed to further reforms to, and where possible reductions in, levels of taxation. Progress towards these goals cannot proceed in isolation from the general conduct of economic policy. To the extent that we are successful in achieving our economic goals, so we shall be successful, I believe, in achieving our broad objectives in the area of taxation. I present the following paper:
Taxation system-Ministerial Statement, 12 March 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement has all the marks of what my colleague the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) once described as a cut-out-and-paste job in relation to an energy statement which was introduced by Mr Newman a few years ago. It appears that there is a fundamental dichotomy in the statement. Half of it appears to have been written by the bureaucracy-it is written in descriptive and dispassionate terms. The other half appears to have been written in the political office of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). It is, of course, political propaganda. I think it is most appropriate that in the copy which I received and which, at least, some others received, the pages which contain the tables and which constitute the appendices, are upside down. I think that is most appropriate because, in several instances, the statement proper does, in fact, stand truth on its head. The first example of that can be found on page 4 where it states:
This fact--
That is, the fact that Australian taxes, by comparison with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, are not high--
does not show that Australian taxes should be higher. Indeed--
The statement has the audacity to assert--
it is our objective to further reduce them.

This clearly asserts, of course, that the Government has reduced taxes. The fact is acknowledged three pages later-presumably this is one of the dispassionate sections written within the bureaucracy-on page 7 that:
During the five years this Government has been in office, Commonwealth tax receipts as a proportion of GDP have risen from 23.2 per cent to an estimated 24.8 per cent in the current financial year.

On page 3 of the statement we have the false implication that the Government has reduced taxes and has the intention of further reducing them. On page 7 we have the dispassionate admission that, in fact, taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product have increased by 1.6 per cent while this Government has been in office. The only additional thing that ought to be added, of course, is that taxes as a proportion of GDP are higher right now than they have ever been in the country's history. The Government has the audacity to imply that it has reduced taxation and will continue to do so.

That passage on page 7 is immediately followed by an assertion that the reduced deficit which has been estimated for this year but which does not look like being met, at least not for the full magnitude of the estimated reduction, is due, in large measure, the statement states, to expenditure restraint. The reduction in the deficit, if it is finally realised, will be almost precisely equal to the increase in the crude oil levy. The reason the deficit has been reduced has nothing to do with expenditure restraint because expenditure, in fact, in real terms, has increased by at least 3 per cent and is entirely a function of the large increase in taxation contained in this year's Budget.

On page 8 there is a reference made to table 5, one of the appendices to the statement, which purports to compare rates of tax applying under the schedule which applied prior to 1977 and rates of tax which apply now. Of course, since the calculations of tax paid made no allowances for the fact that the same money income in those different periods is a very different real income, the superficial impression generated by an examination of that table is that, in fact, taxes are substantially lower under the present schedule than they were in the pre-1977 schedule. It would have been even more dramatic-I wonder why the Government did not do this-if it had included the 1950 taxation schedule without making any allowance for changing money values over the period. The misleading effect which the Government is trying to get across would have been even more startling if that sort of fallacious comparison had been made. A few pages later, getting back to the section which it would seem the bureaucracy wrote, it states:
In all our analysis of changes to the taxation system, we should never lose sight of the impact of inflation upon a progressive tax scale.

This is an appropriate time, I think, to refer to a question asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on 25 February. He reminded the Prime Minister of his 1975 policy promise when the Prime Minister said:
We will fully index personal income tax for inflation over three years . . . It will make government more honest with your money.
That was the bold rhetoric of 1975. When the Leader of the Opposition asked whether tax indexation had been abandoned the Prime Minister replied:
. . . it has been difficult for the people of Australia to understand the benefits of indexation in terms of a policy of tax reductions.

I want to pursue that point a little more. The assertion by the Prime Minister that a policy of tax indexation is a policy of tax reduction, an assertion which is repeated on several occasions throughout the statement although not in precisely that form, is again fallacious. The plain truth is that unless the taxation schedule is fully indexed, anything less than full indexation is, in fact, an increase in taxation.

There are numerous assertions of the Government's alleged activity in the area of tax avoidance. Certainly, plenty of legislation has been put up to the Parliament. Plenty of other Acts have been wheeled up to the Parliament which open up additional loopholes which the tax avoiders and evaders may exploit. One of the recent examples of this, currently in the pipeline, is the taxation rort promised by the Prime Minister for film making. Originally this was costed at $2m. Now, by admission of the Treasurer only yesterday, it is costing at least $20m. If the legislation is to be as loose as has been forecast, the cost of it, at least in the first financial year, is more likely to run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Certainly the Government has done all those things but the plain fact remains that it refuses to take the one simple step which would be effective against tax avoidance and that is, the credible threat of retrospective legislation. In spite of the activity-there has been activity in terms of the number of Bills wheeled up to the Parliament-the plain fact remains that the leakage of the revenue due to tax avoidance is greater than it has ever been and it appears to be still rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an industry in itself.
—It is a parasitic industry certainly, as Senator Cavanagh says. It is also a pernicious industry.
—Would attention to section 260 be a step forward also?

—Given recent changes on the High Court Bench a new section 260 might have more chance of standing up than the old one would have had. But a credible threat of retrospective legislation would kill the tax avoidance industry stone dead. On page 3 of the statement there is really an apologia for tax avoiders. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which this principle should apply-
That is, capacity to pay income tax and so on-

must in turn be tempered by the recognition that if marginal tax rates become too high, adverse effects on incentives occur with consequent loss of economic efficiency with productivity and greater resort to tax avoidance.

In more simple language the argument being put forward is that high marginal rates of taxation are a deterrent to effort and an incentive to tax avoidance. I will deal with the latter point first. It is again a fact that the maximum marginal rate of tax, presently 60 per cent, is the lowest it has ever been since uniform taxation was introduced in 1942. Yet in spite of that the leakage of revenue because of tax avoidance is greater than it has ever been. The reason for that has nothing to do with marginal taxation rates. It has a great deal to do with the bizarre judgment of the High Court of Australia and with the present ethical standards or the standards of fiscal morality which prevail in public life.

For example, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia was exposed publicly as a speculator in land through insider trading. He took measures to avoid tax on the profits gained. He was readmitted to the Ministry and again became the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. The Deputy Leader of the Country Party, on his own admission, still has custody of $200,000 misappropriated by his father. The Prime Minister's relatives, apparently with the connivance of the Premier of Victoria, received loans at an interest rate of 4 per cent in ways which, if not illegal, certainly were highly irregular. The present Prime Minister presides over the lowest ethical standards that any Australian Prime Minister has ever tolerated.

I turn to the alleged disincentive effect of high marginal tax rates on effort. It is peculiar, given the stress placed on this argument by the Government and its supporters, that they never bother to mention that the effective rate of taxation for pensioners earning more than $20 a week is, in fact, 82 per cent because of the combined operation of getting into the bracket where income is taxable and the fact that their pensions are reduced by 50c for every additional dollar earned. The effective rate of taxation for pensioners earning more than $20 a week is 82 per cent. We hear nothing about that from the Government, yet the Treasurer puts his name to an assertion that the present marginal tax rate of 60 per cent is a significant disincentive to work. The position of the unemployed who earn more than $6 a week is even more striking. Their effective marginal tax rate is 100 per cent because every dollar earned above $6 a week reduces their unemployment benefit by--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty cents.
—Not by 50c; by a dollar.
—For every dollar.

—For every dollar they earn, their unemployment benefit is reduced by a whole dollar. So the effective rate of tax is 100 per cent. That apparently does not worry the Government. All its sympathies are poured out on those people who are paying--
—If you want to be pedantic the real rate is over 100 per cent.
—Because they incur some expenses in earning the income; that is a fair point, too. On page 10 of the statement there is a reference to primary producers. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax averaging provisions for primary producers have been improved and enable primary producers to even out the inevitable fluctuations in taxable incomes which occur in rural Australia.

It does not specify what those improvements have been but I will elaborate on what they presumably are. The evening out in fluctuations in incomes presumably refers to income equalisation deposits which would be an equitable and sensible measure had it not been sabotaged and undermined by the ill-considered amendments which the Government made to tax averaging provisions in 1977. In 1977 after the very hasty changes to the tax schedule had been rushed through the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, apparently with little or no consultation with the tax experts at the Treasury, the Government was under attack from the farming sector. The Government then introduced an arrangement under which primary producers, if their taxable income in a year was lower than the five-year average, would have their tax liability assessed at the current year's income. If their taxable income in a particular year was higher than the five-year average, their taxation liability was assessed at the rate applicable to the average income instead of the actual higher income. I suppose that probably sounds a bit complicated to people who are not familiar with that matter, but I thought it was beautifully summed up at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference held at the end of January by none other than the Secretary of the Treasury, John Stone. Professor Lloyd of the School of Agriculture at Melbourne University attacked this report that had been written into the Income Tax Assessment Act in 1977 by the Government. The chairman of the Conference proceedings asked Mr Stone whether he would like to make a comment. He said: 'No, I have no comment to make other than to say that the present system is one of heads we win'-that is, the farmers win-'and tails all other taxpayers lose'. That rort has been under attack at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference. It was under severe attack at a seminar conducted by the Rural Adjustment Unit of New England University a few months before. Its removal has been explicitly recommended in a report that came from that institution. Before turning from Mr Stone, I note from the Treasurer's other statement today that:
Mr Stone has assured me that in accordance with long-standing convention regarding public servants commenting upon policy issues, it was not his intention to publicly advocate or infer support for-

The statement continued. It can be seen very clearly from the example I have just quoted that Mr Stone was commenting on a policy issue which, indeed, is not at all unusual for him. He has been travelling around the country for the last couple of years delivering highly political speeches in respect of government policy. He gets into trouble with the Treasurer, however, only when he is reported making comments that are critical of or in disagreement with government policy. There is dispassionate reference in the statement-so I presume it was written by the bureaucracy-to the fact that no Federal capital taxation exists in Australia, that State capital taxation exists to only a negligible degree and that Australia is one of the very few countries, if not the only country, in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in which this applies. I think an excellent indicator of the moral poverty of this country is the fact that that is one of its proudest boasts when two million Australians live in poverty. The statement repeats that the Government is opposed to a resources rent tax although I note for the record the considered answers today of the Minister for National Development and Energy, when he, like John Stone last Friday, knew exactly what he was saying. Senator Carrick certainly indicated that as far as he was concerned a resources rent tax was still an option which was open.

The fact that until now the Government has refused to impose a resources rent tax has led to many absurdities and has helped to create situations which the Government, according to its own value judgments, finds quite distressing. It is predictable that into a tax vacuum, such as that which the rejection of a resources rent tax has induced, somebody else will move and this has happened. The unions have moved in. Most dramatically in relation to the Utah Development Co. coal fields and the Utah employees of central Queensland, the unions are taxing away a portion of the economic rent which the Government has refused to collect. The current campaign to obtain a 35-hour week in high profit industries which with their low labour requirements are capital intensive, likewise is an attempt by the workers in those industries to tax away in the form of reduced working hours for themselves, the economic rent which the Government refuses to collect. The States are moving in with concealed, crude and inefficient attempts to appropriate economic rent by means such as excessive rail freights in Queensland, the Northern Territory's proposals to change the royalty provisions at Gove and, of course, more recently I think the Winchester coal project in southern Queensland. It has produced the absence of a sensible, rational resources rent tax. Such a tax has not been opposed, to my knowledge, by any economist in Australia other than those who have direct associations with the mining industry.

The abdication from the introduction of a resources rent tax has produced such idiocies or absurdities as the advocacy by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) last Thursday night that an export tax should be imposed on unprocessed raw materials. That is the full resurrection of Tudor mercantilism. That is exactly what Tudor mercantilism was based on. It was based upon embargoes on the export of raw materials which could be further processed in England. Its resurrection is being advocated by a Government member who has some pretensions to understanding in this area. I also note for the record that he recommended a similar tax on livestock exports. It puts him in the same bed as members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union who are attempting to restrict the export of livestock so that it can be further processed-that is, killed and dressed-within Australia. The Government's abdication of responsibility in this area has certainly produced some strange bedfellows.

In conclusion, I really do not know why the Government has made this statement. Caught by the historical imperative, perhaps, that it said it was going to introduce the statement, it felt obliged to do so. Possibly of equal or greater importance, I guess it did so to explain away the posturing of the last couple of months about how it was going to change the whole basis of the taxation system. Again, as it has customarily done in spite of its tough rhetoric, when confronted with significant opposition from people who were opposed for one reason or another to fundamental changes in the taxation system, it backed down to these pressures. The statement certainly does not constitute either an accurate assessment of the present taxation system or any sort of rational indications as to how it may be improved.
