SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I enter this debate on several reports, some with application to foreign affairs, to consider our attitudes towards the Association of South East Asian Nations region, that is, what used to be called South East Asia. I have listened with some disquiet to some of the earlier speakers in this debate. They seem to feel that there is nothing much wrong in the ASEAN area, that it is now relatively placid and peaceful and is likely to continue in that way. That attitude, I believe, based on the facts of the past and the present, is dangerously unperceptive.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly a fact that South East Asia appears to be relatively peaceful after the storm of revolutions and civil wars that plagued that region for several decades. I would contend that it is mainly an appearance rather than a reality. We cannot look back on those decades of war, I believe, with any complacency, nor can we be assured that the conditions which created them no longer exist. Our involvement in Vietnam was part of a tragic adventure, the net consequence of which has been to extend the communist world so that it now includes the whole peninsula which was once called Indo-China, all of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. In other words, we were in any terms the losers by that process.

I think it is important for us to analyse why we were the losers by that process. Actions should, I believe, be primarily judged by their results. It is not good enough to say: 'We tried; we were wrong: But at least our motives were good'. Those are the sorts of things that are being said again now. People say: 'It did not work last time but maybe it will work this time'. I suggest that this attitude is not safe in today's world. Any effect which has diminished the free world or destroyed even a struggling and inadequate type of democracy, is not an effect that can be applauded.

When one looks back on the history of South East Asia, it is quite evident that simplistic theories like the domino theory, which was quite the vogue at one time-it asserted that one nation would fall to communism if its neighbours fell-have to be ignored as the dangerous, simplistic nonsense that they are. Nations are not dominoes; they are complex entities much less bound by general principles than we would like to imagine and much more conditioned by their own peculiar history and their own state of society.

If there appears to me to be any universal theme-I have made something of a study of this area-it must be that communism extended in Asia where there was a suitable climate in which it could prosper. I think that climate can be identified fairly easily and has lessons for us in the ASEAN region again. Indeed, a similar type of pattern applied in all of the ASEAN countries that have become communist since the end of World War II. The scenario was pretty much the same everywhere. It was found in those nations in which there was a gross disproportion of wealth, where often much of the wealth was in the hands of a few families with acute problems of landlessness, dictatorial government-often, indeed, of those wealthy families-widespread social injustice or a lack of any of the normal services that a state should provide its people such as medical care, social services and education, and a close association of the ruling junta with a military force designed not so much to protect that nation from outside aggression but to keep its own people in subjection. That was the case in China, Vietnam and Korea. The communist revolts in Malaysia, Luzon and Java-for instance, the Madiun affair-were caused not by any domino effect but by the poverty, landlessness and sheer despair of the majority of people in that area. They were driven to it by what seemed to them to be the force of necessity of their own circumstances.

Through you, Mr President, I shall give honourable senators an analogy. A bad tennis player will beat himself with little effort on the part of his opponent. I believe that that analogy might be applied to the attitudes of the West over the last two decades towards the spread of communism in Asia. Speaking of the West in its generality, which includes Australia, we have too often supported the unpopular military juntas and we are still supporting them now. What we fail to see, I think, is that just as military juntas have fallen in the past in the spite of our assistance, so those we are now supporting will also fall. History does not change. Cause leads to effect. I believe that there is nothing we can do about that. Granted that fact, we can assume that further trouble is only a matter of time. Can we afford the risk of associating ourselves with that kind of problem? Can we afford a situation in which Australia slowly becomes separated wholly from Europe and America by a steadily-growing group of communist states to our north? Can we not say that those who over the last 40 years or so have presented us with solutions to the spread of communism have not always been wrong? They have been wrong to the extent that every exercise they have prompted us into has led to a defeat. Their solutions were wrong. I think it is time that we understand that.

If we look again at our experience in Vietnam, it ought to demonstrate that fact to us. The military effort poured into that country was enormous. By any reasonable assessment it should have prevailed; yet it did not. The only way that it could have succeeded-I think this is generally admitted-would have been, in effect, to destroy an entire nation and its people. If we reach the stage where our policies have that sort of end, I think we all might as well turn on the gas oven, because there is no future for the world or any nation in it if our policies and aims can only go that way.

A study of the early history of Vietnam-I refer to the period between the end of World War II, when a provisional independent government was set up in Hanoi, and the fall of Dien Bien Phu-shows a trend which ought to be of great interest to us in our assessment of the ASEAN region as it stands now. Of course, that trend has an equally important application in central America. I believe that the situation there is probably analogous to the ASEAN situation. Before the French reoccupied North Vietnam, the Communist Party-then basically the Vietminh, which had been a resistance movement during the war-was very much a minority in the independence movement, which included many other elements including the Roman Catholic Church. According to Donald Lancaster, who is an authority on that period, Ho Chi Minh himself appealed at that stage to the French: 'Given me some weapon against the extremists. You will never regret it'. But Admiral Argenlieu and the French hawks were determined to reimpose the colonial era.

The effect of this was to begin the war, that same tragic war in which we and the United States were eventually involved. That war and the conditions it brought gradually and steadily increased the influence of the Vietminh. Gradually all nationalists were forced into the arms of the communists and the communists came at last to dominate that independence movement. The rest of it is history which is familiar enough to all of us. That process is something which may well happen again.

The point I am trying to make is that every effort we make in Australia, which is a democracy, to sustain and encourage democracies in the ASEAN countries will be in our own interests in the long run. If we try to sustain and to help military juntas and military solutions, we will be contributing to further defeats which might eventually encompass our own defeat. I think we should consider that thought. There is a tendency for nations, especially happy nations like our own, to believe that they are immune from the processes of history and that terrible things happen to other people but not to them. Of course, history teaches us that that is not the case. It seems to me that this is so obvious a lesson of recent history as to be virtually axiomatic.

From that background, let us look a little more closely at the ASEAN nations of the world today. What do we find? We find that the huge majority of the ASEAN population-in Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines-live in conditions which are becoming steadily worse, not better. In the Philippines, standards of living, education and food supply are deteriorating. Child mortality is on the increase. There is a gross financial disproportion. Nothing effective has been done about the problems of landlessness and poverty in the barrios. In Manila persists a government which uses armed force against its own people to maintain itself in power. In Jakarta the generals, corrupt, autocratic and self-seeking, impose themselves on South East Asia's largest nation in exactly the same way.

I still have many contacts with Indonesia and I can assure honourable senators that most Indonesians regard their Government with fear and hatred, and with good reason. Poverty, disease, bad housing conditions, and economic disproportion flourish throughout the archipelago. Of course, we have seen an act of the most blatant and unjustified aggression in recent years in the takeover of East Timor. Indonesia had no rights whatsoever to it historically, ethnically or in any other way. That has been associated, tragically, with an act of virtual genocide against the Timorese people which we in this country, to our eternal shame, have tolerated. It is a black page in the history of this country that we allowed that to happen to a small and weak neighbour which made many acts of generosity towards our own servicemen during World War II. So our act of treachery was all the greater and all the more unforgivable.

Thailand, once a graceful, prosperous nation which could export rice, is now in the throes of a population explosion which is forcing more and more people into poverty and even starvation, especially in the remote impoverished north-east region which borders Laos and Cambodia. Here again a military junta maintains itself by turning its weapons against its own people. In other words, in all these places the tinder is there ready for the spark. Just as in China, Vietnam, Korea, Laos, Cambodia and Cuba, it is only a matter of time.

I know that I sound as if I am preaching a gospel of despair and I do not want to do that. The real point I wish to make is that where ASEAN is concerned, I believe we in Australia have a special obligation and duty to encourage in every way we can forces that might restore democracy and self-determination. We have a special duty to set our forces against the forces of suppression, evil and dictatorship and a special duty to speak out against these things. Yet we tend not to do that. We tend to accept them. We would not accept them in our own country, but we accept them there.

I have tried to show that for reasons of history such an active role on our part can be seen purely as one of our own self-interest. We cannot afford to go on backing or encouraging losers. We cannot go on countenancing social conditions which we know, or should know perfectly well, are ideal for the propagation and continuation of communism. If we believe in freedom and if we believe in our own system of democracy, we should try to ensure that as best we can, without undue interference in the affairs of other nations, we encourage those values elsewhere.

I worked for a number of years in South East Asia. At one time I was an adviser to a Thai Cabinet Minister. I suspect that sympathetic interest from this country would be taken pretty much at face value. We would be given much more credence and credibility than I believe we think we would. Our example, I think, is looked at keenly. If we show signs of accepting the terrible lack of values which occur in South East Asia, I think those countries would see it as tacit approval. We might also have that on our conscience. I use this debate to criticise the Government for its apathy, its spinelessness in foreign affairs and its apparent inability to recognise these forces of history which I assure honourable senators there is no escape from, except to change one's attitude to cope with those forces in a proper way and a constructive way.

It is against this background of instability, of fragile, ineffective and dictatorial regimes which dominate most of the peoples of the ASEAN region, that I believe we must regard with alarm recent tendencies in the United States to revert to the philosophy of the past, the disasters of the 1960s, the use of military solutions, the willingness to plunge whole populations into chaos and to contribute to the deaths of tens of thousands of innocent people in the name of world zonal rivalry. This is a failing procedure. It is something which I do not believe we can accept again in terms of sheer cold expediency. Of course there is a humanitarian reason, a moral reason, for objecting to these horrors, this butchery of innocent people who are often too ill-educated and too badly informed to know even what are the forces that are destroying them. I know that honourable senators have the humanity and compassion to recognise that.

The reason for this speech is to reiterate that, purely in our own self-interest and that of our allies, it would be stupid, dangerous and self-destructive to think that a return to the policies of the past will do anything but damage us. Hence, I appeal to the Government to begin, as soon as possible, to use its good offices, in association with other interested middle powers, to try to modify in every way we can the extreme attitudes of the new Reagan-Haig Administration in the United States. We must start in San Salvador. There is a strong parallel between San Salvador and the past problems of the ASEAN countries.

Surely the aim there ought to be to end the conflict, to get that small country away from the zonal conflict, if necessary under the aegis of the United Nations, and allow it to work out its own destiny through a referred process of self-determination. If the President of the United States and the Russian leaders wanted to do so they could do something which would probably save the lives of scores of people every day-thousands of innocent people in totality-and be doing something worthwhile. I do not know whether honourable senators had the opportunity of listening to the Australian Broadcasting Commission's P.M. program tonight, which gave a most harrowing account by Alex Brody in San Salvador of what is happening there. Young people in their teens are lying about in the streets with their heads cut off or their feet cut off and showing evidence of torture to their bodies before they were killed.

An account was given of two young men who had nothing whatsoever to do with the revolution and who allegedly owed money to a woman. She denounced them to the national guard. She arranged a meeting at a bus stop with the two young men. The national guard came along and the two young men were shot in the back of the head. The woman was then asked whether three other young people who had been casually standing at the bus stop were in fact guerrillas. She was so frightened that she said yes. Those three men were then taken away, tortured and killed. I will not spare honourable senators the details of the situation in that country. Another account was given of bodies lying in the streets and of a photographer going by and seeing one being eaten by a dog. A little later in the day that body was being pulled to pieces by vultures.

We are a small country, too. It could happen here if we allow the system of small countries being dominated and ruled entirely by the zonal conflict to continue in the world. I appeal to the Government to consider these matters carefully, not to sit passively by, not to allow our friends in the United States to feel that what they are doing is right. The world is full of strong people who have sycophants around them who say: 'You are right. Of course you are right. We agree with you' even though they know it is not true. It is not an honourable role to pursue. It is not a right, proper, honest or moral role. We should speak to our friends, if we are true friends, and say that we disagree, that there may be other ways, that there may be a middle course. The Australian Democrats are afraid that if everybody sits passively and allows the world to drift again into a conflict which could, for the reasons I have given, grow into another running sore such as Vietnam then we can only expect worse trouble than we have had before.

If the ASEAN countries, particularly-there could be an extension there if we have this philosophy on a global basis-are to have any hope of more equal, democratic and prosperous communities, the demand there, more than anything else, is for peace. That is the thing that is needed more than anything else. The most dangerous thing that can happen to those societies, the thing which will breed an extension of communism faster and more surely than anything else, is war and military measures. If we cannot see, from the history of the last 30 years, that that is true then we are too silly to continue to survive as a nation in this world. The ominous words we hear from time to time from Washington, from President Reagan and from Secretary Haig that threaten conflict and war rather than peace are tragic. I think it demonstrates a misunderstanding of what the world needs at this stage. I wish I could feel confident that those uttering those words have a clear understanding of the likely results of that conflict and war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the report brought down by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. As a member of that Committee I would like to record my compliments to the Chairman, Senator Sim, under whose excellent chairmanship the Committee has worked together as a team since 1976. Each member has contributed in his own way and, with a different approach to the many terms of references and under Senator Sim's able chairmanship, has brought down recommendations which have been supported by the Committee as a whole. We will miss Senator Sim when he retires later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also like to take this opportunity to thank the five Association of South East Asian Nations for the hospitality and assistance they afforded to Senator Sim, Senator Primmer and myself when we visited those countries in April last year to collect information for the ASEAN report. Other members of the Committee who have spoken on the report have made reference to the mistakes which were made over the International Civil Aviation Policy agreement. Qantas Airways Ltd came in for its share of criticism, especially from Singapore. I dare say that mistakes were made on both sides, and Singapore, when it found itself in a rather bad negotiating position immediately donned the cloak of ASEAN. I think it should be made quite clear by the ASEAN nations that they have a responsibility too, and that is to say when they are acting as an economic bloc and when they are acting bilaterally. That is a responsibility which they should face up to. I do not entirely blame Qantas for acting bilaterally when it does not know the rules of the game which ASEAN is playing. I am quite sure that Singapore Airlines Ltd, when it is negotiating with European countries in regard to their airlines does not negotiate with the European Economic Community and would be quite annoyed if any member of the European Economic Community suddenly dived for the cover of the EEC without Singapore Airlines knowing. Singapore seems to want it both ways. It also claims to be a Third World nation, but I have doubts about that.

During the Committee's inquiries into the question of financing Asian students who attend Australian universities, there was quite a bit of discussion. I agree with my colleagues that we should increase the number of talented students we sponsor from the less privileged families in South East Asia. However, I point out to the Senate that we can do a lot more effective work to assist to train some of the young men and women in the manual trades in Thailand and in Indonesia. It is all very well training academics and having a troop of chiefs but not enough Indians. When these people return to their country they find that there are not enough trained men for them to work with. I feel that we could do a lot more in that area.

The Committee had the opportunity, while it was in Bangkok, to visit a school which was set up by the International Labour Organisation. Instructors were supplied to teach the instructors on trade training methods for the young men and women in Thailand. We found that they were very much in need of funds. They wanted only simple technical books. They were not getting the trade training which we would get here in Australia, but what they were taught were the basics of the trade which would equip them for the industrialisation of that country. Both Germany and Japan were assisting in every way possible, and a lot of credit went to Germany and Japan because they saw the potential there. I am afraid that Australia is lacking very badly in its level of assistance in the training of some of these young people in the manual arts. We should have a lot more craftsmen in those countries and we can do a lot more towards training them.

The Senate Committee report was originally tabled in December 1980. There was correspondence between the President and the Committee with regard to the availability of finance for travel. I should like to say a word or two on that subject. Senators take a great pride in the committee system. Indeed, when one listens to most honourable senators talking about the parliamentary system one finds that they seem to hold the committee system very high in their list of priorities. One must give credit to the Government for issuing a directive to Ministers that they should reply to recommendations contained in committee reports within six months of their being tabled. However, that directive is not always complied with.

The lack of funds for travel reduced the role of the committee to a rather farcial one. Let me explain what happens in regard to a committee such as the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The committee secretary inserts notices in the national papers seeking submissions from organisations or from individuals who feel that they have something to contribute in the field of foreign affairs. Only a small section of a community is deeply concerned with foreign affairs. Many people are not willing or are not able to contribute. The number of people is cut down further when they find that they must come before a committee or transfer their thoughts to writing. As Senator Primmer said when he spoke to the report, they are inclined to see things through Australian eyes. If one cares to check the list of those submissions and the people who put in those submissions-apart from government departments whose submissions we could not do without and to which we look forward on each occasion-one seems to meet, on a repetitive basis, the same half-dozen academics. I am not belittling them. In fact we are much indebted to them for their points of view. But it becomes a very different story when the Committee has contact with those who have been personally involved in an area covered by a particular term of reference, when the committee meets people on their home ground when they feel completely at ease and when they can communicate with the members of the Committee on their own terms. I assure honourable senators that it becomes an entirely different ball game. Again, if one reads the submissions before one has exposure to a topic and then reads those submissions after one has exposure to the topic, one sees the matters entirely differently. For example, the way in which we see Australian-ASEAN relations and the way in which the people living in the five ASEAN nations see them are quite different.

I refer the Senate to the statements made by Senator Sim and the late Senator Knight to the Senate that Australian ignorance of neighbouring states and peoples is considerably regrettable. Our ignorance is almost overwhelming and at some future time could react seriously against us. I should just like to refer to what Professor Kernial Sandhu said. He was of the opinion that Australia's standing in South East Asia was not as high as one might imagine. He felt that on a bilateral basis Australia could talk with equality. However ASEAN countries see themselves as an association, and when being dealt with as an association they feel that they have a greater power than Australia. He equated this with the situation of America and Europe being looked up to as greater powers than ASEAN. However, Australia, irrespective of her Anglo-Saxon attitudes, was not considered an equal to ASEAN.

I feel that the difference between each ASEAN nation and ASEAN as a group is something that is not appreciated by most Australians. It was quite clear to most of the members who travelled to the ASEAN nations that the Australian image was not as great as we imagined it to be. For example, there was little knowledge of Australian politics in South East Asia. An awareness of Australia was sadly lacking there. Professor Kernial Sandhu went so far as to say that if there was any great interest in Australian politics in South East Asia and if there were any Asians who had studied Australian politics in Australia, he would be prepared to employ them tomorrow. So there is a necessity for us to try to project our image a lot more than we do. Understanding is like friendship; it is a two-way process. We met many people who had an appalling lack of understanding of what our social and political set-up was. Some people still place us as part of the European or American scene. We were convinced more than ever of the necessity for Australia to project its image a lot more. In the report we suggested that films were one of the most effective ways of projecting the Australian image in South East Asia.

I will deal for a moment with our relationship with South East Asia, how we are understood and should be understood. I will quote from a speech that was given by the Australian Ambassador to the Philippines, Richard Woolcott. He was the man left holding the baby, so to speak, during the brutal annexation of East Timor by Indonesia. At the time when a caretaker government was in power here, he was placed in the most unenviable position of being left with that problem on his plate. At a lecture he said:

Where, then, does Australia fit into this regional picture at this time? Australia, as an isolated continent, of mainly European social origin at the southern end of the world, faced, until relatively recently, three choices in its search for an identity in the world.

Firstly, we could have tried to cling to the perception of Australia as a western outpost in South East Asia, in which case we would probably now be seen as a sort of Anglo-American step-child which never really grew up; a second-hand transplated society, in danger of losing its momentum before it decided what it really wanted to be.

Secondly, we could have sought to retreat into our own vast and relatively remote continent. We could have tried to turn our backs on the problems of our less fortunate and more populous neighbours. We could have attempted to isolate ourselves and sought to live a bucolic, inwards-looking, materialist, self-satisfied, apathetic and pleasure-seeking national life-like innocent nihilists drifting in a remote southern Squaresville of our own making.

Or, thirdly, we could work to become a distinctive, tolerant, co-operative, accepted and well regarded middle power, in the world community at large, but especially in the region in which we live, the Asian and Pacific region.

I think that we all like to think that we fall into the third category outlined by Mr Woolcott. But in order to fall into that third category, we have to live up to high moral principles which sometimes I wonder whether we are capable of doing. I believe that we try to live up to his image in many fields. However, in the field of aid I think that we fall somewhat short of the principles that Mr Woolcott pointed out. Senator Primmer, on 4 December, informed the Senate about our concern in regard to the lack of study into the social consequences of our aid projects. We did not have much time to take a close look at the projects in the Philippines but I remember one or two senators making a report on our aid projects there. They made a glowing report but I do not know how deeply they looked into the social impact of the projects. I certainly think that we should take a closer look at our aid programs there.

However, the social consequences of those schemes is something that, if possible, I would like to see the Committee take on board in its terms of reference. It should have a closer look at our aid programs. Senator Primmer gave one or two illustrations of aid being given to Indonesia through an agriculture research project near Bogor. There were one or two instances where we felt that the assistance which should be helping people was not doing what we had hoped. For example, we felt that the assistance given to the people in most need-the workers-fell rather short of the desired objective. The particular program that gave me most concern was that in Trengganu. The Trengganu hydro-electric project involves the building of a large dam, the creation of a lake in the rain forest area, eight saddle dams and a variety of other infrastructure including access roads. When we looked at this project I questioned the offices of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation about the social impact of the project on the local fishing industry. They did not seem to have many answers to my questions. What I had on my mind at the time was what happened in Sardinia when the Russians built the Aswan dam. People who were making a living from the fishing industry in Sardinia were deprived of their living because of the deprivation of silt caused by the building of this large dam. Hundreds of kampongs around the area in Malaysia will be affected by the building of the Trengganu dam.

Because I was not satisfied with the answers from SMEC I started to make some investigations when I returned to Australia. The information that I looked up suggested that the Trengganu project was investigated and approved as a matter of urgency because the electric power produced was required for the national grid system by 1982. A series of feasibility studies were initiated in 1974 by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation in association with the Malaysian Engineering Corporation. However Malaysia decided that it wanted the project started as soon as possible and, before a proper feasibility study was completed of the Trengganu area, it started to build the dam sites and everything else associated. I realise, of course, that we could get out of that situation by saying that the responsibility falls squarely on the shoulders of the Malaysian Government. After all it was its decision. But if we are interested in aid and the effectiveness of aid, we should also be concerned about the social impact of that aid.

A further report in 1978, four years after the project had started, was commissioned by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. It commissioned Environmental Planning Associates to look into the social impact. If honourable senators read its report, they will see that there is a lack of information on which to make a full and detailed assessment of the social impact on the fishing industry of that nation. I also had a look at the report that came from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. In its most recent annual report it briefly discussed the problems of environmental issues and development projects. The report stated that there is a growing international concern that attention should be given to the environmental factors in the development of aid programs. I wonder just how many of our aid programs we have looked into thoroughly, especially with regard to their environmental impact.

Again I plead with honourable senators that we allow the Committee to look more closely at our aid projects. I am not in the least satisfied that we have studied this aspect through to a logical conclusion. I feel that projects are a waste of money if they do not benefit the people they are intended to benefit. I feel that in Malaysia thousands of people will be thrown out of work and lose their livings because of the fishing industry there. Therefore, I think we should look more closely at the environmental impact of all of our aid projects. Indeed, I would go as far as to suggest that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has a permanent environmental officer on its staff. This is something that the Corporation does not have at the moment. I feel quite strongly about that subject and believe that such an officer should be employed. I will close on that note. Once again I compliment Senator Sim on his chairmanship of the Committee. He will be missed when, later this year, he retires.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate to speak briefly. I welcome the opportunity to speak in this general debate on foreign affairs. I join with other honourable senators in paying my respects to Senator Sim who has now made, as he described it, his last speech on this subject in this place, although I will believe that when I see it. We have all admired his sometimes independent approach to the subject of foreign affairs and his informed contribution to such debates even though sometimes we have differed mildly with his opinions. On 26 February, several contributions were made to this debate on foreign affairs papers on subjects which ranged in some cases around the world several times. Among these contributions was a speech by my colleague, Senator Wheeldon, and on the same day, incidentally, comments by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Senator Wheeldon at the end of his speech made the following statements which I quote from Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: We have to face the fact that the era of detente is over. We have to face the fact that no longer does our major like-minded country, the United States of America, believe that it is possible to secure peace merely by netogiation; that it can be achieved only if the United States greatly increases its strength. This places greatly different burdens and greatly different requirements upon us, whatever one's opinion may be of some of the other views I have expressed during what I was just saying. Things are not what they were before the elections of last November; they are now quite different and Australia will have to find a way to accommodate itself and to influence the new course of events.

One cannot help but agree with Senator Wheeldon's last remarks even if many of us would disagree with some of the remarks made earlier in his speech about various regions in the world. Certainly we do have to reassess our position; we certainly have to realise that things are different. Although we cannot throw out the possibility of detente quite as freely as Senator Wheeldon did, we certainly have to accept that we have to accommodate ourselves to a new set of circumstances. The problem that I have found, and the problem I think Senator Mason found when he was speaking in the debate, is that the Government has learned nothing. The Government has not adapted itself to the new set of circumstances of the post-Vietnam era. In fact, the Government retains its policy of agreeing with everything that the United States does and says be it in respect of Central America or Asia. I believe that this can be demonstrated by the Government's approval of the United States increasing its military aid to El Salvador and decreasing or ceasing much of its aid to countries like Nicaragua because it believes that most of the arms going to El Salvador in fact come from or through Nicaragua.

Like Senator Mason and other honourable senators in this place, I think that this is a dangerous attitude for the United States. It is even more dangerous, I believe, for countries like Australia just to accept that attitude and not try to influence. It seems to me that the Government's view is that we must unquestionably accept the views of the world, of President Reagan and of General Haig and therefore unquestionably accept the United States approach to El Salvador, to Central American countries in general and, more recently, to South American countries. We must accept that attitude of the United States that claims that it will support any country which proclaims itself anti-communist no matter how repressive or what sort of dictatorship governs there. The simple fact that these countries call themselves anti-communist or the United States has a suspicion that Cuba or any other communist country is supporting a revolution in such a place is enough reason for the United States and countries like Australia to interfere.

It seems to me unfortunate that people on both sides of politics in this country and indeed, in other countries, take such a selective view on foreign affairs and particularly on human rights around the world. The implication seems to be that depending on one's view there is a difference between torture in a right wing country or torture in a left wing country and that invasion of sovereignty of a country of the same political persuasion is not all right but that the invasion of sovereignty of a country of the opposite political persuasion is okay. Guns in the streets of San Salvador or Tehran are worse than guns in the streets of Prague or Warsaw. I do not think there is a need, or is it desirable, for countries like Australia to take sides because as a small country we should condemn, in my opinion, the destruction and diminution of human rights wherever they occur. As a country we should protest when our alleged ally, Malaysia, gaols two members of parliament, members of the Democratic Action Party, a democratic party and member of the Socialist International. They were gaoled without trial and kept in gaol by a Minister. We should not remain silent, as I believe this Government has remained silent, when that sort of thing occurs in our region. We should not remain silent or passive as we have at first the threatened hanging and then the gaoling of people such as Kim Dai Jung any more than we should remain silent at the treatment of dissidents in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or at the treatment of political prisoners in any communist country in the world. While I share the view that those who support democracy should support each other, that does not mean, I believe, that they should support regimes which abuse human rights, indulge in torture of citizens or act to deprive people of socialist rights through repression or even inequality because they follow a blind opposition to communism. Nor should we remain silent in the face of the abuse of human rights in any country, for similar reasons. To do so, to support governments and groups for such reasons, has the effect of driving those fighting repression into the camps supported by other totalitarian regimes. I have heard Senator Wheeldon argue persuasively in this place that the United States attitude was a factor in driving Castro's Cuba firmly into the communist camp.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in his speeches on Vietnam.

—We heard that many times in his speeches on Vietnam. It has been put in this chamber that United States funding of the intervention in Angola by mercenary paratroopers from Zaire gave Cuba later the excuse to paint itself as a non-aligned country coming to the rescue-coming in after the United States came in. I believe it does little good to condemn Cuba for its intervention in Angola because it is outside its sphere of influence and at the same time to ignore United States intervention in that area.
—What about the French?

—It does little good to ignore French intervention in other areas. We certainly should not, and do not, ignore intervention by the USSR in both Europe and Asia in that sort of situation. I believe the problem is further complicated by the fact that national pride and national feeling are potent forces in most of the countries that are involved in the sorts of internal conflicts which led to the situation in El Salvador. Those who believe it is their duty to fight repression, murder, torture and social inequality in their country-who would deny that it is their duty to do so-are nationalistic as a rule and have no desire to see that internal repression replaced by external repression. To introduce a foreigner to interfere in the affairs of the country, be he from the United States, the Soviet Union or anywhere else, frequently causes a coalition of disparate groups interested in self-determination and in proudly developing their nation. That, I believe, leads us to the problem that is present in El Salvador, a country in which I have a personal interest because of my friendship with people from neighbouring Nicaragua who recently were involved in a similar struggle.

SPEECH.PARA: El Salvador is a tiny and poor country with a population of about five million. It is the most densely populated country in Latin America. It is a country beset by poverty, by lack of services, by incredible differences between rich and poor and by inequitable land distribution. Fifty per cent of the arable land is owned by 300 families and power has been basically in the hands of 14 or 20 families for some 50 years through military dictatorships. If we add to that presence for many years, and still, of a government controlled, quasi-military force-the ORDEN-which was described aptly in newspapers in Australia recently as a series of goon squads, which started in the days of the infamous President Umberto Romero and which has been repressing people throughout the countryside out of control for many years, there are in that country all the prerequisites of a revolution. Since the 1930s all so-called leftist parties have been labelled communist. Ruthless activities have been used to suppress those alleged communists. Well documented stories of mass murder, of torture and of repression in the community have emerged and have been unquestioned in the Western Press and by those who have made a study of the area.

Certainly in 1979 President Umberto Romero was overthrown by another military dictatorship and President Jose Duarte, who was a christian democrat politician, as Senator Wheeldon has said, was brought back and installed. But he is utterly dependent on and constantly under the threat of the military which in fact runs the dictatorship in that country. The activities of the ORDEN continue, and torture, murder and repression have been commonplace. Unemployment remains at 50 per cent and the situation is and obviously has been desperate. President Reagan's response to this is to increase military aid, to send in military advisers and, if necessary, to send in American troops in a show of strength because of the alleged Cuban supply of arms-I do not doubt that the Cubans have been assisting in the supply of arms in this area-and because of the assistance and support allegedly given by other communist nations. I think it is worth while pointing out that not only nations from the Soviet bloc have supported the efforts of guerrillas and others in El Salvador to overthrow the Government and to improve conditions in that country. Many European countries, including West Germany, Sweden and others which are considered friendly to this nation, have given support to their brothers and sisters in a movement in El Salvador because one of the parties involved in that movement is a compatriot party in Socialist International.

No one denies the presence of Cuban-supplied arms in El Salvador. But from looking during the last few years and the last few weeks at documents and publications from right across the political spectrum and from looking at overseas newspapers, I can find no suggestion at all, as was suggested two weeks ago in this place, of the presence of Cuban forces in El Salvador. But there is ample evidence that both United States arms and advisers are in the country supporting the regime. We hear a lot about what is said by various people closely involved in the situation in El Salvador. I think it is worth while examining some of those things. I wish to quote the words of Professor Jeanne Kirkpatrick, President Reagan's Ambassador to the United Nations. She summed up the dilemma which faces those who would want to support the United States action unquestioningly when she said:

If we are confronted with the choice between offering assistance to a moderately repressive autocratic government which is also friendly to the United States and permitting them to be overrun by a Cuban-trained, Cuban-armed, Cuban-sponsored insurgency, we would assist the moderate autocracy.

As Senator Mason said, that is the sort of thing that was said to justify the intervention in Vietnam. The implications of this are clear: Any repressive dictatorship such as that recently of President Somoza in Nicaragua-he was President for 37 or 40 years-will be supported by the United States if its opponents are supported by the Cubans.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least President Carter had the right policy there.

—Carter certainly had more concern for human rights and, therefore, took a different policy. But other people close to the scene and equally concerned had different things to say. Archbishop Romero, who was murdered in his church for condemning the junta-inspired murders, said just before his death in February last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of promoting greater injustice and peace in El Salvador (military aid) will no doubt sharpen the injustice and repression against the organisations of the people who repeatedly have been struggling to gain respect for their most fundamental human rights. The present junta have resorted to repressive violence, producing a total of death and injuries much greater than in the recent military regime.
His successor, Archbishop Rivera y Damas, said on 7 September last year:

Five thousand five hundred people have been murdered since 1 June-80 per cent by the army and national security forces and the remainder by parliamentary death squads with army protection. Twenty-seven thousand families have been evacuated, ten priests have been murdered and churches have been sacked and desecrated. The repression we are now suffering is worse than the sadism and bloody cruelty in the days of President Romero.

Robert White, former United States Ambassador to El Salvador who was sacked because of his views, was described in scathing terms by members of President Reagan's group as a social reformer, which apparently has become a pejorative term in the United States today. He has been an outspoken critic of the United States policy of propping up the junta. He has said that such policies are wrong and will drive those people desperately trying to hold a position of social, economic and political reform through democracy and persuasion, to the far Left because of the hopelessness of the situation. On his return to the United States the former ambassador has repeatedly said, from direct knowledge of the place, that the real threat in his view is from the extreme Right. He said:
There is no demonstrable need for putting United States military advisers into El Salvador. It would put El Salvador in the position of being a vassal State.
The issue is not military aid. The issue is how you are going to supply military aid to a military force that is killing and assassinating thousands and thousands of people down there.

Many other organisations in the world have repeatedly warned of the dangers of a new Vietnam situation arising if the United States does not stop supporting repressive, unpopular and totalitarian regimes because they happen to say that they are anti-communist. It is hopeful that Willy Brandt, the President of Socialist International, an organisation which has persistently called for talks and a reasonable and sensible solution to the problems in El Salvador, is at last being called in to assist in trying to end this difficult and dangerous situation. He has said, Amnesty International, the church and people with knowledge in the area have said that if the United States continues to support every repressive, dictatorial, murdering and torturing regime in Central America, it will lose all the respect of those seeking to assist the abused, the starving and the downtrodden people of this benighted part of the world. If such aid, with our support, goes automatically to those who say they support the United States while standing literally on the bodies of their countrymen they will receive no respect. We cannot intervene directly. We cannot, as an individual nation, have much of an effect on this situation. But we may be able to, I believe, in combination with others, by taking a consistent attitude to the abuse of human rights and the abuse of human freedoms everywhere, be it in communist countries or in non-communist countries. We may be able to play some part, as I hope Willy Brandt can play some part, in reaching some sane and sensible solution to the sorts of problems which occur in El Salvador.

What is certain is that if we follow blindly the policies which are being pursued now we put ourselves in the position of being an inconsequential nation, blind followers of our masters as are the satellites of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for that matter. This path, I suggest, has a great danger of leading inevitably to another Vietnam situation which no one wants to see again. Therefore I suggest and hope that we will not persist with the foreign policy in this area that I fear the present Government will persist with if we can judge from the statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Mr Street and the statements relayed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in this place.

I hope that we do take an independent stance as a freedom loving nation, of condemning the abuse of civil rights and freedom wherever it may occur. I am pleased that, unlike the situation which existed in the days of Vietnam, the editorials in the newspapers in this country-in the Canberra Times, the Age, and the Sydney Morning Herald which are respected newspapers-have questioned and in many cases condemned the sort of stance we are taking. The Government is seen internationally in this situation as speaking for all of us in the Parliament from all sides of the political spectrum in this country. I believe the Government should take a closer look at, analyse and be more careful about the attitude it has taken to the situation than it has up until now.
Questions resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS RELATING TO SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Progress Report on Australian Marine Science: Government Response
