Debate resumed from 27 November 1980, 2 December 1980 and 4 December 1980 on motions:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
and
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to participate in the debate this evening on this series of reports on science and the environment and in particular, to relate the remarks that I will make to the annual report of the Department of Science and the Environment and the annual report of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. The subject that I wish to put before the Senate this evening is one which, I think, has not been considered by the Senate before; that is, the question of the administration and regulation of genetic engineering in Australia at the moment and the proper role of the Commonwealth Government in the control and regulation of what is, in fact, likely to develop as one of the great growth industries in the whole world.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just that we are dealing with matters which are themselves purely commercial or, indeed, purely scientific, because the first point to make, I think, is that in essence these debates are ethical debates. We are, for instance, dealing with questions such as the legal and moral aspects of test tube babies. We are dealing with the legal and moral aspects of genetic manipulation and the possible creation of new forms of life. Mr Justice Gordon Samuel of the New South Wales Supreme Court several months ago drew attention to this problem when, in writing in the journal called Quarterly, published by the University of New South Wales, he indicated that he saw a need for comprehensive legislation on the question of the legal and moral aspects of test tube babies. Consideration should be given to the enormous questions, for instance, of their exact legal parentage, their inheritance rights, the relationship between them and their natural parents and between them and what one might call their surrogate parents. To that extent this debate is a serious ethical debate and undoubtedly the Commonwealth, which has made great steps in a number of these fields-for instance, in its legislation about removing the stigma attached to illegitimate children-will have to face up to its legislative responsibilities in these issues. At the moment treatment of disease, and treatment of cancer in particular, is one of the things at the forefront of medical research.

In a number of areas it is believed that the recent discoveries in genetic engineering may bring about some hope for people suffering from currently terminal medical diseases. But, at the same time, we are now in a situation of seeing, for instance, in the United States that experiments are taking place using new genetic discoveries on human patients without regard to the normal standards which are required in these matters. For instance, in the very learned journal Science on 24 October 1980 it was indicated that two patients suffering from the disease thalassemia had been treated with a new genetic discovery by researchers at the University of California in Los Angeles without the endorsement of the University's Human Subjects Use Committee. In other words, a medical discovery, potentially life-saving for diseases such as sickle-cell anaemia, already is being used on patients without regard to the established patterns of proper use of new discoveries and drugs on human subjects. It has often been speculated how quickly we will move towards a Brave New World situation. I was intrigued, if not disturbed, to read a report last December in the Sydney Morning Herald, and I will quote to the Senate part of that report:

A Shanghai newspaper claimed this week that a chimpanzee, artificially inseminated by scientists with human sperm, was three months pregnant when the Cultural Revolution put a stop to the experiment in 1967.
Discussing the experiment, the report referred to the comments of Dr Ji, the head of the scientific unit:
Dr Ji said a 'near-human ape' would be able to serve mankind. It would have a higher intelligence and therefore could perform simple tasks. It could also be taught to speak.

I do not know whether there are any grounds for believing scientific reports from Shanghai, but certainly the reputation of the Chinese Academy of Sciences is one not to be discounted. However, if we are to believe that experiments of that sort are under way, we would want to be sure that in Australia the work that is being done is being done within what we would regard as ethical guidelines. I shall speak later about the work being done at the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National Uiversity into the breeding of certain animals and the development of animals by the manipulation of their genetic qualities and characters. It may be that the report about genetic engineering in China does not need to be taken too seriously by this Parliament, but it raises questions in view of the fact that these things are now theoretically within the technical competence of medical researchers in the field of genetic engineering. The fact that frogs and lesser animals have already been bred in this sense and that the techniques available are themselves not different in kind, although they are in degree, from those being used in experiments touching on human beings, needs to be of concern to this Parliament.

The second question that arises, although at this stage it may not seem immediately related, is the question of Australian patent law and the impact it will have on the medical profession and on genetic engineering in general. This issue arises because we are talking about procedures, we are talking about experiments, we are talking about processes which may yield hundreds of millions of dollars to somebody holding a patent over them. The Hoffman-La Roche patent rip-off on valium looks like kids' play in comparison with what might be the situation not just with tranquillisers but with life-saving drugs. This matter came to a head in the United States with the work of an Indian scientist by the name of Chakrabarty, who was working on the development of a microbe called pseudomonas which would be used to eat oil spills, in effect. Essentially, a bacteria which consumes hydrocarbons on the surface of the water would be released into an area polluted by oil, apparently doing no harm to the sea environment but capable of eating the oil spill.

Needless to say, it was believed that there was a potentially very significant commercial benefit to be gained from all this, and an attempt was made to patent the discovery and the life-form pseudomonas. The magazine Science, reporting this in April 1980, was very concerned that the matter should be settled finally in the United States courts. Since 1793 the United States has had a fairly complicated but also fairly open-ended scheme of patent legislation. The appeal went backwards and forwards between the lower courts and the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals and the Patent Office in the United States. The Court of Customs and Patent Appeals batted both cases back to the Patent Office, with the ruling that the claims for the patent should be allowed. It indicated that it could not be the intent of existing patent law to deny patentability to something just because it is alive. Indeed, the court said:

We do not see any reason to deprive it or its creator or owner of the protection and advantages of the patent system by excluding it from the (statute's) categories of patentable inventions on the sole ground that it is alive. It is because it is alive that it is useful.
The court went on:
In short, we think the fact that microorganisms, as distinguished from chemical compounds, are alive, is a distinction without legal significance.

The matter was eventually tested in the Supreme Court of the United States. In a five to four decision, the court ruled in June 1980 that life forms could be subject to patent. Chief Justice Burger said:

We are told that genetic research and related technological developments may spread pollution and disease, and may result in a loss of genetic diversity, and that its practise may tend to deprecate the value of human life.
These arguments are forcefully, even powerfully presented; they remind us that at times human ingenuity seems unable to control fully the forces it creates.
The grant or denial of patent on microorganisms is not likely to put an end to genetic research or its attendant risks.

Two points arise from that United States decision. The first is that because of our entry into international co-operative patent arrangements there will be some patents granted in the United States which will have applicability in Australia. In the other place on 19 February 1980 Dr Klugman put a question on notice to Mr Newman, who at that stage was responsible for productivity, in which he asked, among other things:
Does Australian patent legislation allow for living organisms to be patented?
At page 985 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 19 March 1980 Mr Newman replied:

The Australian patent legislation does not specifically exclude inventions concerned with living organisms from patent protection. The criteria for accepting an application relating to a living organism is therefore the same as for any other invention.

It is quite clear that Australian patent legislation allows the patentability of life forms and the discoveries which may be made by Australian genetic engineers. I think this Parliament needs to ask itself whether that is the accidental consequence of the legislation or whether it was the intention of the Australian legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am wondering why we need the plant rights legislation.

—Senator Georges raises a most interesting point. Given the operation of Australian patent laws, why has the debate about plant variety rights reached the levels it has? It seems to me that patentability of living organisms is exactly the same as patentability of living crops in that sense, and the debate about plant variety rights may already be a debate settled in Australian law. Those who are getting worked up about the plant variety rights debate may well find that they have to go back a little further to do their homework. The important thing about genetic engineering in this sense is the sheer size to which it can grow in financial terms. The genetic engineering companies that have gone public are the highest fliers on Wall Street. They are the boom stocks, in the way that Kodak and Polaroid and Xerox were the boom stocks, in the way that IBM was a boom stock for many years in terms of its internal shares. It is quite clear that small companies have been making enormous profits from this development.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, early in 1980 Inco Ltd, which is a fairly small company in the genetic development field, sold its stake in Genentech Inc., for $5.2m. The value of that package of shares would now be well in excess of $15m. Let us look at the sorts of things which are under investigation. Brazil, for instance, has been using genetic engineering techniques to develop alcohol as a fuel. The Cetus Corporation, a major research corporation, has been doing research on yeasts and other substances. Genetically engineered yeast could improve fermentation. As I will mention later, there is even a proposal to develop interferon, which was described in the latest issue of Newsweek. The article referred to the development of micro-organisms to combat malaria and hoof and mouth disease, as it is called in the United States. One of the companies involved is the Monsanto Chemical Company. The report states:

A Monsanto spokesman says the company plans to ''develop and evaluate'' the use of bacteria to synthesise chemicals that now require expensive, energy-intensive processes. And Inco has a direct stake in research that Cawthorn describes as ''bordering on science fiction''-the use of bacteria in mining.

Within the genetic engineering field a process is developing for the use of bacteria in mining. In fact, bacteria would be released into soils, mines and various places that bear minerals. We would allow the bacteria to extract the mineral or the substance concerned out of the ground. The prospect of releasing large amounts of bacteria for the purpose of commercial mining again is a matter which currently appears to be totally unregulated by any legislation in Australia. Enormous financial possibilities are at stake. The development of synthetic insulin will bring about a change in a market which is currently worth more than $100m a year. That is the size of the insulin market. It is currently in a state of total confusion because of the breakup of the existing insulin sales arrangements by people who are starting to market commercially produced insulin-produced by technical processes-instead of by processes which are currently cumbersome and expensive and which rely in the first instance upon the production of certain animal materials for the insulin to be extracted. I have said that a number of companies are now involved in the genetic engineering field which are already public companies. I will cite just a few of these companies. Genentech Inc., which was founded in 1976, is probably the leader in the field. It is seeking to make commercial quantities of interferon which is alleged to be the wonder drug for the defeat of cancer. The Cetus Corporation was founded only a decade or so ago. There is also Biogen SA of Geneva. The Genex Corporation started in 1977. The battles are going on between the companies for the services of leading scientists around the world. They are now not merely scientists; they are Nobel prize winners, and they are becoming instant millionaires because of their discoveries in the field of genetic engineering. The patents that accrue to them are reshaping the way in which scientific work is being done around the world. The Australian Financial Review of 15 April 1980 carried a report stating:
The British Government has been urged in a report from its scientific advisers to treat biotechnology-including genetic engineering-as seriously as it treats micro-electronics.

I raised this matter by way of a question in the Senate on 21 April 1980. I asked the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) for some information about the extent to which Australia is supporting research in biotechnology. I received a lengthy letter dated 20 June 1980 from Mr Thomson in response to that question. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Science and the Environment Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600 10 June 1980 Dear Senator Puplick,

In his response to your question concerning biotechnology, which you asked in the Senate on 21 April 1980, Senator Chaney advised that he would arrange for additional information to be provided. This letter is intended to fulfil his undertaking.

The article on biotechnology in the Financial Review of 15 April 1980 dwelt on the recommendations of a particular Report prepared in the United Kingdom. My Department has not yet obtained a copy of the Report and thus the following information should be viewed in that context.

From the article it would appear that the U.K. Report focussed on that part of biotechnology which is, or will be, dependent upon genetic engineering or more precisely on what is becoming known as recombinant DNA technology. This involves adding to or changing the genetic make-up of an organism such that it performs a new or improved task of value to man.

As an example, research is at an advanced stage in attempting to persuade a bacterium to produce human insulin. Once successful it will be possible for this bacterium to be produced in large batches and the insulin separated out. Thus, a ready supply, on whatever scale, will become available and dependence on the far less satisfactory and relatively rare animal insulins will be unnecessary.

In 1978 the Executive of the CSIRO commissioned an investigation into the role of the recombinant DNA technique in research. The Report, released in July 1979, concluded that the application of the technique was already of immense value as a research tool and within the near future would be likely to produce commercially viable opportunities in applied microbiology. Other applications were also likely but the time scale was considerably longer.

It should be noted that to our knowledge no research group has produced commercially viable amounts of products by this technique. At the same time the CSIRO study clearly indicated that the potential range of application was broad and that Australia should be able to develop expertise and technology in particular areas and thus obtain world markets.

A number of Commonwealth departments and agencies have been monitoring the progress of research involving the recombinant DNA technique for several years. The Departments of Science and the Environment, of Health and the CSIRO have been prominent in this regard.

In addition the Australian Academy of Science has been most active in this area. It has not only operated a peer group monitoring system but it has taken a lead role in the evaluation of the potential of this technology. It has received the Government's support in performing this role.

The Academy is currently undertaking a comprehensive review of this subject area with a view to formulating recommendations on the safe exploitation of new opportunities in genetic engineering. This study has been underway for some months and I am advised that the Report will be available to the Government shortly.
Upon receipt of this Report it is the intention of the Government that a policy covering the safe exploitation of this technology will be promptly developed.

Neither the Financial Review article nor your question was limited to recombinant DNA technology. Thus, it is appropriate to make some comment about biotechnology in general. As you will appreciate, biotechnology encompasses an extremely broad range of processes. All industrial processes involving living organisms or their active products fall within the definition of biotechnology.

In this broader context the CSIRO has been active in biotechnology for many years. Some of its current programs include the production of fuel ethanol from sugar beet, the conversion of agricultural waste into gaseous and liquid fuels and the use of micro-organisms to enhance oil recovery from oil wells and oil shale.

I am advised that the Department of Productivity is materially assisting a number of biotechnology programs as part of its more general industry assistance activities. In particular two projects have received public interest funding under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act, namely the commercial development of both the 'bionic' ear (University of Melbourne) and enzyme laballed immuno assay systems (Royal Prince Charles Hospital, Brisbane).

In summary, therefore, the Government is aware of the recent research advances involving the recombinant DNA technique and, in co-operation with various experts, has been monitoring advances and is proceeding towards the development of necessary policies for the safe exploitation of these advances.
Your sincerely, DAVID THOMSON Senator C. Puplick,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that this development appears at the moment-if one had purely taken note of the companies I have mentioned-to be very much one that does not concern Australia. Yet the truth of the matter is that Australian scientists are at the forefront of research in genetic engineering. Regrettably, as with so many of our major scientific advances, they are not receiving the support from governments and from institutions which one would have thought they ought to be given. For instance, a report of the Sydney Morning Herald a few months ago stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A young Australian scientist is emerging as a leading researcher in a biological revolution that is expected to have far-reaching medical, industrial and social consequences.
Dr John Shine, of the Australian National University, has, with a team of American scientists, succeeded in genetically engineering bacteria to ''manufacture'' a promising therapeutic drug.
It is beta-endorphin, which researchers believe could prove valuable in the treatment of pain, some illnesses, high blood pressure and diarrhoea.

One reads in the Weekend Australian magazine in January 1980 of the work of a young scientist, Dr Jim McInnes, and a Dr Ray Harris of the South Australian Institute of Technology. They are involved in research on interferon which, as I said, is currently supposed to be the world's great new wonder drug. It is enormously expensive just to produce a few grams. These doctors say that in the work they are doing in the United States they are on the verge of producing interferon 'by the bucketful'. It will cost thousands of dollars compared with millions of dollars spent in the United States. Yet Dr Harris and Dr McInnes find that, typical among these situations, their work is in jeopardy because of the lack of government support for medical research.

What will happen? Australian cancer patients will be required to pay enormous sums for access to interferon treatment because the patents for the drugs are held in the United States when in Adelaide people are at work producing the substance in large quantities and at low cost. It is possible that they could get the patent for their process under Australian legislation but they cannot complete the work because there is not a few extra hundred thousand dollars allocated for medical research. One sees in the United States the major work being done at the University of California on genetic engineering. The team there is led by an Australian scientist, Dr John Baxter. Undoubtedly, he is working there because the contribution that he has to make is appreciated far more in the United States than in Australia. The National Times in its weekly issue for 27 July to 2 August 1980 led with the heading: 'Genetic engineering; Australia misses out'. Unless we are very careful about the role of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the role of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the role of the Department of Science and Technology in Australia we will deprive ourselves as a people and as a nation of enormous benefits not only as individual human beings but also in terms of patents and medical cost savings.

The Bulletin on 3 March 1981 carried an article entitled 'Australia's biotechnology bid' in which Dr John Hurrell and his colleagues at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in Melbourne state that they believe they were making great strides towards the development of a technique to detect early warning pains and symptoms in people who are on the verge of a heart attack. That is a point that ought to be fresh in the memories of many honourable senators. Heart attacks do not occur just among our colleagues. They are the greatest single cause of death in Australia. A group at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories says that it is on the verge of making some breakthrough in the process of recognising the danger signs at an early stage. Dr Hurrell said:
The need to get our foot in the biotechnology door is becoming more urgent.

The head of the Department of Immunology of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, Dr Graham Mitchell, explained the concern which he and his colleagues have about the lack of funds which is preventing scientists of great quality in Australia from taking the next step, which is important.

Honourable senators will recall that last year, I think it was, we passed amendments to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act. We agreed that the previous restriction on the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in undertaking research-it had previously been limited I think to non-biological areas-should be opened up and that the Laboratories should be allowed to get into new fields. We said that that would be done by regulation. Statutory Rule No. 7 of 1981, Commonwealth Serum Laboratories regulations, describes the sorts of things that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in terms of classes of pharmaceutical products are allowed to get into. They now include: Agents derived from blood and tissue and synthetic analogues of such agents, agents derived from micro-organisms and synthetic analogues of such agents, agents for parentathal therapy into toxic agents, immunological agents, and laboratory agents and devices. So, we have within the very considerable resources of our own Commonwealth Serum Laboratories the facility to go ahead and do some of this work.

Again I refer to an article in the National Times. It was headed: 'Australia ready to test Interferon as cancer cure'. Again it refers to the work of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in Melbourne and the plan to begin the first Australian clinical trials of interferon in the course of the next couple of months. Dr McCarthy, the director of CSL, also stated that, in the longer term, CSL plans to study interferon as a treatment for multiple sclerosis in conjunction with other conventional methods. Other studies of multiple sclerosis had recently begun in the United States.

We are miles along some of these tracks. I refer to some of the work being done with animals at the Australian National University. Immunology researchers in the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the ANU recently announced that they had produced the world's first mixed species twin cattle consisting of a European species, Bos Taurus, Fresian calf and a Brahmin calf of the completely separate Indian cattle species, Bos Indicus. The unique animal specimens were produced by the transplant of a Fresian embryo into the uterus of a Brahmin cow who carried the foreign offspring together with a normal foetus of her own. This facility for what is called tetraparentalism-that is to say, an animal with four parents-is, again, on the frontier of international research. Again, it is languishing in Australia because we are simply not paying attention to these Australian scientists whose work is on the international frontier and who are entitled to look to the Australian Government for financial and other support to help them push those frontiers forward a little more.

The final points that I wish to make relate to the question of the regulation of all of this work and the concerns that are being expressed about genetic engineering and what we are to do about genetic engineering. An article published some time ago in Fortune magazine gave me some cause to stop and think. It was entitled: 'The Cloning Era' and was written by Gene Bylinsky. The important thing that I learned from that article was that this work at a plant level has been going on successfully now for two decades. In fact, in 1960 the Cornell biologist, Frederick C. Steward, had started to grow plants-in this case it was a carrot which he grew from a single cell of a pre-existing plant. That was 20 years ago. Work on animals started in the 1950s and, in the early 1960s, clones-in this case, only of fairly lowly clawed frogs-were actually produced by him. I am talking of the early 1960s. In 1975, scientists came very close to producing cloned animals in rabbits, grown from single cells. So, it cannot be said by anybody that the technique is suddenly new, that we have not had an exposure to it, or that we have not had time to take in its consequences.

Individual genes have already been synthesised. The first work in this area was reported in 1970 by a team headed by Dr Khorana of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Again, that was 10 years ago. On reading in a scientific journal entitled Across the Board an article headed 'Should scientists play God', I was staggered to find a cartoon by the famous cartoonist Dan Barry who drew the Flash Gordon cartoon series of the early 1950s, in which cartoon interferon was identified as a drug. In fact in this case it was going to be used, I think, to cure a traveller suffering from deep space plague. I repeat: That was in the early 1950s. Interferon, which Time and Newsweek are now carrying as their front cover series of the great wonder drug of the 1980s, almost 30 years ago was being talked about in some of the literature and picked up in the esoteric literature as having some potential value in medical research.
The United States National Research Council in terms of talking about elaborate equipment, that is to say, what is called recombinant DNA engineering stated:
The magnitude of the breakthrough provided by recombinant DNA is hard to estimate.

It in fact changes the very nature of the thinking that we ought to be bringing to the question of medical research and to the question of the cure of diseases like cancer and the production of useful bacteria for industry and for commerce. The question is to a large extent: Is anybody in the Australian Government giving the slightest bit of attention to regulations or to procedures which ought to be followed as far as the control, let alone the support, of this sort of research is concerned?

Honourable senators will recall that many years ago a mild panic ensued in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The city fathers at Cambridge, Massachusetts, passed some municipal regulation or ordinance, the aim of which was to prevent genetic engineering being undertaken at the nearby Harvard University. Scientists in the United States started to become very panicky about this situation. In 1971, the scientists, Robert Pollack and Paul Berg, suddenly became very jittery about the whole matter. They called a conference in 1973 known as the Gordon conference, which recommended to the American scientific establishment that there be no further work done on genetic engineering. In 1975 the so-called Asilomar conference was held in California. Scientists from all over the world came to it, including Australian scientists, and agreed to what in fact was a scientific moratorium on work on genetic engineering, much the same as Einstein and Fermi had at a later stage urged scientists of the world after the Second World War to get together to put a moratorium on further development in nuclear engineering. In 1975, this was taken to be the correct way in which to go about things.

As I have said, some people fought very publicly against it, James Watson, the famous Nobel Prize winner, being one of them. In Australia, that action has led to the establishment of a committee at the University of Melbourne of which Professor Max Charlesworth was the chairman and which produced a report on genetic engineering. It came to similar conclusions. In its report, the committee recommended:

The Open Inquiry has concluded that the benefits promised from recombinant DNA research are not so clearly advantageous to society that the immediate prosecution of the work is essential. Its potential impact has not yet received sufficient attention. We therefore believe that: there should be a further halt on all work in the field of the recombinant DNA research to permit the evaluation of the potential impact.

That is somewhat of a Luddite view, I believe, and has been seen to be so since that date. In fact, since that date the pendulum has gone in entirely the other direction. James Watson, of the famous Watson and Crick double-helix Nobel prizewinning team, is reported in the bulletin of the atomic scientists as saying:
I believe we should quickly and resolutely abandon any form of recombinant DNA regulation.

The United States has recently reported that approximately 85 per cent of the experiments now covered by the National Institute of Health guidelines on recombinant DNA research would be exempted from most of the rules under a proposal recently approved, by a vote of 10 to 4, by the recombinant DNA Advisory Committee. The same has happened in the United Kingdom. The interesting thing about what happened in the United Kingdom is that it happened after the report of a select committee of the British House of Commons. This matter was looked at by a select committee on science and technology of the House of Commons. It gathered the debate together, it investigated the matter and it made recommendations. Its recommendations were, by and large, to ease the restrictions that had occurred in the United Kingdom.

Finally, I turn to what Australia has done about this matter. The Academy of Science has been most active in this field. In its symposium in 1979 entitled 'Scientific Advances and Community Risk', a significant paper was presented by Professor G. L. Ada of the Australian National University entitled 'Genetic Engineering Research: Evaluation and Containment of Potential Risks' in which he laid down some of the issues for significant debate. That went on to be built up into a report, under the chairmanship of Professor Fenner, which was issued in 1980. Recommendation No. 1 reads:
The federal government should establish a Surveillance Committee to supervise all work with recombinant DNA in Australia. This Committee should have a Scientific Subcommittee.
I do not know how many honourable senators have noted that the Government in fact has announced it intends to do that. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 July 1980 states:
The Federal Government is to set up a committee to supervise genetic engineering research and its industrial uses.

I wrote to the Minister for Science and the Environment, Mr Thomson, and suggested that if in fact there was going to be a committee to supervise genetic engineering research and its industrial uses it should have on it representatives of the Commonwealth Parliament. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Minister for Science and the Environment to me, dated 23 October 1980, in which the Minister makes some response, essentially saying why at this stage he does not believe it appropriate for members of parliament to be appointed to committees of this sort.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR SCIENCE & THE ENVIRONMENT
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600
23 October 1980
Dear Chris,

Thank you for your letter of 28 July 1980 in which you sought more information on, and made some suggestions, about, the composition of the new committee which is to monitor recombinant DNA research and development in Australia.

I am conscious of the need to balance any conjectured hazards against the potential value of the technique's applications. As you will realise, this will require highly technical assessments of the available data on the technique and wide consultation concerning the actual terms of any guidelines. I see this being an on-going interactive process.

I believe that it is highly desirable to establish the committee as soon as possible. To achieve the minimum delay, the structure adopted for the new committee draws heavily on past experience and follows closely that recommended by the Australian Academy of Science's report. The committee itself will in the main examine issues related to primary and secondary industrial research and application of R-DNA techniques. A scientific sub-committee will monitor basic research in a similar manner to that conducted to date by the Academy of Science's Committee on Recombinant DNA molecules.

I am attracted to your suggestion of having one or two members of Parliament serve on the committee. My attention has been drawn to a number of monitoring committee models in use overseas and I have noted that some involve general community and parliamentary representatives. However, as I am sure you will agree, your proposal constitutes a major policy option which has implications beyond this subject. It would fall outside the arrangements already agreed to by the Government and would need to be brought before Cabinet. I am reluctant to do so now because it would mean a delay in appointing the committee.

When I again bring this matter before the Government I intend to canvass a number of more general policy questions. For example, I expect to raise the possibility of creating programs for actively encouraging the commercial application of recombinant DNA techniques. It is not possible, however, to obtain Government decisions on such matters at present. As you know significant proposals must be the subject of extensive consultations and perhaps negotiation among Ministers and their departments before submissions can come to Cabinet for decision.

In summary, therefore, let me indicate sympathy with your suggestion, advise you that it will be seriously considered but that the arrangements which have been already agreed to by the Government do not readily allow for such an initiative at this time.
Your interest in this matter is appreciated.
Yours sincerely, DAVID THOMSON
Senator Christopher Puplick,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, if Australia is standing on the threshold not only of a major series of scientific breakthroughs but also breakthroughs which have contained within them major commercial considerations which touch upon research, which touch upon Australian patent legislation, which touch upon the role of the Parliament in regulating these matters, which touch upon the enormous commercial benefit to be gained, which touch upon a situation which may be lifesaving for hundreds of thousands if not millions of Australian and which may, in fact, be another step in freeing ourselves from technological dependence upon the United States, the United Kingdom, the Swiss drug companies or whoever it happens to be, it seems to me to be unfortunate that the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia has not given any real consideration to this matter in the course of what is now 30-odd years of exposure to the development of genetic engineering and its offshoots. Within the course of the last 10 years major public debates have taken place in the United Kingdom and the United States and a House of Commons select committee dealt with this matter five or six years ago; but this Parliament has not even started to come to grips with any of the issues which seem to me to be of significance.
—Are you critical of the Minister's reply?

—Yes. It will be seen in reading the Minister's reply that he says that he wants, in fact, to respond to the Academy of Science's recommendation and to establish the committee and a scientific committee fairly quickly. I am extremely critical of the decision that is made that says that in setting guidelines, which are not purely scientific guidelines but are also ethical guidelines, and guidelines about the industrial, commercial, patent use of advances in scientific research and technology, it should not be thought appropriate that the Commonwealth Parliament could have direct input or direct representation on that sort of committee. I see it as a completely proper role for the Commonwealth Parliament or for members of the Parliament interested in scientific matters to be able to play. I hope that in making this contribution on the number of scientific reports which are before us this evening I will indicate to the Minister and perhaps to anybody else in his Department who takes these matters seriously that there are some members of the Parliament who try to keep at least a brief on these things and that the Government simply cannot expect the situation to continue without the scrutiny of the Commonwealth Parliament, the way that it has done for the last 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The continuing policy of the Government is to strengthen the parliamentary system and to enable Parliament adequately to review the activities of government administration. In recent years the Government has taken a number of major steps in this area. These include the establishment of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure to allow for closer examination of the effectiveness and economy of public expenditure in the delivery of Government policy, and the expansion of the Public Accounts Committee's charter to bring within its purview the accounts of statutory authorities and other government bodies. The Bill now before honourable senators provides a similar expansion to the role of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

The current Public Works Committee Act 1969, provides as a general rule that a public work to be undertaken within Australia or an external Territory for a Commonwealth department and estimated to cost more than $2m, shall not be commenced unless it has been considered by the Committee. The major thrust of this Bill is to bring the works of the statutory authorities, instrumentalities and other bodies as well as overseas works, under the purview of the Public Works Committee.

Some authorities and types of works will continue to be exempt from the Act because of their special nature. The works of the Northern Territory Government and the Administration of Norfolk Island are exempted because of the relationship between these administrations and the Commonwealth, while Commonwealth works in these territories will continue to be subject to Public Works Committee review-these arrangements are parallel to provisions in the Public Accounts Committee Act. Similarly, the works of bodies established jointly by the Commonwealth with the States or other countries are exempted, as are overseas aid works because of their bilateral nature.

The works of the tertiary education institutions in the Australian Capital Territory are already subject to careful examination by the Tertiary Education Commission. These works are therefore exempted to avoid duplication. The National Capital Development Commission and the Parliament House Construction Authority are also exempted because of their specific legislation and functions.

It is recognised by the Government that certain authorities which trade, or which provide services and compete with the private sector, require considerable autonomy and flexibility. In some cases their investment proposals and financial and consortium arrangements should not reasonably be subject to an external review. The Bill therefore enable regulations to be made to exempt such authorities from the Act. It should be noted that provision is made for specific works of authorities which are not subject to the Act to be declared examinable by the Committee.

The Bill contains a number of other amendments to improve the workings of the Committee. The Committee is being given the discretionary power to conduct inquiries in private, and in respect of urban land development works the Committee may report without an inquiry. Repetitive type works may also be exempted from review following agreement with the Committee. With regard to the Committee's inquiries into overseas works, the Government is mindful of the legal and constitutional difficulties if the Committee were to conduct inquiries and take evidence in overseas countries. The Bill therefore limits the Committee's inquiries into these works to the consideration of plans, models and statements placed before it, and to the taking of evidence from people already in Australia.

The Government has decided to allow a period of 12 months to elapse after the Bill's date of assent before the works of authorities become subject to the Act. This is in recognition of the need to allow for the alterations to lead times and work loads involved in allowing for Public Works Committee review. The Public Works Committee had requested that the Act be changed to enable the Committee to make random investigations of works costing less than $2m. The Government has rejected this request for two main reasons: Firstly, the responsibilities of the Committee have already been considerably widened by this Bill; and secondly, there would be severe administrative difficulties for Commonwealth departments and authorities.

It is understood that the Committe was particularly concerned with cases where major works costing over $2m have been phased in over several years with small projects, that is below $2m. These propects have either escaped Committee scrutiny, or if referred to the Committee, have been referred at a stage where proper Committee investigation has been pre-empted by the work already done. The Government expects works totalling over $2m to be subject to parliamentary scrutiny, and will do all it can to ensure that all works required to be examined by the Committee in accordance with the Public Works Committee Act will be so examined. I have assured the Committee that should it wish to examine any work below $2m the Government would treat any request sympathetically, and would facilitate Committee investigation of any such work.

The Committee has also sought authority to examine works proposals of the National Capital Development Commission. Clause 6B of the Bill enables the Government to prescribe certain works of the NCDC as public works for purposes of the Public Works Committee Act, and thus open for scrutiny by the Committee. However, it is anticipated that the bulk of the works by NCDC will be exempted from examination by the Committee. The Government can assure the House and the Committee that should the Committee wish to examine any specific work of the NCDC, the Government would treat any request sympathetically and would facilitate Committee investigation of any work. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up too much of the time of the Senate this evening.
—Two minutes.

—It will be slightly more than two minutes. Honourable senators receive a mass of information from individuals in their private capacities, from companies and from pressure groups seeking to justify so-called worthwhile causes. It is not surprising that from time to time many of these people, companies and organisations actually overstate what might not otherwise be an unreasonable case or cause. I remind honourable senators of a document I received last year from a large company that operates in Australia, the Utah Development Company, entitled 'The Comparative Analysis of Tax and other Government Charges on Coal Mining Operations in Six Countries'.

SPEECH.PARA: This document, which I believe fits neatly into this category, appeared to have a high degree of credibility and accuracy as it was prepared, after all, by a leading firm of chartered accountants which has offices in America. The local off-shoots of this chartered accountants' firm have been fairly meticulous in dotting their i's and crossing their t's as to the requirements of tax effect accounting on many mining companies here in Australia. It appears that this firm of chartered accountants was not so meticulously accurate when called upon to perform an assignment for the Utah Development Company. The document, as I said, reads well and appears to be thoroughly researched. I was therefore surprised that from such an eminent group the figures did not show the source which supports the claims on which their argument was based.

Having something of an accounting or an inquiring mind, I was somewhat concerned at the extent of the revelations in these documents. I was also concerned about the inclusion of what I believe to be a relatively unknown producer at this point but one whom we probably acknowledged had considerable reserves. There was a difference between production and a country which held considerable reserves by the name of Indonesia. I sought the assistance of our competent Parliamentary Library staff to verify some of these statistics. From the documents which the Library produced, there appeared to be some discrepancies. The Library, of course, quite rightly sourced the material which it extracted, and it quoted the 1978 Year Book of International Trade Statistics-Trade by Commodity, United Nations. More curious than ever, I then asked the company why Indonesia, which ranks well down the list of countries which I got from the Library, was included. In fact it ranks well behind the United Kingdom which is fifth, France, the Netherlands and Italy. They are well ahead of Indonesia.

The company stated that after all Indonesia was included at our specific request because it believed that that country had significant potential for coal production-there is a difference between production and potential-despite a quite modest current production. We undoubtedly acknowledge that Indonesia has a potential to become a significant competitor with Australia in coal sales to the Asian region. I believe that it would have been far better and more persuasive for this group to have put this argument rather than adding Indonesia to a realistic list of major coal producing companies and giving the impression of its already being a large producer.

However, here comes the rub. The countries mentioned in the report did not account for more than 90 per cent of coal production outside the communist bloc, as stated in this so-called reputable document. Being unable to reconcile this 90 per cent figure with those which I received from the Library, I again asked to source the data and also the year of the figures. If one picks the wrong number in a particular year, one will get the wrong number. So I duly received further correspondence from Utah which had to refer the matter to its accountants who eventually conceded that a further audit of their figures had resulted in some significant changes. I found that in the auditor's letter, dated 19 September 1980, on page 2, first paragraph, sixth line, that figure of 90 per cent became 73 per cent-a difference of 17 percentage points. On page 3, second paragraph, 14th line, 81 per cent became 65 per cent-a difference of 16 percentage points. These changes affect the figures on pages 1, 3 and 14 of the study and also affect further figures on page two of what they refer to as their executive study. Utah subsequently acknowledged the error, but suggested -I agree with their suggestion-that the figures did not alter the thrust of the argument. That is a recognised fact because they were fairly substantial figures.

The point I make is that these countries were significant producers, but I believe that if companies are to present figures to senators to justify a cause, they should source their data and should check their figures because some of us in the Senate have an interest in these matters and do not necessarily take the information for gospel, even though it might appear to come from a credible source. They should not necessarily take politicians for fools. I issue this as a warning not only to Utah but also to other companies and groups to ensure a high degree of accuracy when making submissions to politicians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.26 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 148) Senator Douglas McClelland asked me as Minister representing the Prime Minister, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the activities of the Ministerial Review Committee, commonly referred to by the media as the razor gang. Will the Minister agree that there have been many leaked reports about the responsibilities and activities of this Ministerial Review Committee but that no ministerial statement has been made to the Parliament by the Government setting out the reasons for the establishment of the Committee and its responsibilities? As well as looking at the activities and performance of government departments and statutory authorities, does the Committee intend scrutinising in any way the administrative arrangements of the Parliament? Because the Committee's work could have great repercussions on the functioning of the Australian Public Service and many statutory authorities, will the Government prepare a statement on the work of the Committee for presentation to Parliament before the Supplementary Estimates are brought down in this sessional period?
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Committee reviewing Commonwealth functions was announced in a press statement released by the Prime Minister on Thursday, 6 November 1980. As stated in that press statement the purpose of the Review is to examine the functions of government so as to achieve a more efficient and economical administration of continuing Commonwealth responsibilities. The Government will be giving close consideration to the handling of the Report of the Review Committee when it is received shortly, including the announcement of any recommendations of the Committee accepted by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 437) Senator Walsh asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister in the Senate. The question concerned the Minister for Communications.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

'The affairs of the companies referred to by Senator Walsh together with other companies were investigated under the New South Wales Companies Act. Mr Sinclair was acquitted on all charges laid as a result of this investigation.
As a result I regard the whole issue as closed'.
